description: Food was really good. I had a pesto pasta configuration with some well prepared chicken breast. It was a nice portion, sodium levels were good, was not jonesing for liquids afterwards. I'm going back as soon as I can.
author: Henry K.

description:
I'm a big fan! My party of 4 stopped by on Friday night. Lucky for us, there was no wait, and we were immediately seated at the counter seats by the window.

For appetizers, we ordered the masantol and ulsan. The masantol (filipino style spicy sizzling tofu) was tasty and had a nice kick to it. The ulsan (pajeon/korean pancake) was soft and eggy. I prefer pajeon to be thicker and crispier, so the ulsan was just okay for me. I probably wouldn't order these side trips again.

As for mains, we ordered the lanzhou, havana and san marino. The lanzhou (egg noodles topped with ahi tuna) was very flavorful. The noodles were perfectly soft and chewy, but the ahi tuna had a bit too much pepper for our taste. The havana (Cuban fried rice) had a perfect blend of spices and was very enjoyable. The san marino risotto was also delicious, with the bacon and sweet gorgonzola providing a lot of rich flavor. I didn't care for the panko-crusted chicken on top though.

I'll definitely be back soon to try more of their menu.

Quick tips:
- The menu is seasonal!
- Don't come with a large group. There are only 3 tables for 2 and about 10 counter seats.
- Takeout is a popular option here!
author: Leanne C.

description: Not trying to minimalize the concept, but this spot is reminiscent of the awesome, old-school greasy spoon lunch spots in SOMA that we all loved because they served everything from sandwiches to fried rice, noodles, bulgogi, curry. You all know what I'm talking about! This is definitely more refined and polished and there's nothing greasy-spoon about it. You're going to get a solid meal that fits your mood, a nice glass of wine, great service, in a clean, warm and cheery environment. Very solid place in Sunset for something different and tasty.
author: Julia Y.

description:
I don't know about this place being Thai, but it is most definitely fusion! Came for dinner on a Tuesday night, 4 seats open of the ~16ish seats around 730pm. 

No thai iced tea, incase you were wondering (I was ready for one, but negatory on the menu). 

Tried the Aosta which was solid, comes with 4 "slices", good for sharing. 

Took a bite of the Cuban Style Fried Rice which was tasty! It is an extra $5 for chicken, which made the end cost steeper than expected for what it was. However, it had great flavor!

I ordered the Thai Style Rice Soup..imagine dispersed porridge in chicken broth...with some plain chicken breast pieces...toppings and a poached egg. Was very unimpressed with this but the thai chilies & sriracha made up for it. It was just...underwhelming...maybe because I was expecting something more comparable to Tom Yum Soup =[ I mean, this is a fabulous option if I felt under the weather or wanted to warm up. 

Overall Pomelo seems like a fabulous take out option, one stop that can potentially satisfy several cravings.
author: Anna S.

description: Pomelo on Judah is the best-kept secret in the Inner Sunset. This will forever be my go-to spot in the city!!! Staff and chef are wonderful.
author: Sarin P.

description:
This place has AMAZING FOOD. You usually can't go wrong with places in the Inner Sunset, and this one definitely didn't disappoint. The staff was quick to welcome us when we entered and very quick to serve us drinks and take our orders. He was also incredibly nice. 

I ordered the Havana, which was Cuban style fried rice with chicken. The best part of this was the grilled pineapples they mixed in. It gave it an incredible flavor. Also, it comes with a large portion of guac off to the side, which was a nice touch to mix in. It was a large portion, but I wound up finishing it all. 

The only negative is how small the place was. I sat right near the exit and it felt very cramped. The table was small - I could barely fit anything else on it other than my plate and drink. It was also weirdly sticky. 

All in all, it was a great meal and cute restaurant. I'd definitely come back for that fried rice.
author: Remy B.

description:
Pomelo is a solid spot for good fusion food if that's what you're into. I shared two dishes with a girlfriend, the lanzhou and koh samui. They are willing to split dishes here for an extra $1 per dish, but it's totally worth it as it was more than enough food for the both of us; I almost felt they gave us our own personal sized dish or that their portions are big enough for two meals! The Lanzhou has probably been my all-time favorite here; egg noodles fried in ginger, scallion and garlic topped with peppered ahi tuna! It's one of the more expensive dishes but it's soo worth trying. The koh samui is a coconut curry with chicken, eggplant, squash, served with jasmine rice which was super tasty. I'd recommend these two dishes if you have a palette for thai flavors, otherwise they offer other dishes with other southeast asian twists (filipino, malaysian) or non-asian (italian, cuban)

I've never seen a wait here but the restaurant is tiny; there are very cozy bar/window seating and a couple of two-seater settings. Service is good and it's in a convenient location right next to UCSF or by 9th & judah where many other shops/restaurants are. Pomelo is definitely worth a try if you're willing to splurge a bit but the quality makes it so much worth it.
author: Kathleen S.

description:
I have been eying Pomelo for a while and finally got a chance to try it this weekend. It is a tiny little restaurant next to UCSF.  They have 3 tables for 2 people each and some bar seating. 

Service was meh and disinterested. Water came after the entrees were served. One of the soup bowls was dirty.  The food was just OK. I had the Havana (beans, rice and meat) and the Suva (tofu soup). Not coming back.
author: Sunil R.

description:
I had the San Marino which was risotto with panko-crusted chicken. I loved it! It was a really unique dish - I've never had anything that tasted like it, and it was also beautifully presented. 

My friend and I shared a dessert that the waiter recommended. Honestly not sure what it was called but it had a German name, I believe. It had strawberry rhubarb and was sort of a pudding consistency and it was crazy good! Highly recommend. 

The restaurant itself is pretty tiny, so it's not a good place for groups. Better for a 2-person party.
author: Tiffany P.

description:
I really enjoyed the food and ambiance here and I can't wait to come back! Everything we ordered was delicious! We ordered the Aosta as a side dish and the Havana and Otsu as the mains.

Aosta: The dish included three polentas (cornmeal flat cakes) topped with a bunch of enoki mushrooms and a buttery sauce. Super good!

Havana: We ordered the Havana with grilled chicken breast, which was very tender, and substituted the white rice with brown rice (+$1). I especially liked the mild sweetness from the chopped plantains in the fried rice. The flavor combination of everything -- the chicken, guacamole, and plantains -- made this dish so unique and delicious. 

Otsu: The soba noodles were al dente and at just the right temperature (I was expecting them to be pretty cold, but they were near room temperature). The dish as a whole did not have a very strong taste. The noodles had a lemon-y sauce on them and the tofu was grilled just a little bit (they did not have the toughness and crunch of fried tofu). I loved the simplicity and lightness of this dish.

Service was great! And even though the space is really small, it is comfortable (we came here on a Tuesday night, so it was not overly crowded). The seats at the bar have a good view of the open kitchen.
author: Celena C.

description: I am always skeptical of 'fusion' - but Pomelo does this tastefully. All without fluff or fuss - the wine list is impeccable, and the pancit takes me back to the Philippines every time. EVERYTHING tastes amazing, and the crew is always so polite. I am a huge fan of intimate places to dine - and this is one of them. Love love love. Thank you, Nelson - for always making us feel like family.
author: Richie B.

description: Pomelo needs more photos of it's excellently plated deliciousness :) Small and cozy. When we visited on an evening around 6:30 pm and there was no wait. They offered a special of the night, which is a must order. Otherwise the menu is fairly simple, which I have mentally decided I would probably be able to try all the dishes :3 The portions are more than enough for one person, and we both were able to bring some of the goodness home.
author: Fanny T.

description: We stopped in after checking out the Gardens in Golden Gate on a Friday night, and they had a table available. This restaurant is bitsy, but intimate. The owners were very nice. I had one of the best curries in my life! It had mushrooms, chicken, and eggplant. The flavors were perfect, sweet and spicy. I felt badly when they asked if my food was ok, since I wasn't able to finish my meal. Next time I'll come in hungrier.
author: Ha D.

description:
Just had an excellent plate of ahi tuna with delicious noodles here in the sunset area of San Francisco. Talk about a true fusion experience! Thai, Cuban, Chinese, Philippine meld run buy a Swiss owner serving only German beer.   Doesn't get much more diverse than this.  The food was exceptional, reasonable priced in the mainstream and portions for lunch were large!  I am visiting from New York and was told by a friend to check this out. Restaurant is located on Judah street and 6th  hence the name...   

The establishment is not large and reminds you of street fare / tapas in Barcelona Spain. Don't let the size fool you.  The flavor of the cuisine is immense!
author: John D.

description: Get ready for a tour around the world's most amazing, delectable delights!  Pomelo does Asian fusion justice and really is the perfect cozy place to reconnect with friends, family, or have a romantic first date over some very reasonably priced, generous portions of amazingness.  My partner and I tried 5-8 items on the menu and each dish brought me to a place I've visited (or want to visit) around the world and reminded me of why good food has no borders.  I love this place, and will definitely be back.
author: Kai H.

description: Kind of a trendy place. Super small, I would say there was only 3 tables and then counter space. Food was okay, kinda pricey.  My four year old daughter hd to sit on a bar stool cause there were no more tables and they didn't have high chairs for kids.
author: Gregory G.

description:
I came here for lunch looking for hefty meal to hold me over.

I was originally going to head down to Irving ave to go find some kind of Asian Fusion place to get some quality eating in but because this place was closer I came here. I wasn't sure what to expect but I decided to stop and check out the menu in the window. 

The menu selection is small but that did not defer me away from coming here. I walked on in and immediately found myself right in the middle of this place. The other reviews are not lying when they say that this place is TINY! There are a FEW tables, window seating, and a counter seating area. Limited seating makes for close encounter for lunch if this place gets packed. I would estimate maximum capacity is maybe 20 - 25, I'm being generous!

I had hoped that there was a lunch menu that differed from the window menu but it is the same. Once I was seated I glanced over the menu one more time and then made a decision, I was really hungry. I ordered the manila dinner.

When the food finally arrived I went to town on this food. I was more excited for the Chinese sausage that comes in this meal. The pancit was very good. The chicken was cooked really well but there was not a lot of shrimp in this meal, that was unfortunate. The overall meal was not what a good reflection of the price or portion of the meal. I felt like I was missing a side salad or soup to go along with my meal. I think that would've made a HUGE difference for me in coming here. A side salad or soup INCLUDED would've been great. I was not going to pay an additional fee for either, just to be clear.

The cost of the meal was $12.50 if this helps in anyway, be advised. 

I honestly feel like this place has so much potential but it needs to expand more. Th expansion of the menu and the incorporation of a lunch menu could do wonders for this place, especially with the prime location.

Parking around this area is EXTREMELY terrible so expect to circle for awhile or take public transit.

My midday chow down could've been better, oh well.
author: Robert F.

description: I just love their food and it's perfectly cooked every single time. The Cuban fried rice with plantains plus flank steak is one of my favorite meals ever- like a sophisticated version of the most comfy home food. I love the fish tacos. It's a tiny place and in an area with a ton of fast sit-down food but don't be confused because this is not your random forgettable meal.  The dishes are vivid, well composed, and made with fresh ingredients.
author: Marina N.

description: Caught up with my best friend for dinner at Pomelo! I wish the place were bigger, because it feels like eating in an in-law unit, and the place gets super stuffy since the kitchen isn't separated from the dining area. The manager makes sure his patrons are happy with the service and food. I ordered the manila aka Filipino style stir fried rice noodles tossed with sautéed prawns, chicken, chinese sausage, vegetables, scallion, and lemon. It was SO GOOD! I think I can eat this dish every week, but that wouldn't be great for my waistline. This spot is great for intimate dates or a small party of four/double dates.
author: Joanne K.

description:
Convenient location next to UCSF Parnassus. We walked from the hospital so parking wasn't an issue. If you're driving, give yourself extra time to find street parking as the area is very busy around the university/medical center. Usually I can find parking but need to be willing to walk. The area is very hilly so if this is a concern, opt to take public transit (the 43 muni comes by here) or the N Judah will bring you to the bottom of the hill. 

The menu is very unique, with wonderful flavor combinations. Even though it was healthy, it was like comfort food in a way because it was so hearty. Plus, the service was really great. The waiter was friendly, willing to ask questions, and kept our water glasses full. 

There isn't a lot of space in here so it may be really busy around lunch time. Can't wait to get back to try something else off the menu.
author: Susan G.

description:
Split two plates with a friend and both were pretty good! We tried the ever popular Havana and Lanzhou. The lanzhou was pretty good - noodles were soft, chewy, and seasoned well. The ahi tuna was seared nicely and definitely provided a unique touch to this dish. The deep fried lotus chips were also very yummy. However, we both weren't really a fan of the slivers of ginger that were tossed in. 

As for the havana, the flavors were definitely stronger on the palate. It was smokey, yet warm from the spices, and a bit fruity with the addition of the plantains. Additionally, the avocado chimichurri was excellent - it definitely brought the dish to the next level. We opted to have this dish topped with May's chicken breast which was marinated then grilled to perfection. This was definitely the favorite of the two dishes!
author: Elaine Y.

description:
My review is only on 2 items:

ulsan: delicious seafood pancake (fried goodness)
lanzhou: amazing ahi tuna with delicious noodles (a hearty meal)

This place is TINY. I mean TINY. I think it seats about 10 people total. So come right when they open if you want to eat here. The UCSF people are well aware of the hidden gem this place is.
author: Nikita K.

description:
It's okay here. Super tiny place, small selection of quality plates, good service, but a little overpriced for what you get. 

I tried:
Lanzhou ($17)- garlic noodles with ahi tuna. Overall, presented nicely, but a little overpriced.

Korean pancake- again, presented nicely like little pizzas, and was tasty.

Service was attentive- my water was never left empty.

Overall, this restaurant serves a variety of different Asian flavors. I don't see anything else  worth trying though, so I probably won't be back.
author: Corinna T.

description: Teensy tiny restaurant with just a few tables & a about six counter seas, but consistently delicious. The Otsu with buckwheat noodles, tofu, scallions & cucumbers is usually one of (if not the the only) vegetarian entree listed on the muni, but there are always several vegetarian appetizers & they can usually modify to make a few other entrees vegetarian. Even if the Otsu was the only veggie option though, I could happily eat it once a month. They seem to take a pride in their food & the quality is consistent.
author: Marybeth S.

description: GO HERE!!!! I CANNOT SAY ENOUGH GOOD THINGS ABOUT THIS PLACE NOR CAN I STOP EMPHATICALLY RECOMMENDING IT! I am not the most experienced when it comes to different types of food so that normally leaves me rather hesitant to try new places but wow did this place knock my picky eater socks off! It is Latin - Asian fusion. I had the Manila (stir fried rice noodles with prawns, chicken, and Chinese sausage) and I can't stop thinking about it weeks later. The portion was huge (I can't tell you how excited I was to break into those leftovers the next day) and the mix of meat is incredible. I had never even heard of Chinese sausage before but now it's all I ever want. I could go on and on. It is SUPER tiny so be aware of that and plan accordingly. They have two sets of bar seating and I think 3 tables (I think the whole place can maybe fit 20 people?) The owners are absolutely lovely. Seriously cannot wait to go back here.
author: Elizabeth H.

description: Such unique and yummy flavors! Good wine list and attentive service! Been going here for years! Your taste buds will be happy you went!
author: Benjamin S.

description:
If I could dine here every night and have their special of the day each and every day, I would. So would my mom. That says a lot for two ladies who absolutely love dining out in San Francisco. 

My favorite part about this place was not the food, the atmosphere or being able to watch every single dish freshly prepared and cooked. All of those things were amazing, but not why I'm giving this place a huge 5 star review (can I give it 10?!). My favorite part was Nelson, the part owner of this amazing place. As soon as my mom and I walked in, Nelson greeted us with a huge smile and sat us at the bar area (where we were able to watch the amazing chef in action). During our entire dining experience, Nelson would come by to our table and make sure we were doing okay. After our meal, he gave my mom a huge hug, which made my mom even more happier and inclined to come back. She literally can't wait. A huge thank you to Nelson, we will see you soon!!

Now, lets critique the food. I am an extremely picky eater (sorry to everyone that has to eat out with me) and I can manage to eat more than half of this menu. It's extremely veggie and seafood friendly. It's also one of the most eclectic menu's that I've seen in San Francisco. Food varies from Thai, to Mexican, to Philippino, to Japanese to American to.... I can go on and on. My mom and I shared the special of the day (fresh wild snapper with spinach, wild mushrooms and barley) and the soba noodles with tofu. We also ordered the bread (which my mom begged not to) but then was so happy that we did because she used every last piece to soak up the yummy sauces from our plates. We literally devoured each and every bite and if we could lick the plate, we would (if only that was appropriate...)! 

My other favorite part about this place was watching the chef prepare and cook all of the meals. You can just tell how much passion he has for cooking. There was something so relaxing about it too. My mom sipped her wine and I could tell just how relaxed she was, which made me so happy. If you come here, get a table at the bar - you won't regret it!

Tip: Get their homemade hot sauce - absolutely amazing. 

All in all, this place deserves more than 5 stars. I wouldn't change anything about it. A note to the owner: my mom loves to cook and is an amazing cook - perhaps she can help you create a Russian influenced special of the day? :)
author: Anastasia N.

description:
Came here for lunch with some family on another family member's recommendation. First impression: this place is SMALL! Maybe 8 seated around the counter overlooking the cooking/prep are (very Benihana-styled, intentionally or not), and then 12 or so available seats at tables. Felt cramped, but I guess that's not uncommon for some smaller restaurants in San Francisco. 

Pomelo is located very close to UCSF, with only street parking available. We were fortunate to have arrived before the lunch rush, as we found parking across the street, and pretty much all other open tables were taken by the time we were midway through our lunch.

The server was very kind and extremely professional. The chefs were efficient and quick. It was actually very enjoyable to watch them do their thing and prepare the dishes.

The 'gist' of Pomelo is almost like asking you "WHERE do you want to eat today?" Their appetizers and main plates are based off locales, such as the Koh Samui (Thai-based chicken dish) or Manila (essentially Filipino noodles known as "Pancit"). It didn't feel like a typical "let's try and cover every genre" restaurant: it felt more like they perfected specific dishes from different regions and made that their offering. When I say perfected, I mean it. Our group each ordered different dishes, and they were all outstanding. A personal surprising favorite of mine was the Polenta cakes appetizer, which when mixed with the included sauce, made your eyes pop and go "whoah." It was a great combination of both textures and flavors that I would definitely love to experience again. 

I would absolutely recommend Pomelo to everyone. I know they have two locations, but I cannot vouch for the other location. Quick tip, check their business hours, as they are a bit unique, and arrive early, ahead of lunch/dinner rushes for both parking and seats.
author: Lyn M.

description:
This place is my favorite restaurant in SF.  Good value and delicious food.

The restaurant is about the definition of a hole in the wall.  The entire place can't be more than 400 sq ft, but they make it work!  

As a tip, don't come here in a big group, you'll have a hard time finding seats together.
author: Phil D.

description:
A very small restaurant with very tight and limited seating, but the dishes are super creative and true fusion!
We ordered most recommended Lanzhou, Otsu and Havana. The portion is just right--we are 3 females and we are full but not stuffed.
All are delicious, though in general a bit saltier than what I prefer, especially Lanzhou. Otsu is very refreshing, Havana is very flavorful! The use of mixed ingredients and flavors are truly creative.
author: Ya K.

description:
Going out with a friend for dinner who was a pescatarian, Pomelo was the perfect choice since it catered to both of us.  But despite me being a meat-eater, I decided to go into pescatarian mode as well and ordered their seafood pancake and soba noodles with tofu.

Ulsan -- pa-jeon - korean scallion pancakes with scallop, prawn, red and green chiles, egg and spicy dipping sauce
This was a decent attempt for a Korean pancake.  It had a good amount of seafood inside and made for a great starter to share with my friend.

Otsu -- cold buckwheat noodle salad with cucumber, scallion, cilantro and a spicy soy, ginger & sesame dressing, topped with pan sautéed tofu
While the tofu was a little lacking in flavor, the soba noodles made up for it since they were full of flavor from the dressing.

Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed Pomelo.  My only real gripe with the place is that parking around the area sucks, but that really doesn't deter from the dining experience there.  The atmosphere is a cozy and it's a great place to take a date or a close friend for dinner.  I hope to go back and try their other menu items which do change seasonally.
author: Rodney H.

description:
Pomelo on Judah is certainly one of the most unique restaurants I've visited in SF. The restaurant is very small and intimate with mostly bar seating and a few small tables, and the menu options are incredibly diverse with influences from so many different cuisines around the world! I met a friend here for dinner on a weeknight and got seated at one of the tables. For the appetizer, we ordered the grilled fish taco, which was topped with a good amount of shredded cabbage and served with a mango relish and pickled jalapenos. While I've had better tacos, the tastiest part of the dish was the grilled fish, which was perfectly cooked and seasoned. We then split two items for our main course. The Lanzhou, the stir-fried noodles with ahi tuna, was very, very garlicky; the egg noodles were a little bit heavy for my taste, but the ahi tuna was perfectly seared and so tasty and peppery--this was some of the most flavorful tuna I've had! We also split the Havana, a Cuban fried rice, with the skirt steak on top. I was very impressed with the skirt steak, which was still pink on the inside and surprisingly tender (not typical for this kind of steak!). The fried rice was definitely one of the most unique fried rices I've had, as it contained black beans and even mashed plantains! The dish was also served with a simple avocado salad on the side, which was a great complement. 

Overall, the dishes here are so unique and definitely well-executed. For my tastes, they were a little bit heavy and carb-centric, but I'd definitely be interested in sampling more of the selections from Pomelo!
author: David K.

description: Just as good as the original location in Noe. One of the most inventive fusion menus I've tasted, and we had just a few items so we can't wait to sample the rest of the items.  Faves are definitely the Havana with the steak, so delicious with their perfectly seasoned Cuban rice, and the Manila with the Filipino style fried noodles with prawns, chicken and Chinese sausage.  I love throwing some Sambal Oelek on those noodles, sets of off just right! My wife enjoyed the Forestville, which is their bruschetta with honey roasted butternut squash and fresh ricotta-goat cheese.  If you like the sound of these items, you'll love the rest of their menu. Service is friendly, prices are average.
author: Saminda W.

description: Great little place for lunch by UCSF. Fast service, tasty food, and cooked on demand.  Also, it is very well priced. Will absolutely come again.
author: Nicholas K.

description: I love coming to pomelo for lunch.  Portions are always huge.  I am a big fan of Manila Noodles (Pancit) , Otsu (Cold buckwheat noodles and tofu) and Nan (Rice soup with chicken).   The staff are all friendly and attentive to your needs.  This location is rather small, it can get busy during the lunch rush.
author: Luis E.

description: Cute and cozy spot for a casual and quiet dinner. I ordered the Havana with steak - tasty flavor combination. Service is great! Parking might be tough.
author: Erin C.

description:
Taste: 3.5 Price: 3 I ordered Korean pancake as a starter. It was good, but it lacked the seared crispiness that I like. For the entree, I had the Manila stir fry rice noodles. It came with shrimp, Chinese sausage, cabbage and chicken. Each bite had plenty of meat and cabbage, but I felt that they skimped out on the noodles. Since I ordered a noodle based dish, I expected more noodles. 

One thing I like about this restaurant is its casual ambience. You can see the chef cook your food if you sit at the bar. Who doesn't like a free show? The interior of restaurant is small yet cozy. It feels like you're at the open kitchen of a friend's apartment.
author: Alex Z.

description:
Such good food. This Restaurant is close to my work, so I manage to eat here during my lunch break from time to time. So many yummy dishes! The Nan soup is unbelievably tasty, complex and satisfying. 
I've ordered the menu up and down in the past, and every dish is just so good! Service is great, too!
The other day, they added Goulash with Spaetzle to the menu. Tried it and almost fainted. Beyond delicious!!
author: d c.

description:
Got here right when it opened and I'm glad we did as once it hit noon, it was busy.  Restaurant is pretty small as it fits less than 20 people, but during lunch, it's a great place to get in and get out quickly.

Originally, I was going to order Asian food, but then at the last minute, I decided to order the Cabo San Lucas, which were 2 grilled fish tacos.  It was off their side menu, but for me, it was an entree.  It came with shredded cabbage, mango salsa, some spicy sauce, and pickled jalapeños which were pretty spicy as well.  Simple food, but real intense flavors.

My husband had the Nan which was their Thai-style congee and that was delicious too!  I would have been happy with that dish as well.  Not heavy like the Chinese congees.

Overall, great place for lunch!
author: Erica S.

description:
I kind of don't want to write this, as it's a tiny restaurant down my road and I like being able to get a table!
But it's too wonderful to not review. Interesting menu, great food, nice atmosphere and the owner is super friendly too
author: Kate H.

description:
Pomelo, pomelo.
The large pomelo attached above their doors is eye catching and progressive, just like their food.

My sister and I enjoyed a delicious and healthy ful lunch sub-45 minutes.

We ordered to share:
Butternut squash + ricotta Bruschetta
Havana plate.

The bruschetta was so yummy. The crunch was wow and the flavor was explosive. The Havana place looked like the popular plate as we could see the chefs churning over plates in the open kitchen. I would highly recommend it. They give a nice helping plantains, rice, beans, and yummmmm SIRLOIN SKIRT STEAK. 

We washed this down with water and bottomless ginger lemongrass tea, unsweetened!
author: Bern M.

description: Yes!  Pomelo on Judah serves some delicious, clean food.  I've lived just down the block for almost 35 years and have passed this place a lot yet never stopped in, it always looked so tiny but today my friend met me for lunch here.  First, the place is small as others have said but, hey, I can pick up delicious food and go home, take off my shoes and eat.  All the staff we met were friendly and courteous, not overly attentive, just right.  Food was good.  I had the Manila, which reminded me slightly of pancit, but enhanced!  Enough fresh, lovely vegs, had shrimp, had slices of sausage (not really necessary but there anyway), in a sauce I can't figure out or I'd start making this for ourselves all the time.  I couldn't finish it all so they boxed it and I've got it in the frig for tomorrow lunch.  My friend had the dish with fried tofu and soba noodles.  She doesn't eat hoofed animals, and I don't eat wheat but we found enough on the menu to have to  go "gee, which should I choose??? They all sound so good!"  I didn't even notice there was dessert, but I don't eat dessert either so I didn't look.  They let us sit and talk too, hogging our table (If we'd seen lots of people lining up to get in, we would have removed ourselves).  I'll be back so I can order all the other things on the various menus.  They choose their vegetables wisely, everything is so fresh (crunchy snow peas in winter), flavors are not overpowering yet significantly there, combinations seem to work.  Now I'm sorry I waited so long to eat here.
author: Kai T.

description:
A cozy Asian-fusion/international kitchen that is literally a kitchen with a few tables + counter. I've had the brunch on the Church location and it has a similar, small but cozy vibe. This location only had lunch and dinner and quite different hours. 

I had the Lanzhou, which was Ahi tuna seared with garlic noodles. There was some ginger and other spices as well. The tuna was seasoned quite well and had nice texture and seared almost perfectly. The noodles were also cooked well and not overly salty. My only complaint would be the food was piping hot temperature wise. I also tried a bit of the coconut curry and it was quite creamy, but still had good Southeast Asian flavors. I think this dish did burn my tongue. 

Besides the food being too hot (and the restaurant being warm inside too), this place has a nice variety of dishes from vegetarian to meat and features a lot of cool flavor mixes from around the world. Come here for a nice 1-on-1 dinner.
author: Steven V.

description: This tiny jewel of a restaurant has an incredibly diverse menu featuring dishes from around the globe. I kept thinking "how can a small kitchen pull off all these amazing and varied dishes!l" but I've eaten here 4 or 5 times now and each time, I've said THIS is my favorite meal I've had here! Wonderful hosts who treat each diner like friends and fast service --a winning combo! Check it out.
author: Brent O.

description: Intimate ambiance. Food is a mix of several countries and it was delicious, I ordered the Havana plate, I was not disappointed.
author: Arely F.

description: Would recommend to all who like food that tastes great! Very small cozy place in SF. Delicious food at a very reasonable price!! Coffee is to die for!!!!!
author: John M.

description: I'm a huge fan of Pomelo's Havana dish with grilled skirt steak and brown rice substitution. The combination of the steak with black beans, plantains, guacamole, cilantro, ginger and sauteed onions tossed with rice is super delicious.
author: C L.

description:
For anyone looking for a quick bite in the Inner Sunset area (especially UCSF affiliates), Pomelo is a great bet. It's only a few blocks off campus and serves fresh flavorful Asian fusion cuisine. I'd recommend going in with an open mind as this is not traditional Asian food- but still quite as enjoyable. The foods are mainly in the $11-$16 range. I ordered the Manila for $11.50 which is clear glass noodles, shrimp, chicken, and Chinese sausage. I enjoyed it and it reminds me a little of Singapore curry noodles. 

There is no AC and the seating is limited. Typically that isn't a problem but with the recent heat wave in SF, I figured I would give a heads up. They do accept credit cards. Service is prompt and table turnover is quick.
author: Nicole J.

description:
Very unfriendly. Refused my child a booster or highchair. Tried to get us to sit at the bar, despite a table opening up. We ended up just requesting the table, with no accommodations for the toddler. 

The food is mediocre and very expensive for the apparent quality. As an SF resident, I really want to like this place, but my multiple experiences there do not justify a good review.
author: Alexander K.

description: Incredible! Very good service. You get to watch the cooks working their magic. Amazing flavors. Awesome and unique selection of Mexican and Asian fusion. Not so big yet that you can't get a table on a Friday night without a reservation. Comfortable, home like atmosphere.
author: Kristen K.

description:
Great food, fresh and creative menu. A bit pricey, but reliably good.

The place is super tiny, so I usually do takeout.
author: Kelly B.

description: Really enjoyed the food. Everything tasted fresh. The curry I got wasn't too sweet and had a lot of flavor.
author: Colin F.

description: My favorite go-to place in the neighborhood! Consistently great food, freshly made to order and seasonal menu. Strongly recommend.
author: Yulia R.

description: It's ok. I thought that maybe I ordered the wrong thing the first time, but after another visit, I'm convinced the food just isn't that great. The presentation was nice though. The space itself is very cramped.
author: Steve F.

description:
It's always unnerving when a restaurant can't open on time. 5:33pm and waiting. A minute later, a gentleman runs up and unlocks the door and holds it open for us. He is very soft spoken and apologizes for being slightly late. 

This is a very tiny place, but very cozy and intimate. It was well lit. We were given menus and water. 

We ordered:
+ Lanzhou - $16 - fresh egg noodles stir fried with ginger, scallion and garlic, with peppered ahi tuna, seared rare and topped with a miso-sesame drizzle. 
++ This dish was very delicious. The flavours came together well, it was nice and garlicky. The scallions and ginger really brightened this dish up in terms of flavour. The ahi tuna was a huge chunk sear rare. Very delicious.

+ aosta - $8.5 - baked polenta and gourmet mushroom ragù with madeira and cream. 
++ This dish was very cream heavy. Due to the heaviness, it can essentially be a meal on its own as you'll feel quite bloated after. Overall, it was a decent dish. Pretty much fried cornmeal with a heavy gravy sauce. Not my favourite.

We were not rushed at all, water was a bit slow to be refilled, but it was eventually without asking. This is a cute little place with fairly large entrees. The food was definitely good, and since we sat at the bar, we watched other foods get made. Definitely want to try more of their menu!

By the end of our meal, the whole restaurant was filled up and we were having a hard time hearing each other. You definitely have to raise your voice to talk if the place is full. Not a good thing... :/

Recommended and I'll be back.
author: Kaje Y.

description: We stumbled upon this place because it was the closest place to UCSF that was open late. The food was delicious and the staff super friendly. Good way to end an exhausting day.
author: Judy A.

description: Great food in a relaxed setting! Try the butternut squash bruschetta. It is wonderful. The service was great and the food unlike anywhere else we've eaten. Great neighborhood spot.
author: Kristen P.

description:
Love this little resto just a block from UCSF! My coworker was able to join us on her lunch break :) There's only maybe 15ish seats in here, and it can fill up fast during prime time, so plan accordingly. We had no problems at 1pm on a Wednesday though.

EVERYTHING on the menu is good. I got the ayacucho with the fish of the day -- snapper. Fresh and bright and seemingly healthy. My friends' havana and lanzhou looked crazy good too. Huge servings. I NEED to try that polenta (aosta) next time.
author: Vivian H.

description: I've eaten here for dinner twice while visiting UCSF.  I had the chicken tostada both times. Yummy!
author: Jan F.

description: This is a SF gem. This TINY restaurant is walk-in only but somehow never has much of a wait. Simply put, the food is amazing. Both my girlfriend and I are both vegetarian and we love the bok choy and the mushroom over polenta (which somehow tastes like French Toast). Grab a few glasses of wine from the small but interesting wine list and you have a great night out.
author: Paul W.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant every time I am at UCSF Parnassus campus. Food is great and so with the owners Nelson Miranda and Ron. 

Armando their chef, makes the Manila noodle so so so good, very authentic and that's one of my favorite dish to order and the Havanna..... you guys have to try it and I promise you that you won't regret it !!!!

Try visiting the other location they have and It's by Church Street in San Francisco, they serve brunch on weekends too!!! Go Yelp it and also you can like them on your Facebook.....
author: Raquel S.

description:
I can't help but wonder how they brainstormed this name. Perhaps there was a pomelo tree that previously grew in the plot of land the restaurant sits on.

Wait, do pomelos even grow on trees?

My Cal-to-UCSF friend and I visited on a Sunday evening. We were fortunate that at 6:30 PM, the small 16-seat restaurant was not that crowded, but it definitely picked up around 7 PM.

Pomelo's menu is comprised of an Asian fusion dish from pretty much every single imaginable Asian cuisine, which doesn't make selection easy. Fortunately, my friend's dietary preferences narrowed us down to our two dishes that we shared.

We ordered the OTSU, which is a cold buckwheat noodle salad with cucumber, scallion, cilantro, and a spicy soy/ginger/sesame dressing, topped with pan sautéed tofu, $11 (http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/W_vy9nARtzE3rGnDkp6keA/l.jpg). This was my friend's preferred dish, as the tofu is filling and the cucumber is fresh and generous. The cold buckwheat noodles are topped with cilantro and sesame seeds, which is a pleasing combo, but I found the noodles to be too sesame oily.

My preferred dish was the LANZHOU, which is fresh egg noodles stir fried with ginger, scallion and garlic, with peppered ahi tuna, seared rare and topped with a miso-sesame drizzle, $16 (http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Y2EZW_j5BgZJYl5MqEdhlw/l.jpg). Egg noodles are so comforting, and that miso-sesame drizzle is addictive. The mellow, textured ahi tuna is a perfect complement to the tanginess of the sauce. And the best part? The fried lotus root slices. The best crunchy topping ever :)

The total was $17 per person, which was fitting for the enjoyable meal we had. I later found out that the waitress mixed up our receipts when billing our credit cards, but after contacting the people-in-charge, it seems like it's not a common practice :)

And yes, pomelos do grow on trees. The more you know.
author: Adele F.

description:
I went to dinner here last weekend. Oh so delicious and unique! I had never had Asian fusion cuisine quite like what is offered at Pomelo on Judah Street. 

It is just a little place yet the food and the service is five-star all the way. If you like Asian style food and an eclectic mix of flavors, then Pomelo is for you. 

Even the beverages have a fused flavor. I had the fresh ginger and lemongrass iced tea. Wow, that was yummy! I also had in addition to my entrée, a bowl of the most outstanding miso soup. It was of course a fusion of more than just the traditional miso, that to me was a meal in itself. Very delicious! 

It is important to note that patrons should ask about the dishes before ordering. I say this because as I read some of the yelp comments before going to Pamelo for the very first time, several people were not as pleased as they had anticipated. 

What I surmised about that was the type of fusion and the way the chef prepares it. For example, if you want the beef cooked a bit more, then just ask for it to be cooked a bit longer. And, if your palate does not like certain mixes of foods like shrimp and chicken, then try something else. I think, that might have been why there were some critical reviews on the list. 

Yet as for me, the food was outstanding! It is a very small place and seating is limited. Chairs are not that comfortable. Next time, I will order take out. It is a little pricey, but for the type of high quality and unique flavors, it is worth it. Also, service is outstanding. Definitely, a place I will visit again.
author: Jonathan F.

description:
Clean and focused....simple but complex.

The food was amazing. The place is small but that has nothing to do with the flavor of the food. The flavors are HUGE! 

It was so good I woke up the next morning with questions: when can I go back, why had I never been before, how is it that I have been passing this place for over a decade and never really noticed it? The place has an open kitchen so if you sit at the bar you see the whole cooking area and that makes for a more intimate setting. I like that the owner is cooking and that if you sit at the bar you can watch him at work. He has great flow and he makes it look so easy. 

We had the Manila, noodles with shrimp, chicken and Chinese sausage. The flavors blend together nicely, the aromas are intense and the serving size is perfect. We also had the Havana and it was amazing blend of traditional flavors (much better than any food you would find in Cuba).

The beer selection was simple but very well thought out. There are currently 4 imports, 3 domestic and 3 German artisan beers covering a wide range of style and flavor that pair with pretty much anything on the menu. 

One thing is very clear:  the Chef and staff  have been doing this for a while and it feels as if its effortless on their part, leaving you with a relaxed and comfortable environment.
author: Ben M.

description:
This was a dinner that started out lovely but ended up being very disappointing.

My husband and I came here for dinner tonight, our first time at Pomelo. Everything on the menu looked fantastic. We both enjoyed our food, which arrived piping hot.

After we finished eating, our server brought out the bill and began to clear our table. He bumped my husband's empty beer bottle against the glass light fixture hanging above our table, breaking the fixture.

Glass shattered and went everywhere - onto the table, onto the floor, inside my (not yet empty) wine glass, and onto my lap. The server apologized, asked if we were alright, and promptly whisked away the bill and came back with a wet towel to begin cleaning up the glass shards. He then left the table and came back with our bill.

My husband and I assumed that the bill would be revised to comp or discount some portion of the meal, since, you know, we now had shattered glass all over us. Nope. Not even for the wine that I could not finish (since my glass had, uh, glass in it).

I get it, accidents happen - I have broken my fair share of stuff. But the poor handling of this accident was very disappointing. We will not be returning, which is a shame since we live very close and really enjoyed the food. I hope the service is better for other visitors to Pomelo.
author: F O.

description:
This is my favorite Pomelo branch! Its nice and cozy, kind of a hole in the wall. 

I always love to sit right were the chefs cook, you get to see them cook and prepare your food. Monday nights are the best nights to be there, the cook always prepares his dishes quickly and flawlessly. They are very accommodating for changes in your dishes (don't be scared to ask to replace something or take something off your plate). Since I don't like fish, but I love noodles and garlic, I always get the Lanzhou with Tofu (instead of fish). I love the fresh taste of the noodles, (well cooked) tofu and the sauce on top!

The staff is very attentive and quick to help you. My favorite server is Eli, he has a good pulse of the restaurant, and is always on point! From ensuring my drink is refilled to always getting my order correct. Excellent customer service! 

Great place for dinner on a date or just a catch up with a close friend. I noticed it felt a little crowded when a party of 3-4 people came in once, I would recommend you only bring yourself or one other person with you.
author: Sophia G.

description:
I came here with two other friends. 

I was surprised how small this place is. This is NOT a place for LARGE parties. It's very tiny. 

Also, for some reason, I had no idea this place was asian fusion. 

So we ordered the Annot, Lanzhou, and Bormio. 

The annot was okay. The lamb was tender, but I wasn't overly impressed with it.

I like the other dishes better. I like the noodles and flavor in both the bormio and lanzhou. The lanzhou was pretty good, I like the noodles and the tuna.

I like the feel and atmosphere of the place. 

Overall, the food was okay. The service was attentive and nice.
author: Margaret L.

description:
Delicious. Great mix of world cuisine. 

Feel like something from Cuba?  They've got it. Want some Singaporean noodles?  They've got that too. How about some perfectly prepared fish with seasonal vegetables?  You guessed it, they've got it. 

It's tiny, so don't show up with a party of 8 and get upset if you're not seated together.
author: J. M.

description:
Stopped here after my doctors appointment UCSF. This was truly the best part of my day. 

The service was impeccable. The room was full and staffed with just one waiter, yet he was super attentive to everyone. 

I tried the Lanzhou. Fresh cut egg noodles topped with ahi tuna and miso-sesame noodles. I didn't think the combo would work but the tuna was so fresh, it really balanced the thicker noodles. I'll definitely be back to try the Thai dishes.
author: Susie R.

description:
We ordered to go and were pleased with how quickly they made our late night order (it was past 8:15pm when we called it in) and how pleasant the couple who runs the place were to us when we went to pick it up. 

Our order was a Havana plate with grill shrimp and a lanzhou with ahi tuna. Both orders were still warm when I got home and everything tasted fresh which we loved. The only down side to this place is parking while picking up an order, as there usually isn't any and I had to double park. Other than that, I would go back here and recommend it to vegetarian friends and meat eaters alike.
author: Carolina S.

description: I really enjoyed my experience here. I was welcomed immediately and warmly. Very little seating but the food is worth it. I ordered a moscow, which is a sausage penne dish that I would absolutely get again. It was a good portion size, had as much meat as there was pasta, had just enough sauce to coat the dish (not soupy), and had amazing flavor (good peppery kick).
author: Cynthia T.

description: My doctor at UCSF recommended this, so we eagerly came & were in heaven.  It is a small Asian fusion restaurant with an open ki9tchen; if the aroma does not lure you in, I do not know what will.  I had the langzhou with buttery garlic egg noodles, onions, cilantro, & rare seared ahi with ginger & miso topped with a crispy lotus root.  The fish is buttery & tender with a wonderful miso & crispy lotus root like a thin potato chip.  My mother loved d her Havana style fried rice with black beans, plantanes, squash, & ovacato salad.  For dessert, do not pass up the gelato; I had two scoupes with caramel & sea salt truffle & dark chocolate; both smooth, creamy, & the caramel with that slight saltiness.  Round it off with an Asahi & in my mother's case, a glass of red wine & you cannot go wrong.  We can hardly wait to come back & try more.  We were eyeing a seafood, chili, & onion pancake that we will order.  So, for wonderful Asian fusion food with friendly service in a casual neighborhood atmosphere at reasonable prices, Pomelo cannot be beat.  Keep up the good work guys.
author: Brian S.

description: The greatest little place to eat a seasonal meal ever. Prices are very low, ingredients are excellent, setting is small, but what does that matter when you have great food and great staff, chefs and owner? Hard not to order the Koh Samui - we have to force ourselves to get something else because it is delicious. But the tuscan bread salad, the pomelo salad (changed its fruit and cheese with the seasons), the polenta appetizer, the butternut squash bread salad (in season), the Manila, the Palermo, the special of risotto (right now, asparagus and bacon!). It is a GREAT place.  Wish they could get enough waitstaff to be open again on Sunday nights. A real loss that they are now closed on Sunday night. Thanks to Rolf and his crew for their excellent restaurant and keeping it going against SF odds.
author: m j l.

description:
Cute and warm ambiance with yummy fusion food. 

Ordered the baked polenta, korean pancake,  lang-Zhou noodle, weekend special (it's a baked fish dish, but I don't remember the name), and salted caramel ice cream. 

The dish that stood out to me the most was the baked polenta. It was really flavorful with a delicious mushroom sauce. 

All other dishes were well flavored as well. Great place for dinner if you are in the area. 

Service is decent, but not anything spectacular.
author: Becky W.

description: Menu was pretty all over the place and I felt that the food tasted "just okay". Service was impeccable and very friendly. The restaurant is very VERY small but I found it super adorable. The tofu appetizer had too much rice wine vinegar in it which borderline ruined the dish with too much tanginess for me. They were out of all the wines that I wanted, and I wasn't a fan of the California sauvignon blanc suggested to me. The tail-on shrimp tasted a bit fishy but was okay in my pancit bihon dish. I'd rather go to Lime Tree, honestly.....
author: Veda R.

description: Small neighborhood spot for Asian fusion. Belly up to the small bar and watch the cook make your order in front of your eyes. This is a small place, maybe 12 people total, but Sat night at 6:30 we got two seats at the bar.  We started with the pajeon and it was slightly undercooked, had shrimp, but was tasty. The lime congee chicken was super limey! The ahí tuna with garlic noodles was well seared, but the noodles were super oily. A bit expensive given the experience so most likely won't go back.
author: Jordan K.

description:
Love. This. Place. You would think that a place with a menu that includes items from all around the world can't hit them all on a high note, but Pomelo totally does. Walked in on a recent weekend night and sat at the bar in front of the open kitchen, which is always fun.

We started with the "hania" -- zucchini cakes served with mint-dill yogurt and cucumber -- which I loved. The zucchini was shredded so thin it was the consistency of crab cakes. Moist on the inside, crispy on the outside. Plus, the dip was heavenly.

For entrees, we went with the "nan": Thai-style rice congee with chicken, ginger, Chinese celery, cilantro and a poached egg, served with little bowls of thai chilies, sriracha and fried garlic to put on as toppings. It was comforting and incredibly flavorful yet light. We also tried the "manila" (Filipino-style stir-fried rice noodles tossed with sautéed prawns, chicken, Chinese sausage & vegetables, with scallion and lemon) which I absolutely loved. Unlike no other noodle dish I've ever had. The Chinese sausage was particularly good. I'm drooling just thinking about it.

Pomelo is the definition of neighborhood restaurant. It's tiny and cozy with good service. I only wish I lived closer; I'd be there all the time.
author: Elena K.

description: Good tuna.......everything else Twas salty like the main ingredient was salt doh.............................won't go there again because if that
author: Joe N.

description:
I'm really confused about how to rate Pomelo because I typically give out stars based on how often I would come back. 3 stars means I would go here if I were in the area, whereas 4 stars warrants about a half hour drive/wait.

I've only been to Pomelo twice in the past 1.5 years and I live a block away (granted, Pomelo is on the hill nowhere near the UCSF parking building's elevators that I take to get to Irving, and I hate walking up and down hills). Both times were takeout and the food was truly tasty. I am a fan of their noodle dishes the most, especially the Manila, which is a wondrously fragrant Filipino-style pancit sauteed with prawns, chicken, sweet Chinese sausage, and vegetables. Another favorite is the Lanzhou, with its thick hand-pulled egg noodles, stir-fried with loads of garlic and oil. The non-vegetarian option comes with grilled ahi, which I found to be not fresh; I'd recommend sticking with veggies and tofu for this dish. As for an appetizer, we always get the Ulsan (seafood Korean pancakes), which comes with embedded jalapenos and is tongue-numbingly spicy. The pancakes are perfectly eggy, with soft centers and crispy sides, but I do wish the seafood would be less fishy. I have a feeling that fish/seafood may not be Pomelo's forte.
. 
I'm not a fan of the prices here but I can understand paying this much for fusion cuisine. However, the main reason why I can't in good conscience give Pomelo 4 stars is because I find the food wayyyy too salty. As in I need to continually guzzle down water/tea for the next 4 hours after my meal kind of salty. My husband felt the same way and he's much less sensitive to salt than I am. Still, if you're in the area and craving some Asian noodles with a twist, Pomelo is a great choice if you don't mind the extra sodium!
author: Tiffany H.

description: perfect place for bringing your date!! the place is small but the ambiance is really nice and romantic!! the people working there are great.
author: Karlo G.

description:
This would be a four star review (very good) except for one thing I'll mention at the end. 

The food is excellent as reasonably priced. I had the curry chicken, which was sweet instead of spicy but still quite delicious. My wife had the beet salad, which we agreed didn't quite come together - good idea but incomplete. It may have been better with grilled chicken but I doubt it. The real star was the appetizer, a Korean pancake with shellfish, which was incredible. Highly recommended! 

The ambience was okay when we got there, but after some other parties showed up and the kitchen got busy, it was too loud for us to talk comfortably, so we just eavesdropped on the locals and enjoyed our food. Not bad but I liked it more when it was quiet. 

The penalty is because they charged for water. This is bad enough in itself, but they didn't mention it and charged quite a lot for it - we ended up paying nice dollars for our water, which is almost as much as an entree! This is a pretty serious issue in my opinion! But yours may vary.
author: Richard R.

description:
This place is pretty good! I love how there is a pomelo hanging in front it gives it a unique flair. CAme here on a Tuesday night and it wasn't extremely busy. My friend and I got a seat at the bar overlooking the chef cook our dishes. 

Tried: Havana, This polenta appetizer and  this noodle dish. All three were delicious! My favorite was probably the polenta appetizer it was grilled and tasted so good when it was drenched in the cream sauce with mushrooms its a winning combination. Then for Havana my friend thought the plantains were on the side but they were part of the fried rice. It was a unique fried rice but she enjoyed it for the most part except for the plantains. The noodle dish I had, had thick noodles with seared tuna. It was so flavorful and tasty I loved every bit of it! I want to come back here to try more dishes. 

Only downfall is the fact that it's a small restaurant and that parking is generally hard to find in this area. Otherwise the food is worth trying here
author: Stella J.

description: Love this place! My "go to" spot for lunch or dinner in the Inner Sunset. I always end up here when I can't decide what to eat. A little pricey, but never disappoints.
author: John V.

description: Great fusion food small restaurant with limited seating but we ordered take out and it was awesome
author: Monique E.

description: Really liked the place it was something different but super good. Seems healthy too. I didn't like how small it was but its low key so they have room. Very nice service as well. It's a good place to stop by if your in the area
author: Shawn B.

description: Great things come in small packages. Pomelo on Judah knows how to do fusion right. They blend flavors to bring authentic dishes to another level and leave you wanting more. Seating is limited but the staff is incredibly efficient without making you feel rushed; thus, my wait was less than 5 minutes. Most dishes I've had were based on various cultural palates of Asia. Each dish is very flavorful....very UMAMI (even more so than- dare I say it- umami burger). It is very clean. You also can watch the chef cook if you sit at the bar.
author: Anna D.

description: 3-3.5 Stars. Came here on a Friday and got seated right away at the counter. It is a very small place. We ordered the Aosta, Lanzhou, and the fish special that day. The aosta ($8.50) was decent to me, but my cousin seemed to enjoy it. The fish of the day ($18) was definitely nothing special, tasted pretty bland actually. The Lanzhou ($18) was the best thing here but it was a little bit on the saltier side. I would come back and get the Lanzhou and try other things on the menu.
author: Crystal C.

description: I eat here about twice a month, and each time is even better than the last! It seems impossible, but I am constantly surprised by the amazing freshness of the food and unique dishes. It is a tiny spot, but the flavors are huge. One of my favorite spots in the city!
author: Hannah W.

description:
Pomelo on Judah serves very interesting fusion food, where the name of the dish is related to where the food originates. The menu changes seasonally, so there's a bit of rotation and variety. The restaurant opens for both lunch and dinner (but only dinner on weekends), and when available, lunch options are about $1-2 cheaper than dinner options. Located on Judah St rather than Irving St (where most restaurants are located), Pomelo isn't very crowded. The restaurant is small, but has a casual-intimate feel to it.

Koh Samui --
A dish that truly feels like comfort food. It comes with spicy curry, chicken, beans, eggplants, squash, and mushrooms served with very fragrant jasmine rice. The entree was portioned fairly, with the bowl being half rice and half curry. The coconut milk-based curry was very thick, rich, creamy, and filling. The white chicken meat was a little tough and chewy, and the beans had an unappealing, rubbery texture. However, the squash and mushrooms were really good and the curry itself was overall very flavorful.

Lanzhou -- 
A popular item that was truly disappointing for me! This dish consists of two main ingredients: seared ahi tuna and egg noodles. The noodles were cooked with plenty of fresh garlic and ginger, but I could only taste the ginger. The tuna was coated with freshly ground black pepper and seared nicely, but there weren't a lot of pieces. The entree was topped with a miso sesame dressing, that I hardly tasted as well. This dish doesn't have many components, so I got tired of it very quickly. It was a forgettable dish and I wouldn't order it again.

The teeny tiny restaurant seats less than 20 people. There's counter seating in front of the open kitchen, counter seating by the window, and two regular tables along the wall. Service is friendly and food arrives at your table fairly quickly. Try to get the bar seating, so you can face the open-kitchen. Prices range $10-20 for dinner entrees, but portions are kind of small and not really worth the amount paid.
author: Priscilla W.

description: Little pricey, but every time we've eaten there the food has been excellent and fresh.
author: Stacey S.

description:
If you're in the sunset and even remotely in the mood for food with asian flavors, come here. Yes san tung has amazing chicken wings, and comparing the two is apples and oranges, but this place is just a cut above other restaurants in the area.

The Havana was delicious, as others have mentioned. A tad salty, but the flavors are truly unique and delicious. The chicken was very well cooked as well. 4 stars.

The koh Samui was what really made our experience. WOW. That is one delicious curry. Not very spicy at all (so if you're into that look elsewhere), which was perfect for me. 5 stars for my favorite curry anywhere.

I'll definitely be back to try the Manila and pretty much anything else on the menu.

Only downside, service was not as attentive as it should have been. I shouldn't have to ask multiple times for water, but the tiny place got packed so I'll give my first experience a free pass here. Don't let that deter you!
author: Graham H.

description:
This is my #1 secret hole in the wall in my neighborhood in SF. I only take special loved ones bec it is so dear to me. The staff is few, but they do an amazing job, they are always so sweet. I like how some days they switch off who cooks and who waits tables. The bar is fun bec you can watch while they make your food. 
It is extremely small and intimate, but that is the magic of Pomelo. I can not say enough about this place's ambiance and quality of food. The Havana plate and garlic noodles with Ahi tuna are my two favs, but the taco appetizers and bac choy  are yummy too. I appreciate the fusion and very California farm to table feel it has.
author: Lee C.

description: Tiny place with barely any seating! They only have three tables (but if you're a party of four or more, forget it....). We got seated right next to the entrance (and I mean 6 inches from the front door). As for the food, I ordered the Ulsan (Korean pejeon pancake) and it wasn't even crispy! It came out all soggy. Really sad for a place that is pretty popular in their Noe Valley location.
author: Jessica L.

description: My two favorite dishes here are the Lanzhou (grilled Ahi Tuna with egg noodles) and the Havana (Cuban fried rice with steak (chicken is also available)). Both are rich in flavor and very tasty. I've also tried the Koh Samui (curry chicken) which was ok and Manila (pancit - Filipino rice noodles) which was too salty and a bit underwhelming. The restaurant is really small, so you can't come with a group. It's best to have 2 in your party or 4 max.
author: Ali F.

description:
Wow. The freshest, best quality meal I've had in a long time. Tender tender chicken and plantains with avocado. Presentation and plating was top notch and service was superb as well even with one waiter.
GO NOW
author: Charlie W.

description:
Ok - I rarely leave reviews but I felt compelled as most others do, because in my case, I was thoroughly embarrassed after eating lunch here.

I went to Pomelo with my team (3 in total) for lunch one afternoon, it was my idea because of the rave reviews I had hear about the food. 

As many others have mentioned, this place is TINY - I am actually quiet impressed with what they accomplish in such a small space! 

We all wanted the Havana, but someone changed their mind last minute. The food was so amazing. The amount of flavor they were able to pack in the dish was so thoughtful and truly left my mouth begging for more. We all cleaned our plates. However, the service (again it is a TINY place) really killed the mood.

Two of us ordered Iced Tea, and we got some refills but it did take a while. The other just had water. She had to ask for a refill and even then it took 5 minutes to get her refill. I know, I know; California is in a drought, but you should be able to get more water after you ask for it right? Then the bill came, here is where I got embarrassed. We each threw our credit cards in so happy and carefree and then he looked at us like we were complete idiots and was like, "It is a two credit card maximum" dropped the payment sleeve and walked away. Oops! We didn't know that. None of us had cash. We apologized to him and asked if he could split the check 3 ways because we didn't know about the credit card rule. He was obviously annoyed and gave us a lecture my grandmother would be proud of, and returned with 3 separate checks.

Great! Now we all throw in our cards with the correct check and go back to chatting... WRONG. He comes over, visibly annoyed and states, "Didn't I already tell you there is a two credit card maximum. What don't you understand about maximum?" We all looked at each other puzzled, and apologized, "Sorry, none of us have cash". I am cowering in the corner; why did I convince these people to come here for lunch. One of my coworkers is ready to leave and starting to complain and wants to refuse a tip (we all tipped in the end). He rolls his eyes and again gives us the lecture that this is against the policy but he will make the exception for us but next time... Sorry buddy, there definitely will not be a next time! Ok well maybe but only because the food was SO stinkin' amazing. If I ever go back, I will definitely order to go.

But seriously, if you don't mind tight cramped quarters, and don't have more than 3 credit cards, go here. It is amazingly delicious.
author: Carissa B.

description:
It's been a while since my last visit to Pomelo, but the place remains just as charming.

The space is very intimate so even if you're just a party of two - you may find yourself waiting a couple of minutes for a seat. That being said - Pomelo continues to remain under the radar  - so getting a walk-in dinner should never be a big problem.

Their menu is constantly being updated - according to what is in season - and so while the general theme of their dinner menu is largely comprised of quinoa, buckwheat, and coconut themed dishes - the ingredients and seasoning of them - rotates fairly regularly.

We ordered the brussels sprouts as an appetizer. They were cooked to pure excellence. They were flavorful and cooked with apple and bacon. I don't really eat bacon, so I picked out the bits, but I loved how beautifully all of the flavors melded together. 

For the main dish I got the fish dish, which came with two quinoa cakes, with ancho chiles, served with roasted sweet pepper coulis, tangy onions, avocado and yam chips. The avocado paired nicely with the tangy sauce and the quinoa cakes complimented the fish with a refreshing new texture. I finished. Every. Bite. On. My. Plate.

My favorite aspect of this place is the size and the acoustics. We had no problem talking throughout the evening even though there were a handful of others also conversing throughout the small space. Pomelo with it's soft lighting, darling size, and delicious menu is truly an Inner Sunset gem of a spot.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description: This place is freaking good. It's tiny as heck, and there's only one waiter and one cook, but man, the food is delicious. I recommend the polenta - it's pan-fried to crispy perfection on the outside (delicate on the inside) and adorned with a creamy, semi-citrus sauce and adorned with ragu mushrooms, all of which are cooked perfectly. . You will have to wait a while to get dinner, but it's entirely worth it for a fairly cheap, fancy meal.
author: Danny C.

description: So good a reasonably priced too! Very different if you're looking for a fresh spin on traditional Thai or Mexican food. Not heavy, but a well blended culinary delight :)
author: Garrett B.

description: I work at UCSF up the street. Came on my lunch to try something new. Little nice cozy spot. I was nervous at first but come to find out I made I great decision. I ordered the Manila! Delicious! Mos Def will recommend!  Great cooks, great service!
author: Valerie S.

description: fantastic vibe. hard to explain why.   I love this huge kitchen and the chef working in it. only limited numbers of seatings.  makes it special and communal.
author: Shuting Z.

description:
It's a really small location down the block from UCSF, Parnassus campus. The food is fusion asian american. I dont usually like asian fusion but this place did iy well. I ordered the pancit and it came put well. A good sized portion especially for lunch. I couldnt stop eatting. I want to come back to try their other dishes.

The only think I didn't like was that I was squeezed so tight next to the neighboring table. That's a minor issue though.
author: Christina L.

description:
Oh YUM, so goooood!  I went with 3 other gf and boy did we get lucky finding 4 seats at the counter.  After that, everyone else that came in were told there would be a 20 min wait.  It's super small but cozy and most importantly, they have hooks under the counter so you don't have to hang your purse on your chair.

We got 2 orders of the beef stew, the seared ahi and noodles plate and the ayacucho, did I spell that right?  Oh well...  I loved the ayacucho, the quinoa cakes were perfect.  Although the plates are big we all managed to finish everything. 

I don't consider it Asian fusion.  They have Asian dishes and they have latin dishes but unless you put a bite of each in your mouth there is no fusion.  Very attentive staff and super friendly.  Can't wait to go back!
author: Rosalind S.

description: Had the Havana and it was amazing!!! I love how cozy the place was. The staff was extremely nice and attentive. The presentation of the food is mind blowing. The intense medley of flavor in each bite of my dish made me want to order everything on the menu. The place also has good wine. I tried the  Cava I wish I had order it by the btl 23$. But at 7$ a glass it wasn't to pricey. Every time I have a meeting at Parnassus I will check out this place
author: Andre F.

description:
i'm trying to clean up my inboxes and draft notes for the new year. Part of a type of cleansing. So, take this review with a grain of salt, as it's not going to be based on anything recent.

Notes from my original unfinished review when I last went here about a year ago:
Pomelo primarily serves dishes from different asian countries. 
Lots of variety. I believe I had the Pancit. If you don't know Asian food, then it might be hard to know what to order. But hey, if you're up for a change and aren't too picky, this would be great.

All in all, the place was fine. Lighting was being weird, it would turn on and off depending on if the person closed the door.
The place was small place a few 2 person tables or a bar, so no big groups.
Staff is very friendly.
Prices are average.

UPDATE: I must not have been super thrilled only because I go past this place a lot and haven't been back since the first time. I'm leaving my review at four stars, since that's what I originally gave it.
author: Clara T.

description:
This place is small...very small. If you go, go with no more than 3 people max. I would recommend going only with on other person. Even though you can fit more, the chances of having it empty enough on a weekend is almost nil so plan accordingly. Now if you go on a weekday you'll be fine.

Since this place is small, it's also quaint and very San Franciscan like (similar to any big city urban dining). But let's get to the crux.

The food is awesome. I was worried that there may be a little hype on this review board but honestly what I ordered was definitely worth the reasonable price.

Started with a pajeon pancake which was cooked well and light and ended up getting the Havana (skirt steak). I rarely exaggerate so when I say that this dish was probably one of the best tasting dishes I've had all month, I'm for real.

We also ate the koh samui which was not as impressive. Don't get me wrong - it was a good, but it wasn't "hell yeah this is good" like the havana. Next time I come, I probably wouldn't get it.

I'd definitely recommend this place, although since it's small, the options are less open for large groups. I heard the Noe Valley place is bigger.
author: Julia P.

description:
Pomelo has an interesting and pretty compelling menu. Definitely a fusion place, it mixes influences from all around the world - but competently, and it avoids the trap of a menu that blends everything in all the dishes so that it all tastes the same.

We started with ulsan (pa-jeon - korean scallion pancakes with scallops, prawns,
red and green chilies, egg and spicy dipping sauce). It was on the edge of being undercooked but was still pretty good.

Hat Yai - garlic egg noodles and panang curry with duck legs, thai eggplants, coconut milk, kaffir lime leaves - was a little disappointing. It lacked both subtlety of flavor and oomph, even though we really wanted to like it.

Reasonably priced and worth another shot. We consider 2 stars to be average so at 3 stars, we still would recommend the place and look forward to trying some other things.
author: Amy D.

description: Cozy little place that can fit about 12 customers at most. The food was delicious! I ordered their weekend special which was a paella dish. Loved it! They did not scrimp on the seafood! The owner (?) checked up on tables often and really made us feel welcome. I would def come back here again next time I'm in the area.
author: Jane C.

description:
I've concluded that Pomelo is the... dun dun dun  ***Perfect First Date Restaurant****, officially named by yours truly. 

No, I did not come to this conclusion because I went on a first date at Pomelo.  Not even close.  Unless you consider two girls with backpacks catching up over an early dinner after a long day at school a date. Eh, hm. 

So how did I come to this conclusion?

After walking past Pomelo pretty much every day on my way home, I've probably witnessed many first dates.  The windows are big, people sit close to the window and are very visible, available to be observed by me.  Dim restuarant, soft music, candle lit... that's where magic happens. 

Price:
Perfect price range for a first date. Not too cheap, not too expensive. Dishes range ~$15 each.

Setting:
Candles on the tables. Intimate tables, but not too crowded.  Small restaurant. Music is playing, but never too loud so that you cannot hear your dinner mate.

Drinks:
Wine available. Classy.

Food:
Unique. Different. Interesting. Great way to fuel conversation.  Ex: "ooh Sri Lanka Curry?  Oh, I once knew a friend who from there who..."  or "wow this places serves japanese dishes too!  You mentioned you speak a little bit of japanese right?"  On a first date, the food has to be pretty good and Pomelo definitely makes the cut. Maybe not amazing, but pretty good. You don't want to be stuffing your face on your first date anyways.

Service:
Great service. Friendly staff.  They don't rush you here.  It's awkward when you're on a first date and the waiter is super rude, yuck. How do you respond to that?

All you guys out there, hope you're reading this!  

My last tip to you: Make a reservation. The restaurant is small so make sure you either make a reservation or come early when they open at 5:30pm.
author: Gloria C.

description: Food was great but service was TERRIBLE. Our waiter seemed to be in such a bad mood, was sarcastic in a rude (not funny) way, and was just generally unhelpful and scowled the whole time. It seemed like they were granting us a great honor by letting us eat there...not sure if I'll be back because the food was so yummy but being treated like that sucked.
author: Lina L.

description:
Pomelo is a Thai-Asian fusion food restaurant, mostly with noodle dishes. Was recommended to go by one of my co-workers and very glad I did! Overall, great. I ordered one dish for lunch: the Nan. It's a thai style rice congee (rice soup/porridge) with chicken, ginger, chinese celery, cilantro and poached farm egg, served with side-toppings of thai chilies, siracha, lime and fried garlic. By appearance, it almost looked bland, but when I took the first sip, I was hit by it's delicious intense flavor. Based on other reviews that I read prior to going, it seems that the seasoning or "over-seasoning" was off-putting to some, but I thought it was perfect. It would really be a great soup/porridge for a cold/cloudy day, but was still great on the relatively warm sunny day.

The setting/atmosphere has it's plusses and minuses. 
Minuses:
- incredibly small; only 3 tables and 2 bars. maybe 10 people capacity.
Pluses:
- clean, neat ambiance, good decor/colors
- can watch the chef prepare the food at the bar/counter since it overlooks the small kitchen
- can sit at the counter facing the window

may come back and revise to 5 stars once I try more of their dishes if equally as good. I have a hard time giving 5 stars based on one dish. But will definitely be going back for more!
author: Kirellos Z.

description:
