This is my favorite restaurant in my neighborhood. It's casual but good for a date, cozy, and the food is outstanding. I like how the menu changes to reflect the seasons, but they keep a few dishes on the menu permanently. My favorites include the baked polenta with a creamy mushroom ragu, fish tacos, cuban fried rice with plantains, and they always have a really good salad. I'm really sad that the african peanut butter stew was taken off the menu, but anything that's delicious and is taken off the menu, is usually replaced with something equally delicious. 

Service is friendly and has always been attentive, the place is small (I actually like that, keeps it from becoming over-crowded), off the beaten path, and I like that you can sit at the counter and watch the chefs do their thing.

I secretly hope this place stays kind of a secret.
author: Catface G.

description: Really amazing food, just wish their was more seating!  I think they are popular enough to move to a bigger location.  You can always call in for takeout!
author: Mackenzie B.

description:
I can't believe I have passed by this place for the past near decade and never tried it! That finally changed...

Tiny interior, literally 17 seats, and that includes the counter that overlooks the cook, but other than that, it's a terrific place. Food is good and fresh, simple but far from underwhelming, staff consists of one server/host, and a few cooks. Great place for a casual, delicious lunch or dinner.
author: Lana L.

description:
This review is for their dinner.

My GF and I came here relatively early, around 6 p.m. on a weekday night.  Seats were available at this small restaurant so we were seated immediately and ordered our dishes.  For our entrees, we ordered the Manilla (pancit type dish) and Quezon chicken.  

First the Quezon chicken, it came in a large bowl with chunks of chicken and white rice, along with 2 tiny pieces of shallot and many pieces of large garlic cloves.  After taking a bite, my first impression was I could make this myself!!! Nothing special about this dish and absolutely no wow factor.  This dish doesn't seem to be restaurant quality.

The Manilla:  the dish came with vegetables, Chinese sausage, and pieces of Chicken.  My GF noted that it was too salty, and after taking a bite I had to agree.  The dish tasted pedestrian to me.  Very forgettable.

Overall I don't know what the hype is about Pomelo.  I'm guessing it must be from the lunch and breakfast items, because the dishes we picked for dinner were highly disappointing.
author: Ben S.

description:
A restaurant conveniently a block away from UCSF, I went here for a lunch break. It is a cute little restaurant with limited seating, so don't try going here with you momma and her 5 friends. A large pomelo model marks this restaurant's place, so it's hard to miss. 

There's a few tables and bar seating so you can watch the chef at work, and window seating as well. Simple wood decor and the yellow paint on the walls give it a homey, cozy feel. I was greeted by the owner who was able to seat me pretty quickly, even during the lunch time craze. 

Their food is all different Asian dishes but with a mild twist. I was surprised to see some Filipino dishes-usually not found in this area, which is great for me. I decided to go with the Thai curry- I've been on a curry trip for the past month or so.

The food came out in a pretty large bowl- with your choice of brown or white rice. Usually, traditional curry is deep in color depending on if you get yellow or red or green- this was a white- with hints of red and yellow. The dish comes with chicken, beans, bamboo shoots, other veggies, lime leaves, and eggplant. I and not too fond of eggplant so they were able to take it out of the curry for me. Thank you!

It had the sweet, creamy, spiciness that you are used to in Thai curry, but there was strong citrus flavor from the lime leaves that I wasn't used to. Maybe that's the fusion part? Regardless, still a good plate to have. 

The service was fast and really polite! Definitely gave the place a more personal touch.

I would go here again. I'm curious to try the Filipino dishes :)
author: Kristine T.

description: I almost never write Yelp reviews, but this place is so wonderful! The owners are friendly and so kind. The food is absolutely amazing. I have been living in the Inner Sunset for 2 years and just now found this spot. Such a hidden gem. Reasonably priced and cute. Can't wait to go back!
author: Katya L.

description: This is my second time coming here for dinner and it's been awhile since the last time. I remember the food being good and wanted to take the hubby here. We ordered the Havana and the Lanzhou dish. Both dishes were flavorful but a bit salty for me. For what it is, I feel like the price point is too high. We only ordered two dishes and a tea and walked out spending $50! Don't think I can see myself coming back.
author: Connie C.

description: Cute atmosphere and creative menu. Panzanella salad, Sante Fe, Ahi Tuni with garlic noodles, and jackfruit coconut cake with passion fruit sorbet was friggin amazing! Definitely a new fave.
author: Victoria L.

description:
I really wanted to love you.  I did.  
After looking through photos on yelp (because who has time to really read the reviews?) I know I had to come here because of the Lanzhou - Seared ahi on top of garlic noodles.  Heaven right?  Not so much the taste :(  They drenched it in the miso-sesame sauce that just made it a mushy disappointing mess.  So much potential.  Sigh.  Great service and cute ambiance though.  However this place is TINY.  Maybe fits 10 people in the restaurant max?
author: Tammy N.

description: The flavors were just right on our dishes and parking was a breeze. My husband had the Havana and it was definitely the star of the meal. We will be returning!
author: Kristin J.

description: We had a lovely lunch experience here today. The host went out of his way to accommodate us and moved a table so we could comfortably sit there with two wheelchairs. I had the German goulash with spaetzle which was hearty and tasty and my partner ate the Korean pancake which accomplished the diffcult feat of tasting both healthy and scrumptous. We'll definitely be back.
author: Ursula S.

description: Love love love this place. We find ourselves here at least twice a week and haven't found a bad item on the menu. Soups are A+, fish of the day meals are very solid, and the Havana is hands down the best rice dish I have ever had. Bless yourself with this high quality ingredients restaurant and you won't be let down.
author: Kyle S.

description: This place is a local favorite with great service and world class food (in general, all menu entrees and appetizers are named after cities).the food is fantastic combining fusion and flare.
author: Hildur J.

description:
Pomelo is delicious! I'm usually not a fan of asian fusion food . The phrase usually leaves me with a sad impression, like Asian food that's not good enough to be authentic. So I was a bit apprehensive about trying Pomelo, even though the sign in sort of cute and I have a bias towards one-word restaurants. Anyway, I had always passed by on the N so I decided to give it a try one day with some friends.

First of all, the restaurant is super tiny, and I'm sure it's packed during weekday lunches. I came for early dinner on a random weekday so the crowd was pretty light until the middle of the night, when more people started coming in.

I love sisig, so I was a bit apprehensive trying the tofu sisig appetizer. I wasn't disappointed at all though. The dish is a twist on the tradtional sisig pork, but the flavorings are spot on and the end result is very very appetizing.

The Muravera is absolutely delicious! It's a whole cornucopia of items: toasted sardinian couscous with fennel, spring onion, fava beans, english peas, pancetta, saffron and fresh herbs. There's a lot going on but it works together and the result is wonderful deliciousness

Service is excellent, very attentive, but not in your face. Our server totally knew when we needed something and his timing was perfect. Would definitely come back again when I'm in the area!
author: Viola L.

description:
Such a cute little resto in the inner sunset. It literally felt like we were in someone's house, very cozy and intimate. 

So many wonderful flavors in each bite!

We started with the garlic bok choy, spicy peanut tofu, and fig goat cheese bruschetta. One of the diners in our group is a vegetarian so we followed suit and I was surprised by how delicious and filling the tofu was. Definitely a favorite. 

For our entrees we had the nan - basically thai congee. It was a nice modern bowl of comfort. A friend had the Havana - rice plantains avo tofu beans... Yum!!!! And the vegetarian got the cold buckwheat salad. She mostly ate everything but the cold noodles but she insisted it was just bc she was so full. 

Definitely will go back!
author: Katie P.

description:
Despite living in the neighborhood for the past six years, I hadn't tried this place until last night. I cannot emphasize how deeply I regret having waited that long. The food was some of the best I've had in San Francisco, the service was perfect, and the ambiance is intimate and elegant. This spot is absolutely perfect for a date.

When you come, do yourself a favor and order the polenta appetizer. It has polenta cakes that feature a rich dairy flavor to them, and are topped with a mushroom ragu that somehow introduces a maple flavor while being firmly in the savory category. The dish got a lot of going on in terms of its flavor profile, but the end result is something that both my date and I agreed was breathtakingly good, like something you take a bite of, your eyes lose focus, and you think that perhaps, just maybe, this is the sort of thing that has been missing from your life. Ludicrous, but true.
author: Brent R.

description:
The cutest little establishment in the Sunset.  I, for one, love counter-sitting; At Pomelo you can either watch out the window at the passers-by or watch the kitchen's goingson.  It is adorable and cozy and warm.  Great place for a date as you get to snuggle into your honey

THE FOOD! The Havana was the highlight.  Such a unique flavor of really really deeply carmelized onions and citrus and chilies.  Very true to typical cuban eating.  

The bread toasted on the grill is a delicious start

we had a fantastic mango and goat cheese salad.

We also had the Goulasch which was good and hearty but not so complex and fascinating that I'd get it when I go back.  

Very reasonably priced.  I can't wait to go back and try the various curries
author: Meg M.

description: I ordered the Pomelo salad and the Havana. They were both really delicious. I really loved the buttermilk mustard vinaigrette that came with the salad - went perfectly with the grilled peaches. I ordered the havana with chicken - it was perfectly seasoned, and overall delicious. The chicken was tender (which a lot of places mess up), the rice was perfectly seasoned and so flavorful, and I really enjoyed the cuban guacamole on the side - which was chunkier and more citrusy than regular guacamole. I also asked for hot sauce on the side - and their hot sauce was some of the best hot sauce I've ever tasted. Great neighbourhood joint, I highly recommend it!
author: Sandra R.

description:
I walk by this place all the time and finally had a chance to try it out.  I feel like it's a pleasant restaurant at a strange location since it's basically 1 of the 3 places to eat on the corner of 6th and Judah. However despite that, Pomelo is a tiny treasure to the area.  The restaurant is very small with an open kitchen and will only fit about 18 customers.  

The menu is a mixture of ethnic food so I can't really pin point the type of food they serve.  My boyfriend had a fusion Thai curry dish and I had the Havana, which was a Cuban pineapple fried rice with steak and an avocado salad.  It was very yummy.  The menu changes every so often so expect to get something different if you go once in awhile.  

I also saw German beer on the menu but didn't get to try it that day.  I was eyeing the couple next to me having it though.  I should definitely get it next time.

Overall I enjoyed this place.  It's small but cute.
author: Shirley T.

description: We came here on a Thursday nite. Place was packed. Its a nice and cozy place. Food will not disappoint. For appetizers we ordered Aosta and the  For our main course we had *the Manila *Havana *Kandy *Koh Samui and a *Grilled skirt steak with a side of their gilroy. EVERYTHING was DELICIOUS!! We tried each others dishes of course. There was nothing left on our plates.
author: K P.

description: Had dinner here last night with a friend--and it was super-duper delicious. I've been a little burned-out on the fancy-pants fusion scene, but this place blew me away. I had the nan--congee soup, lemoney with huge, chunks of moist chicken--best I've had in decades. The atmosphere was mellow, relaxed, intimate. I can't wait to go back to try all of the other eclectic items on their menu.
author: Lisa K.

description: Restaurant description looked very tempting but at 8:30 on a weeknight we circled around looking for parking for a while and then went elsewhere.  Sorry.
author: Aliza P.

description:
I love it. Husband had the soba noodles, I had the pappardelle and we LOVED every bite. 

Also, we got a delicious side of garlicky bok choy which was weirdly mind blowing for such a simple side dish. 

Can't wait to go back.
author: Osh J.

description: Got "Padang" slow cooked beef food from Indonesia served with rice taste sooo delicious! I will be back tomorrow to try other things. Late lunch today!
author: Ty N.

description: Was out of town walked pass this place and gave it a shot....great tasting meal will be back!
author: Brian M.

description:
Very surprised at all the rave, 4 star reviews. Honestly, I wasn't impressed with this place at all. D:

Came in with pretty high expectations. I do like Asian fusion. I think its a great way to either a) bring out some really cool aspects of Asian cuisine by using Western food/techniques, or b) bring out some really cool aspects of Western cuisine by using Asian food/techniques. Asian and Western food can compliment each other very well. 

Unfortunately, I did not feel this way about Pomelo. :(

We had an appetizer, the "masantol". The dish was REALLY REALLY flavorful and quite salty.  And super lemoney. I think it would have been better over rice or something. It was just a little too much. 

I got the Manila, and my partner got the Langzhou. The Manila was a poor choice on my part- I don't like thin noodles, and these noodles were the vermicelli thin tiny little noodles. Ick, it felt like worms going down my throat @_@;; but noodle thickness is just a weird personal preference of mine. As far as flavor was concerned, it wasn't bad. I liked the Chinese sausage (Chinese sausage ROCKS). But the chicken had a flavor that really sits in your mouth... I didn't like it :(

My partner found out that he didn't like seared ahi tuna, so we swapped plates. I liked his noodles (they were pretty garlickey and tasty), but they weren't anything out of the ordinary. 

When I go out to eat Asian fusion, I expect the combination to be something new, innovative, and most importantly, the East and West have to compliment each other. .When I ate these noodles, I felt like it was just a fancy Western take on Eastern cuisine without actually understanding what goes into making Asian noodles. 

Prices weren't worth it. The atmosphere was nice and cozy, though. And the service was good :)
author: Jade R.

description: What a great established hole in the wall. There was a dish for every palate, great lunch or weekday dinner spot. This is a tiny establishment with janky wiring and space heaters on opposite corners b/c it gets drafty. I look forward to going there again and trying more of the dishes.
author: Adele A.

description:
I live in inner sunset and wanted this place to be good! It just wasn't, but then again, I'm not a huge fan of asian fusion. I like more traditional asian food personally.
My tuna was likely frozen and the sauce on the noodles tasted like it was generic teriyaki from a bottle. My bf's dish was the same- tasted like bottled sauces. I like the idea of the eclectic/fusion menu. Maybe we just went on a bad day.
author: Caroline D.

description: After seeing the reviews on yelp, we decided to check this place out. The service was excellent. The food presentation was great. Thai food is one food that I love cooking since I grew up eating it, and this place disappointed me. I ordered the nan, and it was way too salty. I forced myself to eat it because I didn't want it to go to waste. The other person ordered the Havana and there was way too much ginger that it took away from the food. We ordered the tacos and those were delicious. Should have just stuck with the tacos. The place needs to chill on it's flavors.
author: Saengthong D.

description:
Kandy curry was a strange mixture of bland islands floating in inedible spiciness.  Portions overall were pretty teeny tiny.  And service was unfortunate.  Our waiter was snide and condescending - not a total surprise in SF but unfortunate.
On the plus side, decor is super cute and atmosphere is very cozy.  Prices are incredibly reasonable.  Forestville appetizer was to die for - so original and delicious.  Merano main dish was also scrumptious.
author: Marcia G.

description:
Such a wonderful surprise to find this place in this neighborhood! 

Food - delicious! I can't wait to come back to try more on the menu. I had the ahi tuna dish and still dream about the flavors. Nice wine selection. There's a little bit for everyone, a very global menu.

Atmosphere - it's small (really small) around 3 tables + bar seating small. but that also creates an intimate atmosphere. Seating is around the kitchen and the smells are intoxicating.  I overheard someone next to us say "you can almost fill up on the smell from the kitchen" and no joke, it's delicious!

Service - Fantastic! Since it's small, there's just one server/host/everything but chef, who was wonderfully friendly and kind. It made the experience all the better. Food also arrived really quickly, which kept everyone happy.
author: AlwaysHonest R.

description:
"Asian Fusion" might technically be correct, but it doesn't really do Pomelo justice.  There are a lot of really good options on this diverse menu.  They had at least one item from each of: Cuban, Mexican, Italian, Indonesian, and Japanese, off the top of my head.  

I had the "Solo" Indonesian chicken noodle soup, and it was great, and $10.  I'll be back.

I've also been to the Pomelo in Noe Valley and really enjoyed that one too.

The space is quite small though, not ideal for big groups or young children I imagine.
author: Eric H.

description:
It is a really cute place. Like how it's small, cozy.

Menu is imaginative and covers lots of ground. Where else can you get a cuban inspired entre with one called "Lanzhou?" Waiter was patient with my demanding crew.

Food was tasty--my tuna was good quality and cooked right. The noodles were good.

Very much appreciated the space heaters they hauled in--we were happy.
author: Paul K.

description:
Seriously, BEST FOOD EVER.  Now, I want to make clear that I'm only referring to the Pomelo on Judah because for some reason, I've never enjoyed the food at their Noe location as much.. Not sure why, maybe because its bigger? Who knows?  Anyway, the Lanzhou, Havanah, Gilroy and Masantol are the greatest dishes I've ever eaten. I am a creature of habit and have only ever ordered a combination of these four items, but I've never been disappointed, so why change a good thing? 

I always try to sit at the counter so I can watch how they make the food but for some strange reason, my food never turns out as good..weird. As others have stated, this place is very small and gets crowded on the weekends but it is worth the wait for sure.
author: Swaicha C.

description:
ASIAN FUSION? We normally try to avoid asian fusion places because they aren't typically good. This place was definitely good, though. 

The inside = small. It was super busy and I feel like we were forgotten once in a while. The host/waiter person would attend to someone else more than us - was it because we didn't order wine or beer? Whatever. 

We started with the iced lemongrass ginger tea and honey lemonade. I really enjoyed my honey lemonade - it was equal parts of honey and lemon flavors. The lemongrass ginger tea was too gingery for me. I thought it was just ginger, but my boyfriend enjoyed it. 

Our app was the Cabo San Lucas - which was "two handmade soft corn tacos with grilled pacific snapper, shredded cabbage, mango salsa, chipotle aïoli and house pickled jalapeños". The pickled jalapenos were delicious. I enjoyed the mango salsa as well. There was way too much shredded cabbage though. I don't remember the aioli, but maybe it was there. It was pretty good. 

I ordered the havana which was "cuban style fried rice with black beans, plantains, chipotles, ginger and cilantro, served with grilled skirt steak,
sautéed onions and cuban avocado salad". The plantains were delicious in the rice. It was such a nice surprise. The grilled skirt steak was kind of...too much. The avocado salad was good, well, because I love avocado. 

My boyfriend ordered the ayacucho which was "grilled fish of the day and quinoa cakes with ancho chili, served with roasted sweet pepper coulis, tangy onions, avocado and yam chips". The fish of the day was salmon and the quinoa cake was SO GOOD. I enjoyed the cakes the most.

Overall, loved the dinner that I had. Definitely will be back, not necessarily to eat there, but it was great.
author: Nina Y.

description: The food selection was exceptional and the food was amazing. It is a small little place but perfect for a lunch date!
author: Issy G.

description: Very salty. Especially the soup. Has the potential to be really great. The overly salted food is a bummer.
author: Kerry W.

description: For Asian Fusion food, I think they have the asian part down.  I don't know what the "fusion" criteria is about though.  I read reviews that this place is small, but literally it's shack small.  I'm not sure if the owner didn't like us because we wore jeans, because we have dark hair, or we look like we're from the ghettos and not UCSF therefore bad tippers, but even after ordering 3 mains and an appetizer for 3 small eaters, we still felt like you had to be of some special caliber to eat here.  We got the garlic noodles with ahi tuna, the curry, and the rice with steak.  We also got less steak compared to the man at the counter.  We saw 3 cars park right in front of the restaurant, the passengers walked in, saw there was no space, and walked out.  Perhaps it's not worth the wait.  This place leaves me with an "I don't know."
author: Janet T.

description: First impression when I walk in is this place is small,  which means it has an intimate atmosphere to talk with your dinner party, which I liked. The food was delicious (I had langzhou), which was very bold and my dining buddy had the Havana,  which was also very good. I would definitely come back for another meal in the near future.
author: Dang T.

description:
This place is just down the street from our house so we go there quite a bit.  

They have never failed us.  You can't go wrong with the Havana or the Koh Samui.  Friday and Sat night gets crowded because the place seats 14 but it's worth the wait.  

Also, if you're socially challenged I'd highly recommend this as a place to go if you're on a date.  Sit at the bar and watch the chef cook your food - it'll give you ample things to talk about.
author: Chris K.

description: Quite disappointed to be honest.  We had the great brunch menu on Church Street, and was looking forward to the dinner menu.  After much very good to great reviews, we finally decided to give it a go.  Unfortunately dinner did not live up to the reviews.  We had the Masantol which we thought was a tad too salty.  Also thought I read "sizzling" somewhere, but that was a definite no.  The Ulsan (Korean pancake) was sorta mushy.  My wife had the Havana which everyone was raving about.  Hmmm...I missed something there for sure.  I had the grilled fish Achuya which I thought was the best dish out of our order.  Nothing great to be honest, but good.  I think we'll stick to the brunch menu instead.
author: Joel M.

description:
Can't believe I have never been to this place before tonight!  I will definitely be back soon.  Stated with the Pomelo salad (greens, persimmon, pomegranate, manchego)  and brussel sports (with apple! and bacon) shared with the table.  My main was the Manila (stir fried rice noodles with prawns, chicken, sausage, and veg), and others had the cuban style fried rice, coconut curry, and rice congee.  

All were delicious and the service was great.  Can't wait to go back!
author: Kendra D.

description:
Been here several times for lunch and went again today. Doesn't seem to disappoint.

Ordered my usual app: Polenta cakes with mushrooms (Party in your mouth every time). Then had their fish of the day (mahi mahi) grilled perfectly with two tasty quinoa cakes surrounded by some sauteed onion and avocado. Wanted to lick my plate.

I can't remember other items I've ordered as the menu has recently changed a bit but everything coming out of the kitchen looked very tasty. 

Place is small, quaint. Mostly counter seating with the exception of 3-4 two-top tables. Kind of hidden there on Judah but worth discovering.

Look to spend $10-15 per entree.
author: Jasmyn M.

description:
The boo and I decided to grab a nice dinner at Pomelo before venturing off to a friend's house in the Inner Sunset. When we arrived on Friday night, around 8:30 p.m., we were promptly seated. Be forewarned: this place is roughly the same size of the living room in my apartment. What it lacks in space, it makes up in providing a comfortable and homey feeling.

Our server, while slightly awkward, was kind, prompt, and pleasant. We ordered:

Gilroy: This was super yummy. I tend to eat a lot of Bok Choy, and I think Pomelo does it right!

Manila: I was less in love with this dish than the Gilroy. While tasty, I thought it lacked flavor. Given my fellow Yelper's reviews of Pomelo, I expected this to knock my socks off. 

Snapper Special: Although the fish was cooked superbly, this dish lacked flavor as well. It struck me as rather bland.

Was it a pleasant enough meal? Yes. Did I leave full and satisfied? Yes. Would I recommend it to others? Probably not. With so many places yet to explore, I won't be venturing back any time soon.
author: Annalise F.

description: This is a nice neighborhood restaurant. The menu is based on grains and noodles from a variety of cuisines- Asian, European, Americas. Everything is fresh, and it's a fine meal, but nothing too crazy. The place is small, so probably best for parties of 2-4 max.
author: J L.

description:
I picked this place for dinner with my girlfriends. 

Place is quite small -- 3 tables and 8 seats at the dining bar with open kitchen.

I ordered fish cakes and it was wrong. Come on it's noodle house! My girlfriends went with noodles and they liked it. 

Also we got two plates of sauteed in garlic bok choy -- I liked it. 

Overall, quite, tiny restaurant with seductive smell from open kitchen.
author: Anelya S.

description:
the space was a bit cold and dark.

hat yai (curry noodle) was quite nice, but grilled fish of the day and brussel sprout are just OK -- would try another place next time.
author: Rebecca C.

description: Great asian fusion near UCSF Medical Center. Very small but we did take-out. Food was excellent.  Service was great. By far the best in the area.
author: Billy A.

description: This location is a bit cramped but the food's just as good as the Noe Valley location. We like to come by for random weekday dinners when it's not crowded and service is more attentive. Sometimes we end up being the only diner in the restaurant which is probably due to their location. If wasn't for the big Pomelo outside, we probably would have driven right by it.  Menu choices don't get tired or stale due to their ever-changing menu. I'm a fan.
author: Esther A.

description:
Despite the reviews saying that it's freakin cramped in here Jonathan and I got super lucky and took the last available table the night before our anniversary as the other part of my gift to him (there were many parts :P lol) It was a cold, breezy, foggy night that I found parking about a block and a half away from the restaurant and hurriedly walked over just to be sure we could get seated.

We loved the setting here, well other than being a little too dim but we did like the romantic vibe it gave off. It was quiet, comfortable, and just what I wanted for our night ^_^

The open kitchen was a nice sight to see and observing that other customers were definitely enjoying their food. The waiter was amiable and he kinda figured that we were new so he gave us extra time to figure out what to order.

The food came out surprisingly quick compared to restaurants like this. (thumbs up!) For appetizers we ordered the Cabo San Lucas which is basically Fish Taco's with mango salsa. To be honest this is the first time i've ever had fish taco's and it tasted amazing!  the salsa went paired up with the fish so well and, oh man, we devoured that plate til there was just jalapeno's left on the dish haha. 

Jonathan had the Madiun and I had the Manila. Both were noodle dishes which were both unique and delicious. I thought that these dishes were priced very appropriately and we thoroughly enjoyed our meal. We had lemonade and an iced ginger lemongrass to quench our taste buds for some relief. There was a lot of food to go around so we did not complain at all. Jonathan had finished everything seeing that the bowl was only half full whereas he would have liked it to be filled to the rim :P 

I'm coming back here again :) YuM!!!!
author: Marie G.

description: Small and intimate. Definitely a favorite for lunch or dinner. Amazing food!!!
author: Johnny L.

description:
To review any singular dish would be neglectful of the others. Let's just say I've had half the menu over the last year or so and not a single dish has been less than terrific. 

When you walk into a closet posing as a restaurant, it's difficult to know what your getting into but this place delivers. Almost diner like in it's simplicity of decor but the waiter/owner is exceptionally attentive and the proximity to the chef is unprecedented. You don't want onions in your dish? You can whisper it to the chef. 

I had the Polenta with Wild Mushrooms and Penne with Spicy Italian Sausage. Sounds like I'm in an Italian restaurant huh? This menu has Asian, Cuban, French, Filipino, and Indonesian as well. Don't let the diversity fool you. They have a concise menu that WORKS at the highest level. 

Nautilus Sauvignon Blanc and some Capay Valley Vineyard Viognier made the meal even better. 

You're nuts if you don't give it a try.
author: david t.

description:
3 Tables for two (6 seats)
4 Counter seats facing the window.
8 Counter seats facing the chef.

Don't go here with a large party.  While the restaurant is tiny, atmosphere is pretty good with a nice San Francisco vibe.  I've been to their Church Street location a number of times for Brunch and gave it 5 Stars. (http://www.yelp.com/biz/uZybAaC88oLnqR1FEUamGQ)

FOOD:  I tried dinner at Pomelo for the first time at Judah location.  Compared to their brunch, dinner menu is noodle heavy.  Almost every item is noodle base - which keeps the prices reasonable around $10-15/dish.  I must say that I enjoyed their brunch more than their noodle dishes.  The problem of a restaurant offering a vast variety of cultural food is that they don't know how to make all dishes authentic.  For example, their 'Sapporo' ($9) Ramen was a disaster.  They did not use the right type of ramen noodles; instead used some soggy noodles that is NEVER used in ramen.  Soup was slightly better than the noodle, but not authentic.  On the other hand, their soba dish 'otsu' ($9) was pretty tasty.  It sure wasn't authentic, but it was made in an interesting california style that made the dish work.  Their ahi tuna dish 'lanzhou' ($14.5) was pretty good.  

All in all, a pretty cool restaurant, as long as you don't go here to seek authentic dishes.  Come here with an open mind and enjoy watching the chef cook.  I enjoyed $3.5 beer.  I look forward to going back.
author: トモ T.

description:
With just 18 seats, Pomelo epitomizes "hole in the wall" but that's not to say there isn't charm in its tininess. We arrived about one o'clock in the afternoon on a weekday and waited about ten minutes before claiming two seats at the counter. Watching the chefs work (and maneuver around one another) is pretty amazing considering that the kitchen space they've got isn't much more than that of  your average city apartment. A large tray of water is kept boiling on the side into which they dunk individual portions of noodles. From what I observed, it appears that everything is cooked to order. If you're a fan of watching your food being prepared, I'd get a seat at the counter.

For lunch I ordered the "garfagnana" which is an organic faro salad tossed with roasted corn, cherry tomatoes, scallions and an aromatic herbed vinaigrette, topped with grilled skirt steak. The steak was very tender and the dish was full of flavor. It held up to my ultimate test of tasting good the next day (since I rarely finish a dish in one sitting, this holds weight with me). My dining companion had the "lanzhou" - fresh egg noodles stir fried with ginger, scallion and garlic, with peppered ahi tuna, seared rare and topped with a miso-sesame drizzle. I had a couple of bites and enjoyed that as well.

I like both the concept and execution of Pomelo and am excited to return and try some of the other dishes on the menu.
author: Miriam W.

description:
It's been years since I've dined at Pomelo on Judah.  I love sitting right up close so we can watch our meal being cooked up!  

With only 18 seats, I was a bit worried about my party of 5 being able to sit together.  We were lucky though as everyone after us had to wait for seating or ended up getting carry out.

I chose the "Manila - pancit bihon, Filipno style stir fried rice noodles with sauteed prawns and chicken, chinese sausage and vegetables, with scallions and lemon wedge" ($10).  The chinese sausage was cooked separately to blacken them up a bit.  The noodles and chicken were very tasty and I was impressed. I was a bit disappointed with only two shrimps though.  (The cook made two orders of Manila together, and I think most of my shrimp ended up in the other take out order as I watched.)  

Menu changes seasonally, which is always nice.  There weren't many choices on this menu that particularly struck my fancy though.  

Atmosphere is nice and this is definitely a 'local' eatery.  If you're sitting at the bar stools facing the stove, be prepared to make friends.  With this intimate setting, it's easy to overhear conversation and check out the other diner's food choices.  Parking can be very challenging, especially on weekends.  (I was there on a Wednesday night.)

They offered dessert of gelato - 2 flavors for $4.50.  We passed this time.

P.S. The bathroom in the back...watch out when turning on the water.  The pressure from the water bounces right out of the sink and gets the door all wet!
author: Teri C.

description: I thought this restaurant was very good, it was small but open, and I could see what the chef was cooking so I felt safe with the food.
author: Tristan G.

description:
Love this place! It has a very comfortable neighborhood feel to it. There are only 8 seats at the counter, 4 facing the window, and 3 tables, so don't come with too many people. The service is excellent and the chef is professional. It's an open kitchen, so you can watch your food being cooked. 

My favorite dishes (but everything is good):
-Manila
-Sonoma (the goat cheese that comes on it is delicious)
-Lanzhou (if you like tuna... it's perfectly seared)
The flavors are perfect -- never too heavy.

This is the best place to be on a cold foggy day in Inner Sunset. If you love healthy Asian-inspired style food, you should definitely visit this place!
author: Jessica W.

description:
The atmosphere is very cute.  It's a very small place, 3 tables and the rest are bar/counter seats.  There's an open kitchen where you can see the chef's every move and your meal prepared right before your eyes.  It feels like you're in a friend's kitchen.  There is only a team of 3 in the restaurant - 1 head chef, 1 helper who also cleans dishes, and 1 waiter. The waiter is a little slow, but you kinda have to take that as part of the atmosphere.

Food was good.  I picked out some of the recommendations Yelpers listed here.  

1.  Otsu - Japanese buckwheat noodles, served cold with stir-fried tofu, with a hint of lemon and hot sauce.   This is listed as an entree but we split it as an appetitizer.  (What I liked was that when we told the waiter that we are splitting this, the dish actually came out on 2 small plates already separated.)  
2.   Manila - vermicelli stir-fried with a combo of veggies, shrimp, and chicken.  I thought it was really good because the vermicelli came out not dry at all!!  This dish didn't have any sauce with it, so it was amazing that the vermicelli was still tasty and moist.
3.  Bandung - thick Shanghai-type noodle with baby bok choy and shrimp.  This is a spicy dish.  I did not particularly think it was all that great.  It was OK.  Definitely not my favorite.

The only dessert they have is gelato/sorbet.  We skipped.  

I would go back again to try some of their other dishes.  I definitely love the cozy/cute feel of this small restaurant.
author: Jannie Q.

description:
Pop quiz! How can one restaurant serve a good thai, japanese, and cuban dish on one menu?

Answer: It can't.  

If you're adamant about asian food like myself, you'll probably be disappointed.  It really tasted like cheap cooking to me.  Kind of like the same feeling you get when you see some 20 year old girl at a club in a Forever 21 graphic tee, whose drink in hand certainly cost more than her outfit.
author: Boris C.

description:
Pomelo is one of my favorite San Francisco restaurants. I love how quaint and cozy the restaurant is - it barely seats 20 people. The price is right, too.  

The food is amazing because the chef mixes flavors and ingredients that you wouldn't expect together. The ingredients are fresh and seasonal and the menu appeals to all appetites and palettes. Whether vegetarian, a meat eater, craving something exotic - Pomelo has it. I highly recommend the "havana" entree - cuban style fried rice with black beans, plantains, chipotles, ginger and cilantro, served with grilled skirt steak sautéed onions and cuban avocado salad. Yum!
author: Katie M.

description:
I love this place!

I've been here twice -- both times a weeknight catch-up dinner with a friend. It's sort of the perfect atmosphere for that. Small, intimate.. feels like you're in the kitchen of a close friend that is cooking for you. The seating is limited so there's a good chance you'll be at the bar right by the kitchen. 

It seems to always be full when I'm there, yet I've never waited for a table either. Win. The owner and cooks are so attentive and friendly. 

But anyway, the food is what I really care about and it's so yummy and interesting!  I have a slightly compulsive need to constantly be trying new dishes/restaurants, but what brings me back to Pomelo is their extensive menu that changes ever so slightly (different ingredients depending on what's seasonal, etc. to modify more or less the same dish, rather than removing items from the menu altogether, which seems so brilliant). 

So far I've had their tacos and the korean scallion/scallops/prawns pancakes. These are considered the smaller plates and are $8 to $9, but I think are enough for a small meal for a person. Definitely a steal for the quality of food you're getting compared to many other restaurants.

I've also had a taste of one of the noodle dishes before and it was great. The portions on the noodle/ main entrees are huge. So again, I think the $13 ish you spend on that is a steal, since it really makes for two small meals.

Will be back, but not before I try the brunch at the Pomelo in Noe Valley!
author: Richa A.

description: I love this place.  Whenever I go there it's like returning home.  The concept of global fusion is simple and gracefully, smartly executed.  Eclecticism is their guiding principle here and they pull it off well.   It might seem a bit odd to eat one Provençal- and one Tuscan-themed appetizer, and then consider a Peruvian, Cuban, or Thai entrée, but it does turn out feeling like a global tasting-platter experience that's stimulating and fun.  The unpretentious atmosphere really augments the experience of the food.  The menu cycles through seasonal dishes, so there are usually exciting new things to try on return visits.  Also, they have a selection of red wines I can count on for quality.  This place just warms my heart.
author: Moshe Q.

description:
Truly delicious and "feel good" food and a pleasant ambiance! The person working the floor/phone (possibly owner?) was also kind enough to hold a table for us on Friday night when we called to ask about the wait.

This place is small so a few things to consider:
- expect to wait for a seat to open up, especially on weekend nights
- not very accommodating to large groups
- it gets a little loud b/c of the tight space

For my experience with my friends none of those factors negated the greatness of the food and the general feeling of goodness after eating it.
author: Anya S.

description:
I'm going to give it a solid 3 stars for now, but I reserve the right to add or remove stars in the future after more visits.

A and I decided to walk over to Pomelo after he got off work Friday night.  I found parking near his work and we only had to walk about a block and a half.  There were only two other parties inside the teeny tiny restaurant.  By teeny tiny, I mean there's probably only about 15 or 16 seats in the place.

A and I decided to sit at the counter-like seats by the window so we could sit next to each other and stare at people outside.  Did I say stare?  I meant "people watch."  

We started off by sharing the Cabo San Lucas, which is two soft tacos with grilled pacific snapper, shredded cabbage, mango salsa, chipotle aioli and house pickled jalapenos.  Good, but nothing special.  My taco was dripping sauce (juice?) all over my hands and plate.  Yes, I am a messy eater.

For my "main course," I decided to go with Lanzhou, which is fresh egg noodles stir fried with ginger, scallion and garlic, with peppered ahi tuna, seared rare and topped with a miso-sesame drizzle.  Quite tasty.  Portion size was too big for just me, so I ended up eating as much as I could and letting A finish the rest.

A's "main course" was Amphawa, which consisted of thai style duck noodle soup with house smoked duck, wide rice noodles, thai basil, chicnese broccoli and crispy garlic.  It was good, but the duck was super bony, so a big hard to eat.  i have to admit that I've had better duck noodle soup.  In fact, we ended up going to a Burmese/Thai restaurant the very next night and ordered Duck Noodle Soup again and it was much better.

Cute little restaurant.  Asian fusion food.  Nice place to people watch.  Decent food.
author: Kris L.

description:
this review is for their take-out only.

it was a flaming hot day in the sunset.  I forgot my lunch at home and didn't feel like having a salad but didn't want anything hot either.  ordered the otsu to go.  soba noodles with cucumbers, cilantro, tofu in a sesame soy dressing (?).  the portion was definitely enough for me to split into two meals so paying about $11 for it wasn't bad.

ready for pick up in 15 mins, took it back to the office and ate it.  then i sat back at my desk, stared at what was left and thought...was this really worth getting sweaty from walking back up a hill for?  meh, not really.  the tofu was the highlight, not the noodles.  they were a little gummy.

sad face.
author: Sally T.

description:
After feeling uninspired by the played out selection of restaurants around 9th and Irving we decided to look beyond the obvious. And I am so glad we did. Pomelo On Judah has 3 tables, a bar that seats 5, and another bar that seats 3 looking out the front window. But don't be fooled by the size of the place. The food was remarkable. 

We started out with an appetizer of the Cabo San Lucas; which is 2 fish tacos with red snapper served with mango salsa. Yum. Best fish tacos we've had since we were in Baja. Then we went for the Masantol; spicy tofu in a ginger sauce. OMG, so flavorful. And finally we split the Havana entree. I'm not usually a steak eater, but this steak was spiced to perfection and cooked just right to make the outside crispy while leaving the inside pink and juicy. And oh yeah, plantains mixed with black beans and rice. 

Not only was the food creative and delicious, it was very affordable and the service was great. I will most definitely be returning to this hidden gem. 6th and Judah, who knew?
author: Phyllis W.

description:
I've had a mental bookmark to go to Pomelo for quite some time now, as Asian fusion is one of my favorite cuisines. So happy that it was a hit, and there are so many reasons why I'm a fan. 

I was shocked to see how small the venue itself was--literally 3 two tops, counter space for maybe 6, and another three 3 seats at the widow counter top. That said, it was cozy and added charm. I didn't even mind that it was sparsely decorated. Love the open kitchen, as it was impressive to see the one cook and maybe one sous chef working their magic. And magic it was!! 

The menu is pretty eclectic--pan Asian fusion with some Mexican/Latin dishes. All appetizers are called Side Trips, and entrees, Destinations and Upgrades.  Adored it!!  I was ecstatic to see a dish called "Masantol" as it's the name of the town my father grew up in the Philippines. The dish is a sizzling spicy tofu sisig which was way different as sisig typically is prepared with pork. Loved the dish! Tofu was so flavorful and mimicked the traditional dish very well.  All ingredients listed were very present in the dish (eg chili peppers, garlic, soy sauce, lemon, red onion). My dining companion's pick was the "Cabo San Lucas," two soft snapper tacos. Fish tacos were done right, and while I enjoyed them, it wasn't anything to sing home about. 

For my entree, I ordered the "Koh Samui," and substituted the jasmine rice for the fresh egg noodles offered in another dish. I'm a fan of coconut curry, and the vegetables included in the dish: oriental long beans eggplant, and squash reminds me of a dish my mother cooks. Very flavorful, nice kick. I should have left the order alone and had with with the rice. Probably would have enjoyed it more.  (My bad.) 

Service was timely and friendly. The chef greets you and bids you farewell as you leave the tiny venue. Food presentation is simple yet lovely. All just so very charming. I'd definitely go back again, as there's so many other dishes I'd like to try, and the prices are reasonable.
author: Marie B.

description:
I've always wanted to go to Pomelo for a silly reason - I like the little pomelo hanging outside the door! I drive past here semi-often because a friend has lived down the street for many years, so I always admire the pomelo.

Despite it being a bit cramped inside, I liked the convivial feel. Also, the bathroom is hilariously old-school San Francisco. A tiny cubicle very obviously not updated, at the back of a old building, in what could have been a shed before it was a restaurant.

The German beers were yummy, and the bf and I liked our salad and curry and noodles.  But the best part was the sorbet/gelato dessert. Very tasty berry and other flavors. I loved it!
author: Emily M.

description:
Itty Bitty! 

This is by far the tiniest restaurant I've ever dined in! Seating occupancy is approximately 16! Business was moderate when I came in, but when I left around 7pm I'm sure the place was packed! 

I recommend going early if you can because seating is limited and the restaurant location is near a hospital, so parking may also be an issue.  

I've never really ate Asian Fusion food before, but if it was like what I had, I want some more! I ordered (I forget the name) a Thai curry-like dish with chicken and mushrooms. It packed a lot of punch because I wasn't expecting it to be so spicy! I was really hungry and i wasn't even able to finish the dish! 

The decor is a modern brightly colored look and feel. Loved it! Everything was so cute! 

Tables were a bit sticky (I sat at the window), but other than that I would go back for another meal.
author: Amy C.

description:
They definitely put the word fusion into their dishes!

Pomelo has different varieties of cuisine in their menu from all over the world! I've been here a couple of times and every single time I have NOT been disappointed by their dishes.  One thing I like about this place is whenever I have no clue what I'm craving for, Pomelo seems to give me what I need.  You can order a korean pancake for appetizers, have some miso soup, and then have some coconut curry for their entree. 

One of my favorite dishes here is the lanzhou.  It's a seared ahi tuna with egg garlic noodles. Definitely a must try.  Also, if you're not into fish, their havana is really good too! Steak with rice and beans with an avocado salad! 

Yes, this place is REALLY small. I think it only fits like less than 20 people so definitely call ahead for reservations because there is NO room to wait inside. 

The service is nice, fast, and friendly, but I mean come on, there's only like 15 people in here so that should be a given. 

Order some honey lemonade while you wait. There's a dish suited for everyone's taste buds so you will not be disappointed.
author: Hanna P.

description:
3.5 stars. 

Vegetarian friendly asian fusion restaurant in the Inner Sunset! 
- Green Dots = Vegetarian. how easy is that? 

Starter: 
- TUBAN - "martabak telur - indonesian crispy pastry with minced beef, egg and shallots, served with spicy dipping sauce 7.5" The outside was like that of crispy egg rolls, and it went great with the sweet and spicy dipping sauce. the other side it came with was somewhat relish like (wasn't a fan). 

Entree: 
- Muravera - toasted sardinian couscous with fennel, spring onion, fava  beans, english peas, pancetta, saffron and fresh herbs, topped with lemon marinated grilled tiger prawns 15.5 - TIGER PRAWNS in this dish were tasty, but a bit on the small side. otherwise the couscous was large enough to be semi pasta-ish, but it didn't "hit the spot" like how it was described.  

- the KOH SAMUI however was super tasty! spicy coconut curry with chicken, oriental long beans, thai eggplants, squash, straw mushrooms, kaffir lime leaves and fresh cilantro, served with jasmine rice. and only 11.50! Can't beat a filling dish that will fill you up for 2 meals! The chicken was a bit dry. but if you are eating vegetarian this is still filling, with the eggplant and squash and super tasty curry flavors. 

Libations: 
- Fat Tire
- Asahi Black - Like guiness, but not as heavy. 

Overall. good place to come to, especially if you have a small party (2-3) any more than that.. you may be out of luck at this locale, as there are only about 20 seats in the whole restaurant. small, cozy. And if you sit at the bar, you can watch the chef prep your meal!
author: Judy N.

description: Another place that I have no idea how it got 4 stars.  I really was excited to go here & wanted to like it.  I had the sautéed book choi & Manila stir fry rice noodles.  The food had way too much soy sauce & some other sauce that made both dishes taste sour.  In fact... they tasted the same.  I don't mind sour but the "sauce" was really all I could taste in both dishes. The noodles were not balanced, had dark meat chicken, 2 pieces of shrimp & some Chinese sausage that was unimpressive.  I even tried dumping the leftover garlic from the bok choi into the noodles & it couldn't help the dish.  I would not recommend this place at all with all the wonderful choices within 2 - 3 blocks.
author: N A.

description:
i love sitting at the counter at pomelo to enjoy watching the chef make the beautiful dishes. my favorite dish here is the otsu though the bread salad I tried was wonderful too. 

the otsu is a vegetarian cold noodle dish that is full of vegetables and perfectly cooked tofu. The portion is generous with enough for another small meal to take home. the bread salad is also heavy on the seasonal vegetables. Basically you aren't going to feel guilty about your meal at pomelo and you will not feel cheated on your portion or flavor. The menu is full of inventive dishes and offers a lot of variety.

The restaurant is very small so sometimes it can get full but the service is attentive.
author: Leuwam T.

description:
Got to otsu (the cold buckwheat noodles) which were so good that my girlfriend and I tried to emulate it.  Also had the havana which was good as well.

This place is pretty small, so may get crowded, but worth it.
author: Ken L.

description:
Tired of the food options at my job, I went in search of something to eat off site and stumbled across Pomelo. The interior is small but inviting,it was busy and the host/waiter was responsive. The food looked great and I loved that I could watch it being prepared. 

Now, the reason this place gets 2 stars is because of the lack of sanitary food preparation. The chef would occasionally dip his tongs in what I assume is scalding hot water as he would switch to cooking and preparing different foods. However, I watched in horror as the chef used the same tongs to scoop out RAW marinated FISH into a mini white bucket that he then turned around and used to scoop my food onto the plate. I was grossed out, left with my food in a box and didn't eat it.
author: Tanishia B.

description:
Nice Asian Cousin, so different, every dish is a surprise to me. Also eating a the bar seems like watch the food channel, you can see how chef cook the dish for you, great.
fish Taco is my favorite.
author: Jacqueline X.

description:
The Pomelo on Church may be more well-known, but the 6th & Judah location is God's gift to the Inner Sunset locals (at least the snoopy ones--I know people who've lived in the nabe for years and never even noticed this place until I pointed it out to them).

It's adorably, even impossibly small, with two tables, a kitchen counter and a window counter.  The menu more or less writes the book on California eclectic, with every dish being a uniquely inspired (and decidedly global) experiment that never lets you down for either protein or carbs (like smoked trout fettucine, seared tofu over soba, or Indonesian stir fry in broth, to name but a few choice examples).  The quality screams gourmet, but the prices, portions, and lack of pretension say otherwise.  

In short, it's the perfect restaurant.  Now please forget you ever saw this review, otherwise I'll never get a seat there again (unless I go for an iced tea lunch, which is also fabulous).
author: Wes M.

description: Loved the food and the relaxed atmosphere in this little "hole in the wall". It was fun to watch the chef whip up our tasty meal.
author: Masha K.

description:
Came here for the 2nd time recently.  It was one of those nights, let's go out and I don't know where to go.  So my friend and I were around the area, we were originally gonna go to Hotei but the wait was long.  Then I remembered Pomelo  must be around the area, I just don't know where.  With the help of my dear boyfriend and text Google, we found out we parked just down the street from the restaurant.

Food- I love the freshness and the bursting herbs/flavors.  I got the Semarang and Mmmm.  My friend got the Havana  and MmMmm.  Gelato was yum, good ending for our dinner.  

Place-  The place is located away from the busy 9th and Irving area so I think you can find better parking.  When I saw that Pomelo fruit, I knew I had arrived.  I love the intimacy of the place.  It's like walking to someone's kitchen, ask you what you wanna eat then they cook... you can even see them cook!  I'm undecided whether it'd be good for romantic date... it's a small place and the ambiance is nice so that's good, but if you wanna whisper sweet nothings to your date... maybe not the place.  

Service- Waiter was great, made sure everything is good, but not intrusive which was nice.  

Overall, I love it!  I would go back again and try their different dishes.  I guess they don't totally change their menus coz a lot of the dishes were still there from the firs time I came there.  As we were leaving, we said our goodbyes to the waiter and I felt like saying bye to everyone as if it was rude to leave a family party without saying bye to everybody.  hahah
author: Claire J.

description:
The Inner Sunset is one of my go-to neighborhoods when I want to go out and grab a bite without having to travel too far. That being said, going to the usual places can be a little dull at times and I look forward to finding hidden gems to spice things up. Pomelo is my latest find and is a great example of a cozy restaurant. It looks as if it can accommodate about 20 people. The decor is modern with an Asian Fusion flare to it. 

FOOD: I ordered the Koh Sumai, which consisted of chicken coconut curry over jasmine rice. String beans, thai eggplants, squash, mushrooms, and lime leaves are also infused into the curry sauce. Initially, I didn't care for the sour taste from the lime but as I continued eating, I grew to appreciate it's flavor more and more. It provided an interesting contrast to the subtle sweetness from the rest of the sauce. My only gripe is that they don't offer a brown rice option.

Helpful tip: I ordered the dish to go, which was a smart move. They include a lot of curry and put it in a separate container from the rice. Thus, I was able to save the sauce for a second meal. For $11.50, it's a pretty pricey item, so making the most bang for your buck is a good idea.

SERVICE: The waiter is very nice. I just finished a run at Kezar and while I waiting for my food, he offered me some water, seeing how tired I must have looked. 

PRICE: Food is not cheap even for lunch hours. Expect to spend at least $10 before tax/tip.

BOTTOM LINE: If you want to spend a little more and try some nice Asian Fusion, this isn't a bad choice. Potentially a great place for a date and if you want to have more intimate conversation.

4 stars.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
The coconut curry is superb -- pieces of perfectly tender chicken, crisp green beans, diced squash, and eggplant in a well-seasoned curry sauce. It's served with fragrant jasmine rice, and also microwaves well if you have leftovers.

That's the only dish I've tried so far, but I'm looking forward to returning for the others.
author: Kat A.

description:
I only review places that leave me with really good or really bad impressions.  That said, I love Pomelo.  They have a really great, reasonable menu.  It's small, but cozy, and romantic.

You must try the baked polenta with madeira and cream.  It's simply delicious.  Great entrees too!  I usually get the Havana-- cuban rice and skirt steak.  

Check it out.
author: Lauren L.

description:
Pomelo is a good restaurant. For the prices, the portions are really reasonable! I went there for dinner, not lunch, so my opinion of the price may be skewed, but the most expensive "destination" is $16 (depending on the market price of fish) and for San Francisco that is pretty good. I was in a group of three and, including my two glasses of wine (for some reason the other people in my party were not drinking), the entire meal was around $60, not bad in my opinion.

The food we ordered was really good! It wasn't overly amazing or original, but it was a very satisfying meal with robust flavors and fresh ingredients. It is a great mixture of worldly cuisine with a familiar homestyle feeling. Even my boyfriend who decided to eat a burrito before dinner was amazed at my choice in restaurant and was regretting his pre-dinner. (sidenote: I usually pick pretentious restaurants with small portions in his opinion)

My only complaint is that the service was a bit slow.

I think it is a perfect place to get take-out from or enjoy a calm, midweek dinner amongst friends. I will definitely go back again.
author: Tara T.

description:
Tiny storefront "dive".  Well, a very clean dining room in a crumby old building. 

Excellent cooking of a surprisingly varied menu, though the slant is definitely Asian. Vibrant flavors, good plate presentation.  I had the Koh Samui rice bowl with spicy creamy coconut curry, chicken, yam, mushrooms, long beans.  Big portion, cheap price. Tasty!  Bambie had the Philippine pancit, I tasted it - I liked the Koh Samui better.  My pal, Robert, had the Soba noodles with barely grilled fresh tuna steak coated in sesame seeds.  That was truly excellent.  

It is amazing how good the food is from an open kitchen that's 30 square feet which has a 4 burner stove.  The high food quality here proves that selecting good ingredients and paying attention to careful preparation is 95% of the restaurant game. 

Decent selection of beers, wines, & teas.  

This Pomelo location wins my SF award for great eats on the cheap!
author: Tom S.

description: One of my must visit places every time I come back to visit San Francisco. This place is an intimate setting with an open kitchen allowing you to see all of the Chefs working their magic!  I would recommend sitting at the bar so you can watch them cook! The food is very affordable and delicious! I would recommend the bok choy, fish tacos, the chicken coconut curry and the skirt steak. I have also had other things on the menu that were all very good. Looking forward to my next trip to San Francisco to visit this restaurant again!
author: Ryan J.

description: Always a solid place to grab a quick weeknight dinner if we're feeling a little lazy. The menu is a little static, so it might be a little more enticing if there were more seasonal dishes.
author: Todd H.

description:
Words that rhyme with Pomelo:

-Jello
-Fellow
-Yellow
-Pillow (in certain regions of the country)
-Mellow

...and "oh, hello." 

Which was my reaction after eating here last night. The Inner Sunset is a goldmine for numerous under-appreciated dining options and Pomelo is no exception. 

You hear about small places and this spot is smaaaaaalllll. There are 3 tables, 4 seats at a counter against the window, and about 6 seats at the counter around the kitchen. We arrived on a Friday night at 8pm and got sat at a table immediately. By the time we left, the "lobby" was crowded with folks. And by "crowded" I mean there were 4 people at our backs. Yeah, it's that small. 

We ordered the Gilroy for an appetizer which is bok choy seasoned in olive oil, garlic and peppercini flakes. It was deeeelish, fostering high expectations for the meal. For dinner, I ordered the Ayacucho which, according to the menu, is "grilled fish of the day and quinoa cakes with ancho chili, served with roasted sweet pepper coulis, tangy onions and avocado" (Pomelo website, 2009). The fish was some kind of white fish (v. yum) and the quinoa cakes were awwwwwesome. The tangy onions were not my thing so it was the only item left on the plate by the end of the meal.

My friend ordered the Havana which was cuban influenced rice, beans, plantains and grilled skirt steak. Do yourself a favor and order this. It's served on giant banana leaves and I was tempted to steal his plate, pick up the leaves and funnel the entire meal down my mouth. Yeah, it's that good. 

My advice: either come here early or at an off-hour. Beat the rush. Or order take-out. It seemed to be a popular option for all the UCSF students that came in throughout the meal. 

However you do it, just get those plantains down your throat soon.
author: Jared S.

description:
Ok I will elaborate. 

Bottom line, anyone who looks like they hate their job isn't good at what they do. If your going to have an open kitchen, then hire a chef who smiles. This guy sucked. I decided to give him the benefit of the doubt. Bad start. 

I ordered the Avingon (daube provençal) and my girlfriend ordered the cold soba noodle with pan fried tofu. The waiter was semi-attentive and polite enough, although he was slightly rude to the people next to us. He was expaining how the menu was carefully calibrated to appeal to different palates. Really?

I spent more time watching the chef who was over-grilling a skirt steak that he pulled out of a bucket. Uh oh. Then I watched him cook our order. The Avignon came out of a bucket too! I was psyched (heavy sarcasm). The soba was any easy one, I figured they couldn't fk that one up. They did. 

When the food came it looked ok, so I dug in. I should have ran. 

Avingon. This essencially a stew. The meat should fall apart right? Nope. Well, a couple pieces did. But with a stew it should be cooked for a long time so everything is cooked equally. Traditionally Daube Provençal is a 3 day endeavor 1 day marinate, 1 day to cook, one day in fridge to mature flavor. The flavor. What flavor? There was one singular flavor, no balance, no contrast, nothing. Where's the bay leaf? The bouquet garni? The bacon? BLAND. The gnocchi was doughy, over parsleyed, and just plain bad. The haricort vert was limp and flavorless. To top it off they put bread in the plate. Why? Isn't the gnocchi enough starch?

Soba. Giant pieces of pan fried tofu on top that totally overpowered
the noodles. It wasn't even cooked through. The noodles were rubber and the dressing was singular. No flavor. Just plain bad. My girl ate about a tenth of it. 

Butternut squash soup. SAGE. SAGE. SAGE. WAY TOO MUCH SAGE. it's all I tasted. It completely dominated the buttery sweetness of the squash. Once again. No balance, no contrast, just plain bad. 

Bread and butter. 1$. What? Are you serious? Store bought bread with COLD BUTTER PACKETS that destroys the bread when you spread it. Nice. 

Overall, for a restaurant that charges $10+ a plate it falls short. Not that I was expecting a michelen star quality meal, but in that price range, in this city especially, I expect to walk out with a smile. 

On paper the menu is creative. In reality it was poorly executed. 

I will not go back. 

*****EDITED SO IT DOESNT GET REMOVED AGAIN******
author: Don't A.

description:
Recently, I have decided to explore the inner sunset restaurants... and was really excited to try Pomelo out after reading the previous 3-4 star reviews. Located off of Judah, a small dinning area with bar seating overlooking the kitchen and 3-5 small tables. This multi-cultural restaurant in theory has a great theme... but, somewhat mediocre food. 

Started off dinner with the aosta, which sadly to say... I love polenta, but have - no love - for this dish. Then for the main course, choose their summer '09 special, which I reiterate again, mediocre. Finally bringing me to skipping the Ciao Bella Ice Cream dessert selections. 

Overall, okay experience... of course it was on my "list of inner sunset must trys" - but now it's out of my system - for good.
author: Teena Marie T.

description:
Went here for dinner with 2 of my girlfriends. We had to wait a bit to be seated, but that was ok given that this place only holds about... 15 or so people. Tiny but it adds to its charm!

The service was great and this place is just so cute in its own way. Only 3 stars from me though because I wasn't a fan of what I ordered. It's not on the menu anymore (probably a good thing!) but it was a soba noodle soup with tofu. My friends liked what they got so I think I just made a bad choice. I'd definitely come here again though!
author: Miss H.

description:
I used to frequent the Pomelos on Church a lot but stopped going after a disappointing service experience.  But I missed the buckwheat noodles and tofu sooo much that I just had to go back, except this time to the one on Judah.

It seems like the portions tripled in size (bonus since they were on the petite side previously), however the quality went downhill.  I had the polenta with mushroom ragu.  It was good, but the polenta was dried out and the plate luke warm (I don't think it had been siting in a window, but more like it was prepared hours prior and just reheated).  The buckwheat noodles and tofu were good, but the flavors and plating a little sloppy.  Tofu was definitely dried out.  Cucumbers had gotten soft from probably sitting in a brine for too long.  And noodles overdressed.

Sign.  It really breaks your heart when your mouth waters over a dish you dreamed out for years but then doesn't deliver.  For the price, not sure if I'll go back.  I can definitely make a better version of this dish for a fraction of the price.  Sorry Pomelo!
author: Ashley D.

description: Ambiance, service and setting is perfect for date night at Pomelo judah! My boyfriend and I love this neighborhood eatery. The chefs bar and eclectic menu are fun and makes the restaurant stand out in Parnassus heights/inner sunset area. The menu changes every couple weeks with a few staples that are very good. I recommend the Lanzhou, Manila, the Cabo San Lucas, and the Vigo. All very, very good. The chefs are very talented and fun to watch too which is a plus!
author: Leslie A.

description: This is one of the few places in the city that serves Laksa (what's up with that?). Not super authentic, but still good. Their style of Laksa is a little on the creamy side, and is light on the chili.
author: Marc S.

description:
I have been here many times and usually I give it a 4 star rating because food is good, portions are good, service is good. Our waiter was great, but the chef was mean.
I asked for the Cabo San Lucas tacos vegetarian and the chef wouldn't because the tofu needs time to marinate, but they have made them for me before and were delicious. So I had the Aosta instead and it was not tasty and not filling. Next time I'll stick to the Masantol or Otsu. I also had the Suwa which was good. The strasbourg is a little hard, as artisan bread should be but then the butter is cold. Another customer and her friend sat at the counter and got the chef's attention while the waiter was out of sight and he immediately tells her "the waiter will be with you shortly". There was only 2 parties of 2 people in the restaurant, it's not like he was busy and in terms of customer service why pass on the buck to the middle man when you can do it yourself. The other issue I had with the chef was that his other customer asked for more vegetables in her Manila dish he was "hesitant to add them because that's not how the dish is made". I could understand if it was a Michelin rated restaurant and all high class, but why not be about making good food for people the way the customer likes?
author: Crys L.

description:
Meh.

That's about all I can say for my experience at Pomelo. I had the Ayacucho and have to agree with Lauren F.'s review - the yellowtail had pretty much no flavor (except fish) to it and the quinoa cakes were rather bland as well. Plus, they forgot the yam chips that were supposed to be included with my meal :(  When I finally managed to get the server's attention to politely point this out, he eventually brought out a tiny plate of *cold* yam chips. 

I had been so excited to try out Pomelo so was really bummed to have been letdown. However, I did have a bite of my roommate's meal - the Havana - which was delicious. 

If it hadn't been for the lackluster service, I would have been more apt to just write off my experience as "not the best item on the menu" or "an off-night." But really, Pomelo just seemed to be resting on their laurels rather than aiming to please someone who could have been a really loyal customer.
author: Laura C.

description: One of my new favorite restaurants in the city! I came here on a Friday night with my girlfriend, and we sat at the counter which was fun. Getting straight to the food, we started with the miso soup and bok choy. The bok choy was some of the best I've ever had (even considering my time in China and my grandparents cooking), and the miso soup was a good size, bigger than you often get, and had great consistency and flavor. I had a sort of chicken fried rice dish, and it was amazing. The food combined with the small cozy and friendly atmosphere was perfect. At the risk of revealing a Judah gem and the restaurant becoming more crowded, this is a must visit place! I will definitely be going back.
author: K W.

description:
This is a real gem of a neighborhood restaurant. It boasts a very Californian  menu, but we should be so lucky to have a place like this in Pacifica.You might find something similar in Denver but doubtful in places like St. Louis or Cincinnati. It could be a bit bigger, as they only have tables for about 8 people plus bar space for 9 more. I went with 3 teens and 2 adults and everyone found something they liked a lot, that says something.
We started with  Pienza is a really nice app( bread salad with roasted butternut squash, brussels sprouts, asian pear and lemon-brownbutter dressing)  as was the Palermo crostini made with balsamic glazed figs, gorgonzola and mascarpone over arugula.We had lanzhou ( fresh egg noodles stir fried with ginger, scallion,garlic, with peppered ahi tuna, seared rare ) this was not so rare actually. Sanuki (seafood yaki soba- japanese style stir fried buckwheat noodles with prawns, scallops, vegetables, shiitakes, garnished with dried bonito tunaflakes,seaweed and pickled ginger) Skirt steak and Puno- (quinoa and oven roasted vegetable salad with fennel, turnip, parsnip, carrot, golden beet and fennel-shallot vinaigrette, topped with grilled herbed mary's chicken breast) these were all dishes you'd like to eat just about anytime for dinner. The dessert was  the locally made  sorbet and gelato from Ciao Bella, it's super. Besides the crampness of the space, I'd call this place a winner on all counts 
( nice wine list by the glass too) for an unassuming but refreshing and fairly priced dishes. It's not trying to be more than what it is and the honesty comes across in the food and pricing.
author: Aaron Z.

description:
Use to be our favorite family restaurant.... until last Saturday night. We ate there as usual and when it was time to pay, the 'new' waiter would not accept our tax exemption card (even though it is required by the US Department of State). We asked him to call the owner and apparently the owner refused our tax exemption card. Hard to believe since we've been eating there for 2,5 years now and we never had a problem before. The waiter was very rude in wanting us to pay (including the tax) and leave the premisces, which we were happy to do since we were quite unpleased. I tried phoning the owner myself in the last week to ask for a clarification on what happened but there were either no answer or my calls were not returned. I am very disappointed and will stop referring people to that place.
Bottom line: Don't go to Pomelo if you don't want to ruin your night.
author: Rachel B.

description:
I really wanted to like you Pomelo! You're so cute and close to my house. Yes, you're tiny, but good things usually come in small packages. 

I agree with other yelpers that say that it's tough for a place to mix asian and cuban in one menu and do it well. I went the cuban route and got a dish with Yellowtail (which is evidently much better as sushi), quinoa cakes (highly recommended on Yelp), a deep chili sauce and plantains. Sounds good right? 

The fish was really fishy. And I love love fish - so I'm not really that scared of fishy. But after a few bites I found myself pushing the fish to the corner of the plate to avoid even a little bit mixing with the rest of the meal, that's a bad sign. 

The quinoa cakes were just ok. They were a little mushy, and lacked the crunch I was craving. They were just a little too thick I think. I'd rather them have been more like a latka - instead they were like a soggy crabcake. 

The sauce was just too strong of an unpleasant flavor. I'm not sure what the flavor was, but the dish lacked balance. It was just lots of pungent chili flavor without much spice or balance. 

My friend loved her dish, so it's possible that I just didn't order one of their best dishes. I'd be willing to try again if this place wasn't so pricey! Ah well, you live and learn.
author: Lauren F.

description:
Very small place, with the kitchen very visible...we sat in front of the window facing the outside. Very happy to show off the delicious food we were eating.

We started out with the Gilroy and the Cabo San Lucas. The gilroy is just bokchoy sauteed in olive oil with garlic and pepper flakes? and the Cabo San Lucas was fish tacos with grilled snapper and a mango salsa.

For the entrees my lady had the Manila, which was stir fried thin rice noodles with prawns, chicken, chinese sausage and vegetables. Sounds simple..and it is...but sometimes simple is good.

I had the Ayacucho, grilled fish of the day which was Mahi Mahi with quinoa cakes, had a nice red pepper coulis, some sweet onions and avocado. Very nice, and the red pepper coulis was great.

Overall was very pleased, service was good and it was nice to see the cooking and since it was sunny there was a beautiful sunset going down. Will definitely come back again.
author: phillip w.

description:
i think i'm biased against asian fusion because i'm asian. but i feel like "asian fusion" doesn't do justice to either asian cuisine or whatever it is fused with. 

i had the coconut curry here, which was bland by my tastes. the combination of flavors/ingredients was nothing unique or especially tasty. i tried bites of other dishes, which were equally bland.

i did really, really like the atmosphere. i liked that you could watch food be cooked fresh in front of you. i liked that you could customize and get a half portion and a side of salad instead of a full portion. and i liked the extensive wine menu.
author: lily c.

description:
The restaurant is very quaint and intimate and the food is dy-nomite!

We got an appetizer, a medium range priced bottle of wine, two entries and a desert for $66 out the door.... what an amazing price for what is probably one of the best restaurants yet to be discovered in SF!  When people catch on to this place no doubt the small 15 person capacity spot will become crazy to get a reservation but for now its an easy drop by location to eat your fill.

the portions are ample and honestly we could have split an entree but it was not only quantity but also quality.. the food was inventive and tasty.

i highly recommend trying this place out before more people discover it and it becomes hard to get a reservation. i KNOW i will be back!
author: Edibleocea N.

description:
Gets better and better every time! I'm once again grateful I live only 5 minutes away.

THE PLACE
