1. This little gem of a place gets overlooked due to its location and that's why I love it - because it stays hidden and is a true treasure to discover. 

2. It's a great if you're looking for a quiet dinner, a mellow evening, an intimate experience and a place with really good energy to it. 

3. Good for 3 people or less, since the space is small with maybe 4 tables at most that seat 2 to 4. The rest is bar seating that seats about 10 at most.

4. Clean place, simple taste in layout and noise level is medium to low (not counting the kitchen noise)

THE FOOD
1. Went there a couple of days back with a good book (In Defense of Food of all things!), sat at the counter for the first time and quite enjoyed, with much amazement, seeing the chef cook my meal in front of me on a very simple gas range! WOW! P.S. I almost wanted to take my note pad out and take notes on how he was cooking.

a. Started off with a glass of Malbec and the Gilroy appetizer which is the bok choy sauteed in olive oil with garlic. Wine and appetizer paired up really well. The richness of the wine and the garlic flakes were well balanced with the simplicity, juiciness and natural flavor of the bok choy.

b. Dinner was simple with the Havana which is the cuban style fried rice with plantains, chipotles, served with grilled skirt steak, sautéed onions and cuban avocado salad. Avocado salad was a perfect blend of good texture and a somewhat tart flavor but refreshing. This was balanced with the rice which was rich in spices and the skirt steak was moist, thinly cut and easy to eat.

c. Desert was a simple mochi ice cream with a wafer

2. In the past me and my friends have had the surin, hania, cabo san luca, suwa and tripoli appetizers, the gorgonzola, sonoma, solo, the hué, manila, avignon, koh samui, guangzhou and san marino dinner and no complaints. 

3. Their wine selection, though limited, all seem to have been thoughtfully paired up with the menu.

4. Menu seems to change seasonally.

5. Have heard a lot of good things about their brunch but am yet to try it out.

THE SERVICE
1. One guy does everything and he is friendly, on time, efficient and charming. Very consistent each and every time I've been there.

ADVICE
1. Only advice is to come early if you're with a group because seating can get tough and you could just end up on one of the cramped tables.

2. If somewhat cramped / intimate spaces are not for you, you might want to go to the location in Noe Valley

Thanks, Pomelo for making many a nights with friends special and many a nights by myself enjoyable!
author: Amit S.

description:
This place is a good place to go for lunch if you're thinking about eating something healthy and fresh. The service is very good here and the food was great. I think i had the thai noodles and the ingredients such as the vegetables tasted very crisp and fresh. 

The only down sides are the price, which i thought was a little much for the food. Also, during noon time, it gets really crowded since a lot of people from UCSF are on lunch break and head towards this place. 

Other than those little complaints, it's a great small place for fusion food.
author: robin w.

description:
It's such a cute place but unfortunately, being "cute" doesn't make up for the food. My friends and I took up the entire counter space the night we came here not knowing how small Pomelo is! Fortunately, they were able to accommodate all 8 of us at the counter.

The host/server never rushed us despite of taking up practically the whole place! Overall, the food was just "meh"...nothing that stood out for any of us and we practically ordered everything on the menu! 

I prefer patronizing small & intimate restaurants and wished so bad that Pomelo would be a "go to" spot for me but, like I said, "cute" just doesn't cut it, at least when it comes to food!
author: Soozie H.

description:
The food at Pomelo is great: fresh, tasty and nice seasonal varieties. The service is efficient and what I really like is to sit at the bar and watch the Chef in action!

However I gave it only 3 stars because of the cleanliness of the restaurant:
dusty lamps, dirty walls....The place needs a good cleaning!

Anyway, this is the trend in San Francisco: the dirtier , the more popular!
author: Anastasia M.

description:
Pomelo is a very small, slightly pricey, global-cuisine restaurant. I've eaten take out from here many times in the past, although yesterday was my first experience eating inside. It's the perfect place to dine if you're alone on lunch break (like me) or if you're with a few friends. 

Parties greater than 2 will have trouble finding seating, as there are probably a total of 15-20 seats in the entire place. Of those seats, many are bar seats either facing outdoors or looking into the microscopic kitchen. I'm consistently amazed by what they can produce in such a small space!

My favorite things I've ever had there are the Cuban fried rice, Chicken curry, and Filipino noodles (I think called "the Manilla"). The food is not always 5 stars, but overall I think most people will like it. It's a bit pricey for lunch, but much better than most food available in the area.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Not so much. 

Both of my lunch experiences here were like... online dating: Good on paper... intriguing, worldly. I hyped myself up for the FOOD, it was as if I'd read the profile, perused the pics, exchanged great emails, and set a time and date for "coffee" - and then felt absolutely no connection. 

My first lunch here, right before Spanksgiving was tasty. I mean, it was as delicious as a $14.50 lunch entree gets! I forget the cutesie globally inclined name that described the duck ragout over flat noodles of unknown provenance that made me not care that I was two days away from the biggest eating holiday of the year. 

The portion was gigantic, and I put aside all pretense of being dainty and demure - I worked that predictable Asian Fusion serving bowl like a trough... and grinned as I asked for a to-go box. 

So, last week, my gal pal from Shanghai was in the 'hood and I chose Pomelo because it was 11:30 and I wanted to beat the lunch crowd. This restaurant IS intimate, if that's a charming euphemism for "tiny and crowded". 

We both asked for hot tea... and got a weird basket full of eclectic teas, ranging from Darjeeling Breakfast to Chamomile. Is it too much to ask for the standard Japanese Green Tea at an Asian Fusion joint? As I recall, I ended up with some sort of Ginger-Lemon-Heartburn infusion, so 40 mgs of Prilosec is what I had for dessert, if you really want to know. 

Gal Pal ordered the Lanzhou, which she hated, but was too polite to say so. I used deductive reasoning and simple observation: she only ate 1/8 of her entree and picked at the noodles, which can only be described as flaccid. And that's NEVER a complimentary adjective. 

Did I mention that Gal Pal is the same height and weight as yours truly, but can eat three times as much as I can in a single sitting? 

Cringe-worthy. 

I chose the Manila, which was a leap of faith, because I really don't eat Filipino food... but the description was written in such a titillating manner that I really couldn't refuse the chance to sample their interpretation of this dish. 

* Eater Beware - the menu reads: manila 
pancit bihon - Filipino style stir fried rice noodles tossed with 
sautéed prawns, chicken, Chinese sausage & vegetables, with 
scallion and lemon 11 

However... they don't use rice noodles; they were the standard bean thread, glassy noodles, and while I anticipated finer, more delicate cuts of the aforementioned Chinese Sausage, giant pieces that were overwhelming to the palate showed up in the dish. 

I wanted to fall in love with a tasty lunch and look my entree in the [figurative] eye and say, "You're fantastic. I'm going to take you home with me!" But it just didn't happen. 

The Asian Fusion descriptor is also a bit confusing for me, since the menu is so muddled. Is it really fusion if you're working multiple continents and ingredients that aren't even vaguely Asian at all? And that's tasting on the curve, accounting for the "fusion". 

http://www.pomelosf.com/judah%20late%20winter%202009%20lunch.pdf 

Dishes named: Strasbourg, Merida, Moscow, Ayacucho, Biloxi, Havana, Le Puy, Cuneo, Aosta, Gilroy, Vigo, Puerto Princesa, and... Cabo San Lucas...? 

Please! Don't insult me - there's no Asian in those locations, names or the INGREDIENTS listed! 

Pomelo... it's not me, IT'S YOU! Clearly... you're going through some sort of transition and is global, to be sure... but just because you offer a side of sauteed tofu doesn't mean you're Asian Fusion. Make up your mind and commit, already! 

Then we can enjoy the symphony, red wine, and romantic walks on the beach... just like every other normal couple that met through an online dating service, but will always say we met in the travel section of a bookstore! 

Call me when you get your act together, okay?
author: Kim D.

description: This tiny little hole-in-the-wall is one of the best kept secrets in San Francisco.  Though the menu is limited, each item is well made and delicious.  I've been here at least 25 times in 8 years, and all but one time, the food was spectacular.  Only once did the food disappoint, but I phoned in my complaint, and they comped that item (spaghetti bolognese) for the next time, so I gave them another chance it's always been one of my favorites.   Hard-core carnivores will love the Havana; Spice afifcianados will love the chicken curry.  My little girls love the Havana, which comes with wonderful plantains, but I've also special-ordered grilled chicken over noodles, fat sesame-sauteed noodles.  Sublime!
author: Lucia M.

description:
Went to Pomelo for the first time the other night with my homegirl Sari G.

Wow! This little place is awesome. I had the Habana, which was a black bean and mango fried rice topped with the BEST skirt steak I've ever had. 

And anyone who knows me, knows I'm always chasing good skirt!
author: Jason R.

description:
I had planned to order the weekend special, but was told by the host/waiter (quite a while after ordering) that they were out of grouper. You'd think he'd be able to tell me that when I order (since the place is the size of my bedroom and has 3-4 employees)...

So instead, I decided to get two small plates: the fish tacos and chicken skewers. The fish tacos were delicious, among the best I've ever had. The skewers (served with peanut noodles) were decent, but nothing special.

I will echo what some others have said about the chef and kitchen. Sitting at the bar, you can't help but the notice the chef always looks slightly upset, and most of the food comes out of big plastic buckets. Some of it looks like it was prepped that day, but some of it looks a bit older....
author: David Z.

description:
Based on personal preferences, Pomelo had 2 things going against it form the beginning:

1. small, small place (read: hard to get a seat, high likelihood of smelling like yours and everyone else's dinner, etc)
2. asian fusion - i've been to enough bad fusion places to really be turned off by the term

But after hearing friends gush about it, I took a chance & came with the bf for a friday dinner. We got lucky and was able to snag one of the last seats at the counter top. One thing I noticed right away was how the small space didn't bother me as much here as other places do. While the decor is not fancy, they did a good job creating a comfortable, clean environment. 

The service was great, esp consider that there was only one server (maybe he also doubled as the GM?). He did his job professionally, answered our questions, and retreated to his little cove. 

I ordered the Koh Samui (curry chicken) and the bf ordered the Lanzhou (ahi tuna w/ noodles).  All this is from the summer 2009 menu...i haven't gone enough to fig out if these are 2 year round dishes. Both of us were very happy with our dishes. My curry was nicely flavored and in balance. Sometimes certain things can be really overpowering in curry dishes, but that wasn't the case here. The lanzhou was also a good dish. The noodles were cooked to the right consistency and paired nicely with the ahi tuna. I think my bf liked the dish, but not enough to order it again next time. The portion sizes are also more generous than what I would have expected.

I can't say that I am no longer turned off by the term "asian fusion," but it definitely isn't a problem at Pomelo.
author: Rona J.

description:
My co-worker and I went to eat at Pomelo on Judah and 6th for his birthday. He's been raving about this place ever since I asked him for restaurant recommendations on my first day at work. This place is small, but quaint. It eludes a homey feeling not only because of the atmosphere but also because the staff is very friendly (not to mention prompt). Never had a problem with seating. This place, however, may not be as appealing to those with unadventurous taste buds. This place serves fusion dishes, which means that they take a piece of a country's culture and place it on their menu with an added twist of their own. For people who don't like to venture outside of their comfort zone when it comes to food, I would say this place is not ideal for you. I've seen a lot of reviews about how the food could have been more flavorful, place was too small, etc. but honestly, the two dishes that I've tasted on their menu were prety spot on.

I had the "Havana," which had cuban style fried rice with black beans, plantains, chipotles, ginger and cilantro, served with grilled skirt steak, sautéed onions and cuban avocado salad. By far the best thing I've eaten near my workplace. It is very flavorful, and you know me and my favorite herb Mr. Cilantro. Put cilantro in my dish and I'm sold. You can't go wrong with the avocado salad either. The dish is very well put together and it gives me a little taste of Cuba (kinda want to go there now). It is my favorite dish there so far. I also tried the "Manila" which is a classic twist of the "pancit bihon." It is a filipino style stir fried rice noodles tossed with sauteed prawns, chicken, chinese sausage & vegetables, scallion and lemon. Tastes close to how we make it at home. Also took my best friend here and had their fish special which was delicious. 

If you look at Pomelo's menu, there's a wide variety of dishes to choose from, stemming from different parts of the world. I would absolutely recommend this place for those with insatiable palates
author: Ana B.

description:
I have had two bad experiences at pomelo. When I went a few months ago, the food was served literally off the stove top and burned my mouth.  A few days ago I went with a friend and the waiter neglected to tell me there was a space heater behind my chair.  My jacket was on the chair and apparently the space heater was blowing directly on my jacket with my phone in the pocket for a few hours.  I didnt realize it until I picked up my jacket as we were leaving and the zippers were burning hot, my phone was too hot to hold and my muni pass was sticking to my phone.  The waiter had apparently forgotten to tell me there was a heater there because it was so busy.

So beware where you are sitting!
author: R K.

description:
REALLY small, and REALLY hidden.  I didn't even see this place driving by, and had to drive by again.  I was coming here for my friend's 19th birthday.  Your party can probably only get as big as about 5 people or so and still be able to sit together.  

Anyways, we told the server it was her birthday and all she gave us was the dessert menu to look at but didn't offer any special birthday free dessert. No biggie, but that sucked...

We ordered the the bruschetta for appetizer, the pancit, the lo mein(?), and this chicken fettucine(?).  I don't remember the (?)names anymore.  My favorite dish was the lo mein noodles and the pancit.  The bruschetta was good too.  The fettucine dish w/ the chicken tasted dry to me.

I also didn't really feel like the server came over to check up on us/see if we needed anything much and that my table had to flag her down whenever we wanted something.  

Prices are reasonable.  Don't know if I'd come back though.
author: Leslie Y.

description:
Good food but horrible service, especially from a waiter called Nelson. Despite having made a reservation stating group size and the fact that we were bringing children, this waiter mistreated us our whole stay, and appeared upset at the fact that we had small kids. 
Families beware of this place (and of Nelson!). 
We would have given him $0 tip but because of the group size (6 adults) 18% was already included in the bill. Such a waste....
author: Jazmin a.

description:
MmmMmm.. a cozy spot with an intimate setting that will warm you up from the inside out. Not many tables, a few bar seats where you can watch the cooks literally prepare the meal several feet from you. 

I had the Koh Samui - a curry rice dish - which I thought was a little bitter... due to the kaffir lime leaves. Ryry had the night's special which was seafood paella - delish. We also had an appetizer made with shredded beef on a pastry of sorts... which was really good. 

The menu is seasonal which is awesome (and which also means you have to come back again and again to see what kinds of dishes they conjure up). The food is fresh. The staff is friendly. Very romantic date place.
author: Christine C.

description: Nice change of pace from the cafeteria food @ work. Small venue, but I personally enjoy it.
author: Ashkan D.

description:
Cozy little spot, prob seats about 15. There's a staff of 3, the waiter was very attentive. The bathroom sink cracks me up, smallest sink I've ever seen. Seems like a locals spot.

Sig sig tofu was super salty and looked kinda just dumped on a plate. the Pomelo salad was tasty and the lettuce was good but I didn't care for the little flying insects that we found in the dish..we spotted 3 and had the dish returned and ordered fish tacos instead.

Fish was nice and warm with a decent seared crust but flavor was kind of one dimensional even though it came with a mango sesame salad and cabbage slaw.

The lanzhou noodles would have to be best of the four dishes we ordered...just a tad on the sweet side, nice portion. I enjoyed the chewiness of the noodle and the seared ahi was cooked well.

I don't think I'll return.
author: Chow L.

description:
So often asian fusion foods more often than not will leave you feeling more hungry than before you strolled through the doors. Not at Pomelo's....! My lunch group was plenty hungry and the 17 seating area was small but efficiently quaint. Nice touch with the linen napkins, and kudos for not using those chintzy plastic wrapped wood chopsticks that clog up our trash. 
I ordered the Koh Samui, and the portion size was pretty big, much like the chunks of chicken in the bowl. I wish they added more squash, but they were very generous with the green beans and mushrooms. Love the brown rice, it was very soft and yummy! The coconut curry could have been more spicier, but it was definitely good considering Dr. B, ate all his..not a drop left in his bowl??!!  M. got the Manila plate and it was gorgeous with all the colors of protein and noodles. She not big on the portion size of the chicken (says they were cut too big), but I thought it's perfect. 
My honey lemonade was also fabulous. Not tart at all, with perfect amounts of honey to lemon ratio. Dr. B also loved his lemongrass tea...raved that it was the best drink he's had so far.

Parking is 2 hours around here, plus you have to fight UCSF traffic, but definitely a good place to eat and chill out while you're in inner sunset. Will definitely try to come back for their weekend dinner specials...
author: Pauline L.

description: It was completely empty on a Friday night, and as I arrived earlier than my friend, it was cozy time in the small space (not good for groups!!) with the chef, waiter, and myself. Nonetheless, I was pretty psyched for asian fusion. I think I must have not ordered what was good on the menu. There's a lot of dishes that looked pretty good on the menu, but mine was rather meh. I had a lemongrass broth, rice noodle soup. There were tomatoes, beansprouts, potato chips, and hardboiled eggs in it. Creative I guess, but in the end, I don't think it worked for me.
author: S L.

description:
I must have caught them on an off day because I would hate to think that there is that much review inflation going on here. Honestly, like Lily C., I am against Asian fusion in most cases, but if I have to eat it and it tastes good, who am I to judge them for being creative? Went with coworkers who have been wanting to try this place and, this was not a case of creativity, but rather a lack thereof. 

Came with a group from work for lunch. Had a tough time deciding what to get because several things sounded good. Went with the Koh Samui ($12.50) at the recommendation of the waiter. It was advertised as a Thai red chicken curry with long beans, mushrooms, and squash, and I subbed in brown rice. It seemed like one of the least fusion-y things on the menu, so probably a safe bet right? The portion was very large, so at least they earned the obligatory one star that I have given them. I do not know how this is considered a curry. There was basically no curry flavor to it at all. More like a coconut milk broth. And what was Thai about it? No chilies, or at least no heat whatsoever. No detectable fish sauce. And contrary to other reviews, I tasted no kaffir lime leaves. I could have dealt with the somewhat dry pieces of chicken if the curry had at least been flavorful, but it was so bland. I cannot figure out how they managed to extract all of the flavor from this dish. And to top it all off, the rice was hard and undercooked. I understand that it is short grained organic brown rice, but it should not be hard. This dish was a complete train wreck overall and waaaaayyyy overpriced, especially considering the quality-price ratio expected in this city, let alone this area. 

Perhaps I ordered incorrectly? I must say that the Manila, which is a take on Pancit, looked amazing, but my coworker did not finish more than half of it or take the rest with her despite saying that she liked it. They burned something in the open kitchen while we were eating, which stunk the tiny place up something fierce. One of my coworkers did not get her soup until we were almost finished eating. I think they may have forgotten to make it. 

Overall, very disappointed. Hopefully I never get peer pressured into returning.
author: Miguel V.

description:
Oh my God. Pomelo is like a fucking kitten rolling around on its back in a meadow full of wildflowers: could it possibly get any cuter? Probably not, unless it were wearing a tutu and playing a ukulele.

About the size of your boss's office, Pomelo only has 18 seats, about six of which are at tables. But that doesn't necessarily mean you'll be cramped: I met a hot date here on a Saturday night and we were outnumbered by the staff -- three of them, two of us -- the entire night. 

The waiter was casual, conversational, and blunt without ever crossing that line into being a nuisance. Basically, he was non traditionally excellent and was wearing about the coolest loafers I've seen. He knew that we were there for the food, and he was genuinely excited to help us out: he offered up suggestions (he was a very regular eater at Pomelo before he started working there, so he knows what he's talking about), descriptions, free tastes of wines, and dessert on the house. 

We ordered the massa, an appetizer of Tuscan bread salad: crunchy house-made crouton thingies, perfect heirloom tomatoes, toasted hard ricotta, fresh basil, and balsamic dressing. It's simple, but the flavors and textures worked together in a surprising way.

For our entrees. I had the ayacucho, a combination of quinoa cakes, fresh avocado, grilled mahi mahi, and a sauce that tasted a little like romesco. My hot date had the havana, a Cuban fried rice dish with black beans, plantains, and steak all mixed in together. Both were really damn  satisfying. After dessert (alas, the only drawback: the offer only gelato and sorbet for post-dinner sweetness) and coffees, we had reached the perfect level of fullness.

So. To review: Cute, great staff, a bargain (you could eat here for under $10), completely devoid of pretension, and delicious.
author: Ben P.

description: Finally tried this place. The atmosphere is great and it is a nice place to bring a date.  Small and cozy.  I highly recommend it!
author: Vinh N.

description:
This place is definitely cute. 

Cute Cute Cute.

It's got everything you'd want from a small, San Francisco bistro-style restaurant.  It seats about 18 people total, the menu changes seasonally, and it's moderately priced.  That being said.. I just don't think the food here is that great.  It's not BAD, but I don't understand why people think it's so good.  Sorry y'all.  I take my noodles seriously, and the noodles they served here were just ok.  I like my noodles more chewy and "bouncy" but these were more doughy and just.. not the best i've had.  Also the flavors here are more subtle (i.e. bland) and I'm into big, in-your-face flavor.  I believe years of mercilessly destroying my tastebuds with tabasco, sriracha, and jalepenos will do that to you.  

...but at least it's cute.  The end.
author: William S.

description:
That does it.  I've put off writing this review for long enough.  I hemmed and hawed for ages.  On the one hand Pomelo is excellent, and exactly the type of place that deserves good reviews.  On the other hand, now you will all know about this place that's not as much of a place as a wonderfully-kept secret.

Okay, it has enough reviews that it really can't qualify as a secret.  But when you're in Pomelo it really feels like your restaurant, and no one else's.  One would think that's mostly owing to the fact that there's only room for about a dozen people.  But it's more than that.  The lights are low, you can see your food being prepared, and while you realize you're effectively stuffed like a sardine into a setting that's probably best compared to a diner, you don't really care.  I just haven't experienced that type of intimacy from any other restaurant, and it makes it my go-to place when my boyfriend and I want a date night.  But heck, you could even go by yourself!  It's small enough that the stigma of dining alone is no longer applicable.

What's more, I like the food even better than I like the ambiance.  It's a noodle house, only all growed up.  For those of us who like some starch with our starch and a side of rice, this premise is really rather ingenious.  It's listed as Asian fusion, but I think of it more as a multi-cultural noodle adventure.  Mexican, Italian, French, and Asian flavors mingle quite amicably on Pomelo's menu.  And while they're each saying "Pick me, pick me!" they assemble more in harmony than in competition.  Because the ingredients are fresh and local, the menu tends to vary.  But the most recent thing I've loved is the cold soba salad.  I'm a sucker for cold soba despite its lack of authenticity, and Pomelo really delivers.  The dressing is nuanced and not too salty, and it was the most refreshing thing I've put in my body in quite a while.  I also had a pasta featuring shrimp, goat cheese, and a vinaigrette, and it was delicious.  It's seasonal, so you'll want to keep an eye out for it if you're a fan of goat cheese.  My boyfriend, however, would be woeful if I did not mention the fish and quinoa cakes.  It seems to be a staple, and with good reason.  They cook their fish to perfection, and the quinoa cakes are wonderfully moist and pop in that way that only quinoa can do.

I know I mentioned the fresh ingredients, but Pomelo is also to be lauded for their portion sizes.  They're smaller, and I really love that - but not so small you feel like you're being cheated.  Only small enough that you feel care was put into your individual dish.  What I may like best about Pomelo is that you get food that (to me) feels very upscale for prices that are just a teensy bit upscale.  You get the fresh and healthy food without any snobbery, and you get a truly intimate (almost underground) ambiance without any intimidation.  What's not to love?  Yeah, that's what I thought.
author: Becca S.

description:
Why does this place succeed while the place in my last review fails?

http://www.yelp.com/biz/typhoon-restaurant-santa-monica#hrid:BWy55CTqyuaGMh8e6qWUYA

Typhoon = A gaggle of cheap Las Vegas hookers dressed up in "exotic oriental garb"

Pomelo = A bevy of beautiful hapa babies...

Basically, the former steals from its Asian cultures and presents poor facsimiles of native dishes.  The latter is very much informed by its mother cultures but still develops its own unique and individual cuisine. In the minefield that is "Asian Fusion," I'm glad to see that Pomelo manages to find the right path.
author: A J.

description:
I really wanted to like this in the four or five star range.  A friend suggested we go, so I perused the menu online at my office instead of doing my real work.  I had trouble choosing which selection I would order because all looked delicious.

The noodle dish with seared ahi tuna was just okay.  It didn't live up the giant expectations I had created with my day long menu reading orgy.  They were nicely salty/sweet with a touch of ginger, and would have been a four star meal if the plate of food had cost $10 or less.  (I paid $20 with tax and tip.)  Perhaps, the lunch menu is more reasonable.

The place is also tiny.  While walking by on previous occasions, I had assumed that there was a back room or something.  Nope.  There are three tables for two, and one is pushed right up in the mugs of the folks next to you.  So if you want to talk about sex or divorce, this is not your venue.  There are also several seats at a bar, but I generally don't enjoy bar seating because you have to twist yourself all around sideways to see your companion.  And I'm too old for that crap.

Parking is very tough because UCSF is just up the hill.  It's on the busline, so I recommend leaving your car at home.
author: Bert M.

description:
Did you know that the pomelo is the largest citrus fruit?  That the grapefruit is a cross between a pomelo and an orange?  
Neither did I-thanks Wikipedia!
Pomelo also happens to be a damn good restaurant located in the inner Sunset.  We tried six different items this evening and there wasn't a loser in the bunch...everything was fresh, tasty and most importantly healthy.  I'll definitely be back to try more of the menu.
author: phil h.

description:
Here is your assignment:
1. Go to Pomelo. Take the N Judah. Love MUNI.
2. Order a glass of wine. It's cheap and yummy.
3. Start with the garlicy Baby Bok Choy. One order per person. You will eat it all. If you're feeling salad-y, the pomelo is delish and big enough for two.
4. Go with the Havana entree. This dish will fill you with awkwardly pleasant feelings. You may become aroused. Go with it.
5. Finish with the duo of sorbets. You will be tempted to eat the tangy raspberry and rich cocoa (complete with nibs) separately. This is WRONG. Eat them together. You will understand. 
6. Pay your bill and get on with your bad self. Your new magical powers will wear off eventually.
author: Autumn K.

description:
Pomelo is close by so we go on occasion because it is convenient and cozy.   They have a nice wine list and an intimate yet casual atmosphere.  That said, this quaint little spot is not necessarily a place I would come to if I lived out of the neighborhood.   

Generally, I am satisfied with my food there, but not overjoyed.  There are a few great dishes at this place, including the Gilroy (garlicky bok choy), the Korean pancakes (packed with multiple flavors), and the buckwheat noodle salad ( refreshing if you want a simple, tasty cold dish.)   However, I find that a few of their signature dishes, such as the Havana and the Lanzou noodle dish, quite frankly, taste very similar.  It's  as though they take the garlicky oil used for the Gilroy bok choy and used it to toss the beans and rice in the Havana, and then used a similar 'sauce' for the Lanzou noodle dish.  The result tends to be plates that lack dimension and are heavy-handed with oil.  I may be too particular, but I dont think the savory, rosemary/thyme  chicken on the beet salad should be the same chicken served on the Havana, a cuban inspired dish.  And no, I don't think it is the sake of 'fusion' - if it is, they should note that "grilled rosemary herb chicken" will be added on top.

If you like garlic and arent too finicky about sophisticated flavor in your food, I think you will enjoy it.  The dishes are well over satisfactory and they fill you up - definitely a result of the great quantities of rice or noodles and not due to the amount of protein (meat lovers should dine elsewhere, as they will be disappointed by the disproportionate amount of meat to carbs on their plate).

It would be great to see them fine tune their sauces and use of fresh herbs, and work out their ratios of protein/veg/carb to make more multi-dimensional food.  Until then, we will probably still be going!  It's close by and we support our local businesses.
author: Ki W.

description:
We stopped in for a bite to eat before seeing our friend who was recovering at UCSF. 

I ordered the soba noodles with tofu and my husband order the Havana(Cuban rice dish with beef). We started with the Palermo, their fig appetizer.

Food was good, although I think that I like the food at the Church street location a bit better. The service was prompt, which was important to us, because we didn't want to miss visiting hours at the hospital. Good place to pick up a quick bite to eat and not have to compromise on quality.

Oh! and this place is pretty tiny. Although...it is pretty entertaining to sit at the counter and watch the chef cook up your dinner and put out small kitchen fires!
author: Caroline C.

description:
When you feel like you can't take one more day of the perpetual gray skies and blustery winds that plague the inner sunset, I recommend you head to Pomelo.  

The mere act of stepping through the door will cure the seasonal affective disorder you're bound to have developed from dealing with the god forsaken weather in this otherwise delightful neighborhood.  With its bright green walls and tiny size, Pomelo is an oasis of warmth and charm. 

Start with the Gilroy and feel your strength returning as the deceptively simple bok choy with garlic hits your belly and begins to fight off the cancer you're sure you're going to get one day. 

Follow it up with the Havana and feel the Caribbean sun wash over you as your taste buds delight in the perfect balance of tender juicy skirt steak atop rice with plantains and black beans, and a scoop of some avocado based stuff that complements the beef perfectly.

Delight in the sub-Hamilton cost for this finely prepared mental and physical recharge and venture out the door temporarily blissfully oblivious to the damp, cold, gray you live in.
author: Eli B.

description: I love Pomelo!  I used to live in Cole Valley when we'd eat here once a week.  Recently went back when we were in the hood, and it is as good as ever.  It's amazing they can serve such a diverse menu w/ such a TINY kitchen.  YUM
author: Melanie C.

description:
I fell head over heels in love with Pomelo last night. I don't normally give 5 stars to places after a first visit... but I'm in love, and we do crazy things when we're in love. 

Three stars for a great atmosphere and great food. It is the cutest, tiniest place I've ever seen. Not a place for a group bigger than two or three. From the counter (I love counters), I could see every ingredient that went into my meal and every slice, dice and stir the chef, alberto, made.

The menu changes every few months. I experienced the "early fall" menu with dishes featuring mushrooms, figs and truffle oil. Alberto told me that the menu was changing tomorrow. In fact, I saw him preparing some chicken breast in a marinade of fresh rosemary and garlic for the next day. One extra star. 

My date and I finished our meal and wine around closing time when alberto was making himself dinner. He actually made us little bowl of his pork stew, just to let us taste it. 

I think Pomelo loves me too. One more star.
author: Kathryn T.

description:
This is fine dining without the attitude/tiny portions/overpriced menus.  We've been here twice now and had a great experience both times.

The place is small, and you can watch the chefs prepare your food if you like.  

Last night we ordered
Havana - an absolutely delicious Cuban dish
Kandy - a hearty Sri Lankan chicken curry
Gilroy - bok choy appetizer

It left us feeling warm and nourished.
author: Chris Q.

description:
Calling the original Pomelo on Judah a restaurant is a bit of a stretch, as it's more like a glorified lunch counter or an over-sized coat closet.  The place seats less than 20, and more than half of those are counter seats.  This is not a place for the claustrophobic.

The menu at Pomelo is imaginative, featuring fresh and economical fusion food that is endearing to both palate and wallet.  Most entrees are served over a grain-based foundation (e.g. udon, rice noodles, quinoa), and are clever if not revolutionary combinations of fresh and largely organic ingredients.  My recent meal there included the Pomelo salad, which is your basic field greens and goat cheese salad, but had a delightful accent of fresh, sweet peach.  The Sonoma entree was a good representation of the larger selection, bucatini pasta tossed with heirloom tomatoes that had been sauteed with balsamic vinegar, and topped with basil and tiger prawns.  Everything was terrific.

If you're going to dine in a restaurant as small as Pomelo, you might as well take a counter seat overlooking the kitchen.  There you'll see every step of your meal's preparation, and the cook in return will get to hear every word of your conversation.  That's kind of the fun of Pomelo -- the intimacy between staff and patrons, and if you're OK with that,  you'll do just fine.
author: Hugh B.

description:
I *really* wanted to give this place 5 stars. If I had ordered a little differently, I think I would have. Their menu looks amazing, and I will definitely be coming back to try more of their dishes! The "havana" was outstanding - cuban fried rice with skirt steak and avocado salad. This dish did not disappoint in the least, I highly recommend it! The "lanzhou" was, much to my dismay, a bit disappointing. It is an egg noodle dish topped with seared ahi - the noodles were sooooo good, but the ahi was remarkably bland. Maybe it was just a bad fish, but I think it was actually just a little over-seared... it somehow lost it's usual flavor, and the texture was a little too rough. Plus, there was a sauce on top of it that was just plain weak. I was sad =(

At any rate, overall I was pretty satisfied. The place is *beyond* small - but if you come here on a week night this makes for a really neat experience. The dining area is practically IN the kitchen - you can watch your food being made. The smells inside absolutely taunt you while you're waiting for your meal! Great place for a cozy and intimate date. The couple next to us got what I think was the "salon" as a starter - I think I will try this next time, it smelled amazing.

I will definitely be back!
author: Ben Y.

description: Really yummy, limited seated, but wonderful staff. Sit on the bar seats so u can watch the chef in action. Seen both chefs and tried almost all of the menu and they are very consistent and always tummy!!!
author: Richard G.

description:
Hands down my favorite every day lunch spot. Love the counter seats where you get to watch them make your lunch. The host is so nice and remembers what I like to drink (and eat) every time I go in.  My favorite things to order are: 

A) the most outrageous and best polenta I have ever had in my life.  comes with a sauce you just want to drink straight from the plate and/or take home.

b) Lanzhou is my go to entree every time. I cannot get myself to order anything else. (I have tried 4 other entrees and they are awesome, but this is my favorite).

c) Green tea ice cream with white chocolate chips.  Perfect ending to a perfect meal.
author: Veronica P.

description:
Last Thursday night, a girlfriend and I had a great time having dinner at Pomelo.  (Note: We had a window seat which gave us the opportunity to people watch some cute men in scrubs walking by....)

We had many creative and flavorful combinations to chose from. We decided to share a few dishes so that we could taste more of them! My friend is only eating fish or veggie dishes nowadays, which helped us to narrow down our options. (Although some of the chicken or steak dishes sounded tempting!) 
We shared a salad that was just right with mixed greens, goat cheese, and dried cranberries, accompanied with a light citrus vinaigrette and some fresh bread.  Next we moved onto the fish tacos appetizer which came with 2 tacos with red snapper, fresh salsa, avocado, and jalapenos on the side. MM-mm- those were tasty! 

Finally, our main dish was delicious we had the Ayacucho: a fish of day (that was a Hawaiian fish that I had never heard of before) with a spicy red sauce, and these great, light, crispy quinoa cakes (battered w/egg and breadcrumbs, and some cheese). 
Ah, I savored the taste of each wonderful bite. 

I had a nice $7 glass of Malbec with my meal.

We had such a great time talking and sharing these dishes, and we enjoyed every sip and every bite.  I'm sure it's a great date place, and it's great for girlfriends, too!
author: Amy J.

description: Tried the ayacucho here with mahi mahi. Mahi mahi was cooked a bit rare...not sure if this is common. The quinoa cakes were the best part of this dish! Great tasting dish but wasn't filled up at the end. Wish the portion was bigger. My friends who got havana really loved it and were super full so this may be the better dish to pick if you are starving. And another friend got a weekend special that was fish with risotto. He said the risotto is the best he's ever had.
author: Liwei Y.

description:
I was recently taken out to dinner by someone who has read all of my Yelp reviews.  Figuring that he must know what I like, I let him pick the restaurant.  He chose Pomelo, a tiny restaurant in the Sunset that I had never heard of.  He chose well (and he didn't even cheat and use my bookmarks)!

I wish I could say exactly what we ate, but I didn't take notes and apparently you need access to an IT Help Desk if you try to open their online menu (or maybe that's just me).  We shared a variety of dishes - a salad, a fish taco-like appetizer, and two other dishes.  I realize that not remembering the names of what we ate makes this review a lot less useful, but honestly, I think it would be very hard to go wrong in this place.  I'll bet you're likely to get a great meal here no matter what you order.

This place is tiny, but that adds to the charm.  We sat at the counter as diners came and went and the chef put on a show as he worked in the open kitchen.  Friendly service, and we weren't rushed at all.
author: DD B.

description:
18 seats?  You got to be kidding me.  I think i only counted like 10!  As they all say: tiny tiny tiny.  Apparently you can usually find a spot to sit at but it is probably a hit-or-miss kind of thing.  Still if you get in, try to sit at the "bar" so you can watch the lone chef prepare your meal.  Really, it's amazing what he can do with a tiny rangetop and grill.  Prices are about average for a good meal ($15-$25) if you include a single drink, tack on maybe $8 for an appetizer.  Seriously, though, it's worth it.  I had a Lanzhou (seared rare peppered ahi tuna over garlic noodles) and aside from being a bit strong on the pepper it was wonderful.

Check out their website and menus to get a better idea.

Times visited: 1
author: Amy L.

description:
How I love Pomelo.  Let me count the ways:

I love it because it's tiny.
I love it because there is just one man making food.
I love it because you can sit at the counter without feeling like you are sitting at the counter.
I love it because it's like a little hidden gem in the midst of chaos.
I love it because after dinner you can walk to Park Chow for Ginger Cake  with Pumpkin Ice Cream.  Even in the Summer.
I love it because you get a big bowl of steamy noodles or rice covered in delicious, fragrant curry.
I love it because it's where my favorite girls meet more often than not for dinner.
I love it because I almost always order the same thing and it's almost always perfect.
I love it because on Jeopardy last night one of the answers was a Pomelo and I knew it because of this restaurant.

9 reasons.  That'll do it.
author: Rachel G.

description: For those with more than $5 to spend on lunch, sick of burritos, indian and sushi, or folks who enjoy seasonal, creative food near the UCSF campus, Pomelo is your place. The menu is constantly changing so my peanut sauced seafood dish probably isn't there anymore, though I'm not there anymore, either.  Pomelo has two locations and is cute and it even turned me on to the fruit, which at the time was new to me!
author: Kat T.

description:
Great little Asian mix place that covers all the bases on Asian cuisine. Whatever you are in the mood for, your Asian taste will be satisfied. I had the Havana (Cuban style fried rice with plantains, black beans, ginger and cilantro with skirt steak) and it rocked! It was also portioned right. My wife and daughter shared the Pomelo (salad with persimmons, almonds, shaved parmesan and balsamic vigaigrette) with the Manila (Fiiipino style pancit rice noodle salad with prawns, chicken, chinese sausage and vegetables). Hers was ok.
Parking was more tolerable than the main drag on Irving which lead to a nice dinner outing. Don't go with a big group, as the place only has 2 tables plus window seating (4 seats) and a main counter of about 8.
author: Mark M.

description:
Every time we come here we have a good cozy experience. The eclectic menu covers a broad range of Asian, European and a bit of Latin influence, which I would describe as gourmet California comfort food. Everything from the beef stew to seared scallops, mahi mahi with quinoa cakes, trout crostini and mushroom polenta was very good, well worth a few extra bucks as compared to the many cheaper neighborhood alternatives. The wine list is brief but I found some good options, like a good 2004 Barbera for around $20 that matched just about anything.

The major drawback is that the space is so small -- seriously, the smallest sit-down restaurant I've ever been to -- that you may end up waiting for a bit. Outside. The rewards is that, if you're seated at the counter, you can watch the two-man crew work their magic in the closet-sized exhibition kitchen.
author: Tom L.

description: Think about a place like Olive Garden.  The menu is boring.  Everything is pre-prepared.  Service sucks.  Ambience is non-existent.  And worst of all, the food is bland and gross.  Now imagine Pomelo...it is the exact opposite.  Do yourself a favor and go.  BTW, took a ~6 year gap between visits since I moved out of town and it's even better than I remember.
author: Sam C.

description:
Can fusion food be delicious? Sometimes, yes! I would describe the food here as a mix of  Pan (but mostly Southeast) Asian and Latin flavors/styles. I made my first visit here on Friday night, at around 9:30pm just as a table was being vacated. We were famished after attending the de Young museum event and decided to come here for a late dinner.

It's a teeny, tiny restaurant (similar in seating to Cordon Bleu on California near Polk St.) - mostly counter seating and only 3 small tables. The tight restaurant space is very efficiently used and cleverly laid out.

We had the skirt steak (per recommendation of other Yelpers here), the day's fish special (corvina) and the Nuoro (grilled chicken breast). All of the dishes were tasty, full of flavor, made with fresh ingredients. Really liked the watermelon and roasted beets in our Nuoro dish - the chicken was just okay. The skirt steak was very tender, medium rare and the fish was cooked perfectly - not under or (gasp!) over done. The cab was good - first one on the wine list.

The waiter (owner?) gave attentive service and the 3 of us managed to eat our meal on our small table! We didn't care because the food with the mix of interesting flavors and textures, along with the conversation, distracted us from the cramped eating quarters! 

Total for our 3 dishes and glass of wine: $60. Portions are decent, too. Recommended.. but go outside the regular dining hours or it'd be a long wait.
author: Everso T.

description:
I know I shouldn't have had high expectations for the Havana dish, considering that this is a fusion restaurant, but the skirt steak wasn't even a skirt steak. I'm trying very hard not to compare this cuban dish to the dishes I had at Versailles in Miami, but the rice was tangy (is moros rice supposed to be tangy?). I was expecting the plantains to be sweet and fried, but they were just chopped up and mixed in with the rice - a healthier alternative but I didn't care to be healthy that day. And I think putting ginger in the dish was just a bad idea. Don't get me wrong. It was good, but I'm just painting a really bad picture because I was expecting more. Expecting it to taste like good cuban food .. or remotely cuban for that matter.
The avocado salad was delicious though.
author: Anvy A.

description:
I came to Polemo with an open mind and an empty stomach ready to be impressed. Pomelo serves seasonal dishes so their selection isn't grand but decent. I can't wait to try other dishes. I had the Havana which came with Cuban fried rice, skirt steak (still redish), and avacado. I was impressed. I loved it and my tummy was so full! one of my friends had the Lanzhou (egg noodle with ahi tuna) which was tasty but not very exciting. my other friend had the Koh Samui which was a spicy coconut dish that had absolutely tender chicken, but what made the dish stand out was the splash of lime, so refreshing! I forgot the 4th dish but it was savory.

So remember the menu changes season to season (or probably when ever their supplies change) and seating is very limited. Pomelo is casual and small 
(so small that my slow friend (i kiddin :0) accidentally turn of their lights TWICE!!. There are two tables (one is a two seater and the other four) the other remaining seats are counter stool seats (about 7-8 facing the open kitchen and four facing the window. 

it's best to make reservations bcus of the limited seats. and it's definitely not for large groups.
author: Lynn T.

description: Possibly my favorite restaurant in the city!  You can't go wrong with the friendly staff, the small cozy atmosphere (even if you have to wait) and the staples on the menu!  I love the Lanzhou with Ahi and the Koh Samui Curry with Chicken or Prawns.  The staff is always happy to make substitutions.   I cannot believe that other reviews call this place overpriced and the portions small.  I find it exactly the opposite--cheap with huge portions.
author: Katharine A.

description:
It's pretty hard to miss Pomelo off Judah since there's actually a large pomelo fruit hanging over it's front door. I've been wanting to try the place ever since I noticed it.

Yesterday, I finally did.

Like other reviews have noted, Pomelo is tiny! But, the fact that it's cute and cozy makes up for it. From what I gathered, the place consists of 2-3 dining tables, a window ledge for eating (and for people watching!), and a bar that wraps around the kitchen. In addition to that, the place is pretty minimalist. Yeah, there's a lot of birch...and if I remember correctly, fresh flowers. I'd say it's perfect for catching up with a friend, family member (a cousin in my case), or a date. Despite being packed on a Tuesday around 8pm, it was easy to carry on conversation without having to shout over the people sitting beside me. My cousin and I also sat at the bar - watching the chef cook our meals was an added touch.

Food-wise, I honestly thought Pomelo was just okay. Since I was feeling a bit under-the-whether and wanted something soothing, I ordered the persian noodle and bean soup. Although the waiter said this dish was full of complex flavors, everything tasted sorta bland about a quarter into the soup. I'll give it credit for having interesting texture though - you can't get around them chickpeas. 

My cousin had the seared rare ahi tuna atop a bed of egg noodles. The noodles were fresh, but had no flavor to them...and the ahi tuna wasn't memorable. Sorry.

Sadly, I'm not sure if I'd go back to Pomelo for dinner - mayyyybe once the menu changes or if they ever decide to lower their prices (doubt it). I'm still up for brunch at the Noe restaurant though. Can't hurt =)
author: Gina L.

description: Everything on the menu is good, you can't really go wrong. Great place to have a meal with one other person or just yourself. Restaurant is tiny and the best seats are right by the "bar" like area that overlook the chefs. Nothing beats watching your food being cooked and chatting it up with the friendly chefs. Prices are slightly on the high side and if you're with a large group, you might want to call ahead to see if they can fit you all in. If you call in for take out, your order is ready in the time promised. Walking distance to UCSF if you are visiting someone in the hospital.
author: Nate B.

description:
Pomelo offers really good, fresh food.  They have stuff for meat eaters and vegetarians.  i've never disliked anything I've had here.

The chef is great.  And he has a sense of humor.  We were there recently and there was this drunk woman sitting at the bar. The more she drank the louder she was (duh).  Anyway, she asking the chef what he was making and if it had garlic in it.  The chef was sweet and patient with her while turning out yummy food at the same time.

We went the other night and the service was short and kind of rude.  In all fairness, I've been before and he was fine.  Maybe he was having a bad night.  

Go on a weeknight unless you mind the wait.  And it's best for parties of 4 or less-2 is ideal.
author: T M.

description:
Pomelo is simply fantastic.  Limited seating makes for an intimate experience.  The kitchen is wide open so you can sit at the service bar and watch your meal be prepared. 

The food is wonderful.  Asian fusion and super fresh orgainc produce.  Take a trip here and you will not be disapointed.
author: Ben V.

description:
What's this now? My favorite wine EVAR at $5.50 a glass?! Dude, 4-stars for that ALONE. Ya, that's right. Pomelo is getting 4 stars for having Pomelo wine (shocking, I know) not only on the menu but also at a ridiculously affordable price. Period. End.

No, not really...I mean, look at my quote. Could I really write a restaurant review without addressing the food? No. Honestly--and sadly, because I desperately want to LOVE this place--the two dishes I've had were just a bit off. Not in a "rotten" way or anything. More like flavor/texture issues. Dish one was the soba noodle salad. Textures were good, but the flavor was just not right: tart & spicy. Nothing else. Not savory and/or sweet at all, and you really need one of those (if not both) to offset the sourness and spiciness of the dish. Dish two was the ahi tuna with udon noodles (lazhou, I think). Flavors were very tasty--heavy on the ginger and garlic, but I like that. However, the buttery texture of the very deliciously fresh tuna just didn't meld well with the thick chewiness of the noodles. I had to eat them separately. I might try it again if I can substitute steak or tofu.

So am I really going to stick to 4-stars? Shit yes, I am! Did you not listen to (er, read) my wine rant? POM-EL-O bitches. Yum. Oh yeah, and the chef and server are super friendly and speedy, the place is super cute (READ: TINY) and perfect for date night, the ingredients are VERY fresh, and the boy has always cleaned his plate. He gets the havana and I can attest it's very good. And it's affordable. 

P.S. Corkage is around $12, I think. But, honestly, why on earth would you want to bring your own wine!? ;)
author: Jasmine F.

description:
I really like this joint.  I've been there a few times and it is consistently good.

Pomelo serves tasty food that takes influences from all sorts of cuisines (southeast asian, cuban, japanese, italian, california-style).  The menu changes seasonally but a few favorites are permanently on the menu.  Portions are good and the prices are decent.  My favorite dish is the Havana.  Cuban style fried rice with black beans, plantains and steak.  I'm drooling as I type.

The restaurant only has space for about 15 people, with half of the seats at the counter (where you can watch your food being prepared!).  Personally, I like the coziness.  

I only have two little complaints.  The seats are not the most comfortable and the combination of small space, open kitchen and weak ventilation system means that I often exit Pomelo smelling of Pomelo.
author: Emily L.

description:
I went here last week and really liked everything about this place.  The size was cozy and intimate, there's a small bar area where you can see the cooks preparing everything, the service was friendly, and the food came out pretty quickly.  I was here for a date and thought this was an excellent date spot -- the coziness makes it really easy to have a conversation, the music is truly in the background and mellow, and the prices are really reasonable for the portion size.

I had the basil pasta with zucchini and grilled shrimp.  The shrimp were fantastic.  Juicy, succulent, and flavorful.  My date had the mahi mahi and quinoa cakes which were so good that let's just say I almost ate his food and mine that night.  Luckily he didn't mind :~)  All of the menu items sounded like fabulous creations, so I'd definitely like to go back and try something new.
author: LaSha G.

description:
Fun little place for lunch. 

The food was fresh... quick... and delicious. 

This place is adorable, small, and quick with eclectic cuisine with a hefty bit of Californian cuisine influence. 

The staff is friendly and knowledgeable, the food is tasty, and with the two of us being in and our in 45 min... was a great little lunch!
author: Jordan Y.

description: very cute place. i wish i had the time to sit in last time i went. i got the lanzhou and i was happy with it. the tuna was delicious but i just hoped they would have given me more noodles.
author: Louis O.

description: Loved this cute little restaurant. Perfect place for a date. The dishes had beautiful presentation and had much more food than we expected! Food  was also prepared very quickly! The three of us girls ordered 3 entrees to share, and we tried our best to finish but just couldn't. I would definitely suggest ordering one less entree than the number of people you have and get an appetizer instead. Planning to share dishes family style is also a good idea because each dish is so flavorful that eating one dish by yourself may be a bit overwhelming. It would be a waste not to sample the eclectic variety of dishes by sharing! We ended up spending $20 a person after tax and tips but was well worth it.
author: Erika C.

description:
Had a really nice, satisfying lunch of Otsu, a vegetarian dish of soba noodles and tofu. It had a nice balance between the cold, tangy, slightly spicy noodles and the warm, almost meaty just sauteed tofu.

Pomelo's a sweet little place that I look forward to visiting again.
author: Ben S.

description:
Picking a place to dine for the first time is a difficult task.  Whatever you choose, it's going to reflect on who you are.  And, it'll also reveal who you believe she is. And, it's complicated by wanting to show the best in you both.

Pomelo fit the bill. It's unpretentious. Friendly, intimate, and very good.

I've been before, but this was a special occasion. This was with someone special.

We started with the Pomelo salad: lettuces, raspberries, hazelnuts, goat cheese, perfectly dressed with a light vinaigrette. Easily enough for two. Cabo San Lucas fish tacos followed this: snapper, corn tortillas, mango salsa and picked peppers. Two to share. Generous helpings for an appetizer. For our main, we split the Ayacucho. Quinoa cakes (who can pronounce this correctly??) with a nice size piece of fish. An ancho chili and roasted red pepper sauce was everywhere with onions and avocado.

Gluttony got the better of me and we ordered the Aosta: baked polenta with mushrooms and a cream sauce. It's a delicious dish but too much for us to finish.

Lingering for a couple of hours in this tiny place (seats for 18?) didn't bother the staff of three: waiter, chef, bus. Sitting at the counter we watched the performance art of cooking as the wave of happy diners ebbed and flowed.

Having been before, I knew what to expect from the food. I just didn't know what to expect from the meal. A great place to begin a wonderful night.
author: Dave B.

description: Went in late on a Friday night and got seats very quickly. Tiny place but it had a nice ambiance. Ordered the Bormio, which was pretty bland, but not bad. Everyone else in the group seemed to have a similar experience (pretty spicy, but not bad, etc.). The waiter we had was a little rude. He hassled us about splitting the check when the time came, even though he'd approved it before we ordered-- one of our party had to pay for someone else's meals because he didn't want to split it. This restaurant is not friendly for groups bigger than two people. Won't be coming back.
author: Kim K.

description:
Going there is always a lesson in 'cool'.  They play cool music, their business card and signage is super-cool.  Everything there is tasteful, no pun intended.

Their whole concept is cool - each dish is named for a city - the Phillipino dish is the 'Manila', the Cuban dish is the 'Havana', etc.  The offerings change on a regular basis, but a few favorites remain.

Most important, the food is delicious!  The dishes are healthy, tasty, and elegant - they look like a work of art (eating is destroying).  The prices are incredibly low for the quality - they could easily double them and nobody would bat an eye.

The Inner Sunset location is very small - seats about 15 people.  They don't take reservations, but I've been pretty lucky.  Forget about large parties though.

It's worth waiting a few minutes to sit at the bar, so you can watch the cook working his magic.  If they're busy and you don't want to wait, there are several other great places to eat a couple blocks away on 9th Ave.

The Noe Valley location is more spacious and the food was just as good, but it lacks the intimate feel of the Inner Sunset location (props for maintaining quality as they expand - too many restaurants lose their touch as they get bigger).

I almost didn't write a review because I don't want this place to get too popular, but these guys deserve all the success they can get - they've done everything right.  Hopefully they'll open another location. Downtown?
author: Loren E.

description:
walked by this hidden little gem and decided to give it a try spontaneously. the environment feels like an extended bar area centered on someone's home kitchen and I could see the chef busy flipping my food in the wok. very intimate dinning experience. 

the very intermixed fusion menu provides dishes from all over the world - from Philippine, Chinese, Indonesia, to Cuban and more. We ordered southern Italian style lamb stew and egg noodles with beef and prawns. Both had very authentic flavors from their regions. the serving size was just enough. 

I would definitely go back!
author: Penfan S.

description:
Lunch was great good food, good company. The restaurant was very crowed. 

I had the: 
barinas
pabellon criollo - venezuelan slow cooked pulled beef with
black beans, garlic rice and fried plantains
author: Martha M.

description:
Pomelo is such a cute and quaint restaurant. Not many seats and they don't take reservations. If you sit at the bar, which basically looks into the small kitchen, it's fun because you get to see what the chef is doing to your food! We both tried the catch of the day, which was Ono, paired with quinoa cakes and accented with a sauce of chili powder. The fish was cooked well and the quinoa cakes were ok, but the sauce was overpoweringly "chili" flavored and killed the flavor of the fish. And the quinoa cakes fell apart when cut into. It would have been nice with a crusty sear on the outside and I expected it to stay together more when being cut into. 

For the price and the atmosphere, this place is a gem. Even though I wasn't thrilled with my entree that night, I plan on returning to try the other delicious appearing menu items.
author: Foodie F.

description:
I had lunch here with a coworker and ordered this thing I couldn't pronouce.  It was the spicy curry with chicken and green beans.  I ordered the lunch portion to get a small salad with it.  When the food arrived, smaller portion was still a HUGE portion to me.

I got there at 1pm and lucky for me there were 2 seats, but the last several times I came there was no seating.  It's a very small restaurant and definately not a place for groups.

Yeah for Pomelo!
author: A L.

description:
Food: I've tried the Otsu here which was very unique but good! I added a grilled chicken breast to it which made it even better. A nice, light dish.

Price: Not bad, lunch is around $10 and up and dinner goes up by $3-4 per person.

Location: Right near UCSF. Street parking available.

Service: Friendly!

Atmosphere: A very small restaurant. Kind of reminds me of a kitchen. You can sit around and watch the chef cook and there are maybe 3 or 4 other seating areas around.
author: Miss H K.

description:
Setting: Cute and cozy
Waiter: Nice and friendly
Food: Definitely Below average

We tried the lanzhou, a dish with chinese noodles and tuna (?!) with a garlic ginger sauce. The noodles completely overpower the over-cooked tuna and the whole thing was a mismatch of tastes... My bf had the muravera, a bland mismatch of shrimp and couscous.

I'll give it another try since so many people recommend it, but our first meal there was not a success.
author: Didi R.

description:
Delicious, use in-season veggies and close to my pad.  Everything I have ordered has been awesome!

My only gripe is that I was having a work party and ordered the curry chicken dish (so good) and the container it was in fell apart sending the sauce spilling all over my kitchen floor.

I managed to save enough of it so I could enjoy my dinner.

I called the manager and he apologized, said that this had never happened in 10 years (I find that hard to believe since we had 2 orders of it and the other container seemed like it was about to bust open as well from the hot sauce) and told me to mention my name next time I come in so that he could hook me up.

I have been in since and no, I didn't mention my name at the door to get  hooked up.  After all, I wasn't trying to get a free meal by reporting it, I just didn't want anyone to burn themselves or end up licking their din din from the floor.
author: Amireh G.

description: I have pretty much always had the havana, which is very good, from the avocado salad to the plantains and black beans in the rice to the grilled onions on top. On the other hand, the steak can be fairly variable both in quality and the cooking. The servings are large, but even with that in mind I think it's overpriced. When I tried the lanzhou it was too salty. In the past I generally found it to be too crowded to go to for lunch after noon, but recently I've seen fewer people in there, so maybe it's not such an issue now. Regardless, it's uncomfortably small.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Question. 

po-ME-lo? POM-elo? 
po-ME-lo? POM-elo?

What is the frickin pronounciation? 

Whatever it is, it's tasty and good. Pomelos are tasty too.
author: Spratt M.

description: Cute little restaurant. I ordered the havana, and it was DEEELICIOUS. Definitely recommend it. The service was great, and prices were reasonable. It's pretty small though, so I probably wouldn't come here with a big party.
author: Sophia B.

description: I went here after seeing it on Check, Please Bay Area. Haha. I had bread salad and baked polenta. Both were delicious - as were my friends' meals. It's a pretty small place, so it gets crowded. We went late and sat at the bar. That turned out pretty well because we got to watch the chef work (I love that!). Overall, wonderfully fresh and tasty food, seating is a little cramped.
author: Lara C.

description: I loved everything about my dinner at small, dimly lit and cozy Pomelo tonight.. We took a seat at the bar where you could see the chef making everything ; you can also smell everything right as it is being prepared... hmmm... We shared the baby bok choy, it was sauteed in garlic olive oil and chili flakes that gave it a nice and spicy kick - it was perfect. Then we had the lecce which is pasta and panko crusted chicken breast ,garlic, bacon -yummy and huge, as well as the Manila rices noodles with chicken and prawns - also yummy and huge. Looking forward to trying some more dishes here.
author: Chris D.

description: I am really torn with this one.  The inside is cute and quaint.  I really do like coming here for brunch, but that is all the 3 stars are for.  Every other time I have tried coming here, I have been let down.  The place is always packed for brunch, I'm talking a wait, so you kind of get the feeling they just don't put as much love in to the cooking, the rest of the time, because it isn't, ever, as packed.
author: rachel o.

description: Closed for lunch although yelp said it's open... Would be nice if they kept their info up to date.
author: Oren R.

description: The portions are the right size and the food is surprising, though what you order might not be what you would expect, it will definitely be good. It's small and maybe a little cramped depending on your need for personal space, but all in all it was worth it.
author: Nik H.

description:
God, I love this place.  Just a few days back I was having one of "those" days where you just really want to unwind and enjoy some comfort food.  Not wanting to travel far from home we hit up the nearby Pomelo (a stable in our dining out repertoire), and man did it ever deliver.  

Pomelo updates their menu regularly, and one of their new seasonal offerings really hits the mark - the Ferrara: black pepper papardelle with pulled duck and porcini mushrooms.  It was freaking perfect.  It's hard to exactly explain why - but suffice to say I felt a pang of empathy for the food critic in the Ratatouille movie when he tries the the main characters dish at the end of the movie and has all of those flashbacks to when he was a kid stuffing his face with comfort food.  

For more info and a more detailed review check out:
http://eatingthroughsf.blogspot.com/2008/12/pomelo-review.html
author: Matthew H.

description: Really impressed by this cozy little place with great international dishes. Very easy/simple/chill sort of vibe. Quick service too.
author: Omar M.

description: The food was overall fake asian food, or as some like to call it, "asian-fusion." I usually love asian fusion food, but this place didn't know what it was. The food was not inventive, just cliched parts of random asian cuisine. Probably will never go back
author: Tiffany K.

description: I can't believe we just found this place! The food is amazing and the ingredients used taste so fresh. I have like every single thing we have ordered here, but my favorite has to be the panzanella salad made with delicious heirloom tomatoes and crusty bread. I have never had such sweet tomatoes before. They really take great care in selecting the best ingredients that they were their customers. Also, the chicken curry is a must-try!
author: Rachel P.

description:
How small can you get?  About 10 counter spaces, and two tables, that's how.  But as small and cramped as this place is, it serves up delicious comfort food.  You end up in your own little bubble of heaven, even in the crowd.

Appetizers must include Cebu - pork spring rolls with different dipping sauces.  Aosta - baked polenta with a mushroom sauce.

My favorite entree of noodles has to be the Manila.  Deliciously light rice noodles with a mix of veggies, chinese sausage and the perfect squirt of lemon.  Want a rice dish?  Look no further than the Koh Samui.  OMG.  Spicy coconut curry with long beans, mushrooms and chicken.  Served over jasmine rice.

I've resisted the temptation of ordering one entree to go while digging into the other in the restaurant.
author: Denise M.

description:
I can't pronounce anything on the menu here, I think thats the trick to asian fusion. You mix a whole bunch of ethnic ingredients up and make up names to call your dishes, it doesn't matter if it doesn't fit because hey... its fusion. I looked like an idiot when I tried to order and did the annoying thing where you sound it out very slowly and point to the menu at the same time. They should know they make people do this on purpose with the names of their dishes.

I can't even remember what I ordered because of this. Its soooo inefficient that way... isn't it?

Well it was a bowl full of rice with chicken coconut curry infused with lime and ginger and it was so damn tasty. I think it was about $12 and it was so big it fed me twice. 

I still think about it... kind of like a really good memory, food can do that to me.
author: kate r.

description: Pan-fusion, noodlely goodness.   I think I should stop Yelping now, and go grab some Filipino chicken noodle soup ("Zamboanga").
author: Amelyn C.

description: i heart this place!  nice selection of eclectic noodle dishes and a tasty  dish called havana. perfectly seasoned and grilled skirt steak with cuban rice and beans, plantains, and sauteed onions. wow! tiny place on Judah so get there early or be prepared to wait for a spot at the counter.
author: Jeff W.

description: I love Pomelo. It really is a neighborhood gem. Great, creative, wholesome food in a "I've found a cute little spot that no one knows about" kind of place. I brought my mom here this past holiday weekend - for my 1st lunch visit - and we had a fabulous meal. Sat at the counter, watching the cooks concoct and plate beautiful dishes. We both loved our meals - the cuban rice with steak (love the plantains) and the red quinoa with steak. I could've finished no problem but glad to boxed up the rest to take home and enjoy for dinner. Lunch, dinner, a wonderful meal in a cozy and fresh atmosphere. To try the Noe Valley locale next....
author: Deann M.

description:
Now maybe it's because I chose poorly, but the things I ate at this place were very disappointing.  The appetizer was a garlic crustini with ricotta cheese and winter squash.  The squash was cold, bland and not good.  I didn't care for that at all.  My entree was a buckwheat noodle salad with tofu, but it was too spicy and bland at the same time, is that possible?  I am a big fan of noodle salad, and maybe I should have read the menu more carefully, but I thought there would be some other sweet chili/garlic flavors in the dish and there was none.   The restaurant is really to small for my liking and the prices were expensive.  The service was good, but I wasn't wowed by any of the food, which is why I go out to eat in the first place!!  

It's too bad that this was my first time and I didn't like my food, I probably won't be going back, but I'm sure other things on the menu were better than what I had.
author: Gabrielle C.

description:
Pomelo provides the ideal ambiance for a cozy date, with such a small space (seating for about 10), that you can't help but feel a sense of intimacy. I recently went here for a date and since it was a late Sunday dinner, we were the only ones there, and it felt like our own personal restaurant.  What punctuated this cozy kitchen atmosphere was that the cooking was in clear view right behind the bar. 

Food-wise, I wasn't blown away and it was a bit disappointing, especially since I had given it a lot of hype to my date from what my friends had told me.  We got the Cabo fish tacos as an appetizer, and that was pretty good actually. But the entrees were nothing to write home about. We got the Havana which so many Yelpers have raved about, and yes it was good, but I've definitely had better Cuban food.  The steak could've been warmer and more tender.  We also got the Manila, a Filipino pancit noodle dish, which was way too salty. It was as if the chefs were playing tricks on each other and loosened the top of the salt shaker! 

Dessert sort of redeemed Pomelo's, as the mango sorbet and the green tea gelato with white chocolate chunks were amazing. I love green tea everything (except green tea tea...haha) but I never knew it'd be so good with white chocolate. Mmm... 

All in all, I would give Pomelo's another chance, because I saw great potential in the food and the venue is so comfortably cozy. I just hope my date gives me another chance... haha
author: James C.

description:
I had dinner there a few weeks ago.
The food was very good, the prices san francisco but not too bad. The menu was fun and had lots of things I've never seen before. I had the kandy, sri-lankan-style chicken curry with bananas, basil, etc. with fresh shaved coconut.

I would go back there if in the area to taste some of the other fun items.
author: Tom E.

description: This is a great little neighborhood place for dinner.  I've probably eaten here 40 times and maybe had one item I didn't like.  Much of the menu changes to be seasonal, but the Havana and Lanzhou are consistent hits as well the Aosta app.  Its tiny but doesn't seem to get a lot of customers which always makes me nervous.  Its tiny, so obviously not good for groups but a really sweet place for a casual date.  I wish more people would support this place (the one on Judah).
author: Mo P.

description:
Wonderful tasty fusion style food using only the freshest local "in season" produce.  It really does make a difference.  Cute neighborhoods atmosphere, reasonable price.

Although they blend asian flavors with western style food, the taste are never "forced".  I particularly loved the buckwheel noodle with fried tofu on top.
author: matt c.

description:
Wish I could put this place in my pocket and take it with me.

It's small enough I almost could.

Delicious portable dining on the go.

Let's hear it!
author: Geoff W.

description:
I really enjoy eating here.  It's quite small, but that's part of the charm.  I went here with my wife and a friend last night (sat.) and we were one of two tables from 6pm to 8pm.  

The bok choy appetizer simply says, 'sauteed bok choy with pepperoconi flakes.'  Yeah right.  This dish was incredible - cooked just right, garlic-ked to perfection.  It was delicious.

The ginger lemongrass tea has no sugar and we got free refills.  

The staff is always nice and friendly, and modest.
author: Josh F.

description:
