This review would be 5 stars if all I had was the Cuban black beans with the flank steak.  Holy crap was that delicious.  The wine I got with it was particularly tasty, too.  Unfortunately, we also got the Ahi plate, which while the noodles were quite flavorful and tasty, the ahi was limp and pretty bland.  Which is a real shame, because good ahi is one of the reasons I can wake up in the morning.

Tiny place, but not confining.  Waiter was friendly and attentive.  Food came quickly and even though it was busy, they didn't make me feel rushed at all.  Will be going back fo shizzle next time I'm in the area.
author: Robin L.

description:
Came here with a friend, who warned me it was tiny.  But I wasn't expecting only 10 seats.  It's like a little box.  On the upside, it feels very intimate and you can see the chef cooking from all angles.  

The Havana is amazing (see other reviews for a desription).  Great flavors.   I agree with Robin L.  that this is a 5-star dish!  The duck papardelle was less so. . . there was nothing particularly wrong with it, but it just needed a little more punch.  Coming back to the restaurant, I don't know if I could ever be convinced to stray from the Havana! 

I think it's limiting to call this restaurant asian fusion.... it's more like world cuisine, sampling from many different cultures.
author: Lindsay L.

description:
3.5 stars.

i prefer the pomelo in noe (they serve brunch) more than this location but overall, i've enjoyed the meals i've had here. some of the dishes lean more on the sweeter side, but some of the dishes like the soba were pretty solid.  i'm also a sucker for the honey lemonade.
author: Helen T.

description:
Pomelo served our needs in a specific way....wanting a neighborhood place not too casual not too fancy (ok, there's no fancy in the inner sunset). Something not too heavy, not too light. Menu with some asian-flair but not solely Asian. 

It was a very intimate (code for small) location, we got great service, and the meno was diverse and based on fresh ingredients. And, it was very affordably priced (about $48 for 2 of us: 1 sake, 1 wine, 1 salad, 2 entrees, 1 dessert).

I would have chosen 3.5 stars if given the option. My entree was pretty tasty, but my husband's was bland (a chicken & pasta dish with gorgonzola, but didn't have even a hint of gorg).
author: K. T.

description:
I went here because Amy W. recommended it and I was not dissapointed.

I went on a Friday, and while the place is quite small, was seated immediately.

The waiter was friendly and honest with his opinions over the food. I love when waiters will tell you what's good and what isn't. The waiter did that.

The food was quite good, and for the relatively low cost, was definitely a bargain.
author: Eric B.

description:
I love Pomelo; I'm not quite sure why we don't come here as often (although the amount we end up drinking probably has something to do with it).  I love the teeny, cheerful dining room; I love watching the chefs cook from my counter seat; I love the quirky, laid-back service from what always appears to be the only server working the entire restaurant and the dorky-hip clientele drinking their soup with a lone glass of wine and a book.

Favorites: the ayacucho and the verona.  I've never come here for lunch, but those soups look awfully tasty.
author: Jan C.

description:
So my plate was crap, my date's was awesome. Both cost the same, mine was 2/3 the size. Almost the same ingredients, somehow totally different. 

We came here on one of those cold summer days... You know, all we wanted to do was go somewhere warm. We walk into the restaurant and it is like 50*! The whole time I was eating I was alternating hand keeping one under my leg. If anything has kept me from coming back it is this... I do feel it is a nice little spot.

Maybe I will try it again... Maybe she will join me for dinner again... :(
author: Lee M.

description:
Wow. This place is small.

I know that really didn't need to be said, but I just had reiterate what the other yelpers said because i was surprised by how small it actually was when we went inside. We drove by and passed it up accidentally which I'm sure happens quite frequently.

I've been to Pomelo on Church and liked it, so I was eager to compare it with Pomelo on Judah. Besides the square footage being a lot smaller, the menu is the same. But i'd have to say the food at Pomelo on Church is better. Our food didn't seem to be cooked thoroughly or lacked flavor in certain areas. I think it was more the chef and not the dishes, although it was fun watching him cook everything. The food at Pomelo on Judah s average, but what I do like is the variety of ethnic dishes from thai, to filipino, to cuban, to chinese, etc. 

Overall, cute little restaurant for locals but i probably won't be back to this location.
author: Jen Y.

description:
Asian comfort food off Parnassus: My girl friend and I found Pomelo because of the princess parking we found.  Pomelo is adorable.  With mostly bar seating facing the little kitchen or a few stools facing out into the street.  The Mango Citrus Prawn Salad was divine.  The dressing was light and very fresh.  Not alarming or tart.  Then we dived into hearty.  Jen had the seared Ahi Tuna over noodles, but it had a steak and potato comfort food feeling to it.  My Chicken Curry over rice was delicious and filling in a comforting way as well.  Between the Cote de Rhone and the Sake we were well on our way to 4 hours more of studying after a nice little nap.

Pomelo is tiny and adorable and the service is quick and friendly.  Next time I will have the crab egg drop soup and the pancit.
author: Diana L.

description:
Here's a excerpt of what I wrote for Menupages.com (http://blogs.menupages.com/sanfrancisco/2008/07/pomelo_refreshingly_global.html): 

The menu is seasonal, but some of the dishes can be had year round, one of which, the Havana, is our personal favorite. Cuban fried rice, black beans and skirt steak are the main components, but the cilantro, ginger and perfectly sautéed onions give the dish its bold, full flavor. But what really does it for us are the side of plantains and the Cuban avocado salad. The avocado salad is so tangy and refreshing that we've been known to phone in a side order for take out just to have it with a home cooked meal. And besides, when is avocado ever bad?

In terms of space, Pomelo self-describes itself as "intimate, simple and undeniably global" and they definitely know what they're talking about when it comes to intimacy. The Judah location is small, sometimes to a fault, and if all three 2-person tables are occupied in addition to the six or so bar seats it can really heat up. Nonetheless, if it's not too crowded and you're in the mood for casual, yet elegant dining, the ambiance is warm and vibrant. What's more, if you want a little entertainment, sitting at the bar gives you full view of the kitchen and the chef's impressive culinary feats.
author: Alexis W.

description:
I LOVE LOVE LOVE this place! Definitely one of my favorite restaurants in SF. It's so cute and intimate and I love watching the chef (who is absolutely amazing) cook our food. 

I think the owner is also the waiter and he talked to us for a while about how the menu ideas were created. Everything on the menu is so different and interesting with such unique "worldly" flavors. The wine list is excellent too. 

I don't have a bad thing to say about this little hidden sunset treasure (I even like the light fixtures). We usually eat late and stay until they close, enjoying every last bite while watching the 2 guys clean the kitchen. They are EXTREMELY thorough which should make all the germ-a-phobes happy :)
author: Jessica F.

description: Didnt have a really good experience at Pomelo. The food wasn't that great, and the price was a expensive for the quality.
author: Alex L.

description:
Being of the UCSF set, I enjoy sneaking down the street to Pomelo on regular occasion.  The lemon grass ice tea is to die for and really everything on the menu is good.  The place is tiny but since I'm usually here for lunch, I don't mind at all.  The portions are HUGE (for lunch) and the one wait staffer is really nice.

Brava.
author: Kim N.

description:
I'll have to give this little place a second chance, because I could have had a coke and smile and been better off.  I've been meaning to try this location in hopes of finding a new little gem for dinner, but instead I got a plate of partially cold chow main noddles, topped with small pieces of ahi, with little to no taste. 

I wanted to like the place; I like the bright green paint job, the cozy feel, the diverse choices and even the waiter who liked the whole menu, but my dinner was a bland disappointment.
author: JP Z.

description:
This is place is incredible. Such a small and cute place ...I think about 20 seats total. The kitchen is out in the open (a la sushi bars) and the kitchen is no bigger than 10x10. 

Great prices, great food, great service and great atmosphere.

I'm afraid it would get too popular and prices would increase and it would be impossible to get a table.
author: Sammy S.

description:
We ate here for the first time two days ago.

Three stars for food, but it gets bumped up to four for ambiance. The restaurant fits maybe 16 people, and we sat at the ledge which overlooks the kitchen. I think this might be the only restaurant in San Francisco where the chef can - and does - take your order and serve your food. It's a very quaint place, sort of like eating at home in your own kitchen, though their kitchen is probably smaller than yours.

All the food was prepared directly in front of us and appears very fresh. I think I picked up a few cooking techniques! Everything we ate was quite tasty, flavorful and felt "healthy." 

We had the pomelo arugula salad and nagasaki breaded chicken/vegetables for appetizers. The latter was especially tasty. For dinner we had the annot lamb ragout, and the lanzhou noodles and seared tuna. I loved the lamb ragout. The lanzhou had a lot of garlic but it was not overpowering. The tuna was really good, but wasn't the best match with the noodles.

For a neighborhood restaurant, this is a new favorite. The wine list, though not huge, has some really nice and unusual wines.  It was very surprising to find such a wonderful place in a hole-in-the-wall setting across the street from UCSF.
author: Rebekah T.

description:
Pomelos is such a cute little place tucked away on Judah between 5th & 6th ave.  I went there last night and had an amazing provencal lamb.  I thought my meal was delicious until I tried my dates chicken curry and was in heaven!  So good!!!

The prices are reasonable, the wine list offers one type of each wine ($12 corkage fee) and they don't take reservations as I just found out a few minutes ago when I called them to let them know I was coming back again tonight (no joke).

It was a bit chilly, so bring a jacket!
author: David H.

description:
Yay! Another healthy food option.  This always makes me happy.  Victor and I went here for the first time yesterday and were a little concerned by the variety of ethnicities on the menu.  However, although the food may not be the most authentic, it certainly tasted good.

We had the miso soup with an awesome array of mushrooms to start.  It is huge and really delicious.  With that, we shared the Gilroy (a garlicky bok choy dish) that was very strong, but pretty good.  Maybe a little overwhelming with the lemon.

For our entree, we split the Manila which was kind of like a Filipino Jambalaya.  I have no idea whether it was at all true to the country's cuisine, but it tasted really good and I left happy and full. 

The only downsides:  It's the size of a large walk in closet and is a little pricey for the neighborhood.
author: Erica O.

description: This is very cute place, with lots of unique menu choices. I think it only fits about 10 customers. If you go, I would recommend sitting at the bar where you can watch them make your food. Everything I have had there has been, many different types of cuisine. The service was great, very helpful, but not annoying. I would give it 5 starts if it were priced slightly lower, because the food is not spectacular enough to match.
author: Flippy F.

description: yum!  while admittedly, the reason i've been to this restaurant is that a friend of mine lives 2 blocks away - it still warrants return trips instead of dissatisfaction. love love the otsu as an entree - filling and light w/ soba, flavored sauteed tofu, and cucumbers dressed in a vinaigrette.  yum!!
author: A C.

description:
This is our favorite neighborhood restaurant. We go there almost every week. Anyway, we love to watch them cook the meals and we love the combinations-there's always a little twist to a dish. My favorite is the fish of the day with quinoa and red pepper sauce and my husband loves the Havana with steak, rice and beans. Excellent service-very intimate.
Could use 1 more dessert option other than the gelatos, but we are usually so full that it is rare that we order a dessert there.
author: Julie T.

description:
Thank You for being so close to my place.

I'm never let down when the the tall chef with the curly hair is cooking.  

Sometime these guys rotate and the chef above is actually taking orders.  The others chefs are good also, but the guy above is a repeat performer.

I of course order the Havana (aka Da' Steak).  Plantains with fried rice and a flank steak served wrapped in an open banana leaf.  MMMMMMMMM
author: RiCH K.

description: We happened upon this sweet small restaurant for the first time tonight. This place is awesome. A cozy space with fantastic food-- we had the "Havana" and Koh Samui and both were excellent. Extremely high quality food- didn't have to worry about any mystery meat or questionable freshness here. It was tasty, well balanced, and combined interesting flavors. And, very important, the price was right. It fit the bill and was much better than your average fusion restaurant. Portions were perfect, and service was fast!  We will be going back often!
author: andrea S.

description:
i think probalby the smallest restaurant i've ever seen in my life.  i thought it was a walk in closet at first.  i think they only had 2-3 (very small) tables and some seats around the bar and along the window. you couldn't even fit a half dozen sardines in the place.  on the other hand, the food was really good. which makes it perfect for takeout.  :)  which is what i did.

had some business - i think a workout - in my hood and kept seeing the place along judah there and finally just went for it.  got the menu somehow, i think on my iPhone, called ... got the havana and the ratatoullie (i'm sure i butchered that spelling).  when i walked in to pick up the food it was a bit of a shock.  the stove was right there.  the sink where the guys were washing the dishes was right there.  you could swing a stick and hit: 1. the door, the guys cooking, the guys washing dishes, the people eating and the guy runnign your credit card for payment!  ha.  well, maybe i'm exaggerating but only by a couple yards.  

the food - on the other hand - was very impressive for such a tiny little spot.  and it's NOT asian fusion.  from the look of the menu and judging by what i ate, they only have a few asia-themed things and the stuff they make that's best has a south-american flavor.  the havana was a very good fried rice and meat dish.  the ratatooooeeeyy (or however you spell it) was a nicely european vegetable appetizer.  it was quick and moderately priced.  efficient.  just like the space that it's in.  i'll definitely be going back for take-out. 

just don't expect a luxurious dining-in experience!
author: dan h.

description:
All I need is one word - Yummy.
Other than that the server was really friendly and helpful and the tidbits of eavesdropping conversations were interesting (seriously impossible to avoid with the size off the place.) Yes, it's friggin tiny, but worth the squeeze.
author: Michael A.

description:
sunday brunch here is crazy good! i had the best fresh squeezed oj ever. my brunch was phenomnial. farm fresh eggs, freshly made sausage (not nasty store bought links or pattys) w/ a side of fresh fruit including pom and mangos. yummy! overall the food at pomelo can be best decribed as unique, fresh and clean. 
-----------------
p.s. the place is very small so suck in your gut.
author: Natalie L.

description: I love this place.  I love the ambiance and the fact that it has a small seating area.  It's an excellent place to go for a good conversation over dinner.  The food is always fresh and I can hardly resist ordering the ayacucho every time I go.  But I haven't had something here that I didn't like.  The service is personal and friendly.  If it's full, I usually move on but I've also waited a few minutes for a table.  I sort of don't want to give it a review because I don't want it to become overrun!  I think they also do a lot of takeout but I enjoy dining in.
author: Anne F.

description: It was ok.  Small location, not many seats, but its different to see everything being made in front of you.  They have the tiniest bathroom that you ever did see.  It's like eating one of those pills that say "eat me" in Alice in Wonderland.  The curry chicken dish was very dense.  The beef dish I got was a bit awkward with the hamburger like toppings on the side.
author: Sharon M.

description: I was hoping Pomelo would be awesome but it wasn't.  I think there's a reason you don't see a lot of restaurants that split their focus by serving global cuisine.  It's really hard to do it well.  The flavors, the seasoning, the ingredients - they vary a lot by region and culture.  So when I went to Pomelo, I wanted to try a number of different things to make sure I was giving it a fair shake.  The dishes weren't true to their roots.  They were OK, but you could tell that compromises had been made in the selection of ingredients to simplify the shopping list for the restaurant. There's an abundance of cheap, amazing regional food in the Inner Sunset.  I don't think I'll return to Pomelo.
author: Melissa Y.

description: I do love the giant pomelo out front.  It's a small, cozy place, but too nice to be considered a hole in the wall.  I don't have major issues with this place but I'm not crazy about the actual food.  It sounds great on paper and the ingredients are fresh, but the flavor is lacking. The prices are high for what you get.  I'm not crazy but Asian fusion noodle shops in general but Pomelo is a lot better than Zao.
author: Lolia S.

description:
such a gimmick. looks cozy & cool. fancy name...worldly "sounding" offerings. real foodies don't fall for these attributes...'cause it is the food that really matters.

truth is:
service is sad.
the food is even sadder.
we got the favorites recommended by the server which were also the highest ticket items (like 16-20 bucks) and were so dissatisfied.
my seared tuna did not taste fresh and noodles were underwhelming...lacked flavor & heat......maybe this place was great before but i was there the day the cook & server stopped caring....

that's too bad...i was looking for another sunset staple & gem.
author: Tiger Lily ..

description: Pomelo is where I had my first date with my bf. This was 5 years ago so the menu is different now. I do remember ordering risotto and it was my first time trying it. It was not a good experience. I grabbed a napkin and spit it back out. Not what I expected on a first date. My date also ordered these cold appetizer dishes I thought were atrocious. I smiled politely and ate slowly while thinking when is this dinner over. However I do remember great customer service and dessert being delectable. Let's just say our first dinner date was memorable. I might have to give this place a try again.
author: K L.

description:
I went back to Pomelo after a gap of many years- did not enjoy it as much as I had before. the flavors used to be subtle- but today just seemed over done. 

Food also feels assembled, rather than freshly cooked. Maybe they should shorten their menu, and cook the food fresh.
author: Geetika G.

description: One of my favorite restaurants. I love that the theme is rice and grains versus chinese, thai, mexican, etc. A wonderful first date place...quaint, moderately priced, friendly. Each dish is named after a local cuisine...providing a conversation starter if the date gets off to an awkward start. My favorite dishes are the gilroy, otsu and koh samui. The wine list is also wonderful...small, but great selections and prices. Oh yeah...it only seats about 20 people and most of the seats are counter/bar seats.
author: Amy C.

description:
Very nice place to enjoy a simple dinner with a glass of wine. There was a variety of Asian dishes from different places, all kind of simplified to keep the taste but to get rid of some of the heaviness that really good Asian dishes can leave you with sometimes. I think that people who enjoy super spicy dishes and/or super salty dishes might be searching for the red and soy sauce in here. But if your mood is for something not SO exotic, then this place is a good choice. 

It's kind of small so I wouldn't bring a big group in there unless I called in advance. But if I was holding a private party for maybe 20 people, I'd look into booking this place. The waiter was really nice and paid attention to everyone. 

Great date night for busy and tired people!!
author: m. e.

description: What a cute LITTLE place! Stopped in for an early dinner and loved the menu. Food was OK, I had something that I had never tried before - noodles with some stewed lamb in it. Also tried a bite of the coconut curry.  Nothing to write home about, but I enjoyed the ambiance and very good service and would like to try more of their dishes!
author: De M.

description: I could not have hoped to find a better substitute for hospital cafeteria food.  Practically living at the hospital for three weeks, Pomelo was a great source of much needed nourishment and recharging. The food is nutritious, clean and delicious. Not only did I eat here 3-5 days a week but I brought my mom soups and sides when I couldn't cook for her.  Now that she's healed and out of the hospital I would gladly return when in the neighborhood.  Thanks for being there Pomelo!
author: Nicole F.

description: This place is as close to 5 stars without getting the full 5 from me.  Like others, Asian Fusion has always been kind of a joke cuisine to me.  As a fan of pure Asian flavors, most of the fusion food I have tried often seems to try too hard to be innovative rather than focusing on satisfying taste buds.  Pomelo, however, does an excellent job of this.  Despite a seemingly pretentious looking menu, my Koh Samui came out looking tasty and straightforward: a simple bowl topped w/ chicken, mushrooms, squash, eggplant, and string beans.  One bite in and it was packed full of flavor.  My boss went with the Ayacucho which also came out good.  Pretty much the only knock on this place is their size but it's amazing what they've been able to do with it.  No bigger than surrounding apartments, they managed to stuff a full kitchen, a few tables, and a bar area.  So waiting for a spot is common but well worth it.  A stellar return trip will likely earn a 5th star from me.
author: Derrick C.

description: Unusual for the sake of deliciousness.  No reservations at this location but on a Sunday night we sat our group of five at the corner (L-shaped) part of the bar that allowed us to still feel like we were at a table (sorta--at least we could all talk) and look at what was being cooked.  Small, small, small place.  But good.  Nice portions. Very nice service.  Each of us ordered something so differently flavored, it was fun to try everyone's dish of noodle or grain.  So yum. Highly recommended.
author: Megan G.

description: This restaurant is just fantastic!!  I was really blown by the quality of the food.  Absolutely amazingly priced. We probably would go more often if it were not for the limited space.
author: Sandra M.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in the City to have lunch! After a stressful meeting, a colleague and I decided to have lunch and walked down Judah. She had been there before and highly recommended it. We got lucky before the lunch crowd came in and grabbed the second to the last table. (Actually, there's only about 4 tables and the rest are counter spaces.) The menu was extensive and from all over the world. She recommended we share the Baja fish tacos and the chicken curry.....and boy, did she hit the jackpot! These dishes were incredible. The tacos were full of flavor, light and refreshing. And the curry was so wholesome ---- like Mom would make! It was so delicious. The sizes of every dish were extremely generous.....more than enough food for the both of us!
author: La C.

description:
sooo after spending 30 min. finding parking in the sunset.........

me and my girls finally arrived at pomelo. 
(hahah.. i cracked up when I saw a pomelo hanging over in front of the restaurant)
and was it worth spending 30 min. circling around finding parking? OH YESSS.

pomelo is so fresh, innovation, and cute! 
its a charming little organic restaurant. yess.. this place is so tiny that just by standing around waiting for a table, I accidentally leaned and turned off the lights.. TWICE. I am the "slow friend" who Phat T. noted. Choices are very limited, but its a changing menu that adjusts accordingly to fresh local ingredients available. Even though I didn't like my venezelian slow cooked beef that much, I love my friends' curry bowl entree and my other friend's Havana entree. the meat was grilled to perfection. The portion sizes are just right too. 

I'm coming back here for lunch one day.. since they serve the same stuff at night but for like $2-4 less.
author: Sue Y.

description: I'm giving Pomelo only 3 stars because it wasn't nearly as good as my mind expected it to be.  When I read the menu for the Cuban Fried Rice, my tastebuds went crazy, but the actual taste, while good, got really old really quick.  The small, cozy atmosphere was nice and the neighborhood was otherwise empty, but the food just wasn't as great as I thought it would be.  The fish tacos were really nice, but both my dish and my girlfriend's were a little off.  Neither got finished.  I'm not saying the food was bad, because it wasn't, it just didn't have staying power.
author: c o.

description: The food is tasty, but Pomelo engages in a very sneaky trick.  The menu advertises 1/2 reduced portions, but when you get the bill you'll discover they charge the same as for a full portion!  When I complained to the waiter, he gave the specious excuse that "there's only one price on the menu."  I say then it's the WAITER'S RESPONSBILITY to inform patrons about the price.  Where in the world does a restaurant openly offer half-portions, or small vs. large servings, and then charge for a full helping?  I'm not kiddding.  This is what Pomelo does.
author: John H.

description:
Pomelo is the perfect setting for a quiet, romantic meal. 

The cozy atmosphere and smaller dining room make for a more intimate experience. The wait, usually not more than 15 or 20 minutes on the weekends, is well worth it. 

The food is prepared utilizing a smart variety of rices, ginger, fresh cilantro, plantains, avocado, pepper coulis, fontina and swiss cheeses, to name a few. 

Worth noting is the Koh Samui, which blends spicy coconut curry, lime and jasmine rice with chicken and oriental long beans. Complimentary french bread and a good selection of wines add depth to the main dishes. For light lunches, choose between pan-fried fish, fresh garden green salads, and light rice dishes.

The waitstaff here are always very friendly and attentive, and you don't feel pressured to hurry through your meal. I enjoy the warm atmosphere and being entertained (and amazed) by the chefs who prepare everything- literally- right in front of you. 

If this location is too small, try the Church Street Pomelo- which offers twice the seating and a slightly expanded menu.
author: Alex G.

description:
Disappointment is a bit of an understatment. I had high hopes of this cute little restaurant, especially after reading some of the reviews. Initially I was excited about the "destination" theme of the menu, and fiddled between a couple of dishes to try. 
We started off with the aosta - which is polenta with mushrooms. I have never experienced polenta gone so wrong before. It lacked flavor, and the texture of the mushrooms were so... unpleasant. 
I had the weekend special for the main course. It consisted of halibut on top of risotto. Well, it wasn't bad, but it wasn't good. Again, it lacked flavor, seasoning, etc etc. I actually had to add salt! (i never add salt!!) It definitley was over priced for what it is. 
After the two disappointing dishes, I decided against their dessert.  Usually I would give places a second chance, but I have no desire to return. I am glad I tried it, so I can say I've been. Now I'm moving on to the next little eatery in the area.
author: jennifer h.

description: I enjoyed my dinner at Pomelo, and was happy to find a place in my neighborhood that wasn't Italian, burgers, or crepes. This is a tiny place and I liked that the most, especially because we were treated like royalty. Prices were a bit high, but the quaint atmosphere made me willing to pay it.
author: Jon F.

description:
high on flavour and a very charming and cute setting.  i really like this place but i think i am a protein needy guy-- i come hungry and leave hungrier.  that is not Pomelo's fault it is just how i was put together.  i still like it and i know what to expect-- great execution on flavour.  

Buen Provecho!
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: I've been here a lot with my parents and I am satisfied each time I go.  The place is small but it is cute and the food is great.
author: Sonya T.

description:
I had been stuck inside all day and desperately needed some human interaction when I called up my neighbor hoping she'd want to grab a bite with me. She suggested jumping on the N and taking it up a few stops to the inner sunset to this little restaurant with a pear above it's door. I said ok not really knowing what to expect. 

We walked into a cheerful and casual space that sits 20 at most and sat at a long bar-type table infront of the windows, viewing the ugly 1970s apartment building across the street. We briefly laughed at the lifesize Obama cutout standing at the half-open window of one of the units, the wind banging its cardboard head against the pane. Then we dug into the menu. 

The cuisine is best described as Global Fusion, each entree combining an intresting mix of global ingredients yet none of them sticking to traditional style. I had the Havana, which was a tender and delicious strip steak served over fried rice with black beans and plantains. It was quite delicious and fresh even though I could have done without the citrus flavor. My friend had the weekend special, which was a yummy white fish of some sort. Cooked to perfection for sure, served over a risotto of some sort. We sampled each others picks and decided that we chose well. 

Even though we only had one glass of wine each (she had a Reisling and I had a Pinot Noir), we decided they had a fantastic wine list. One thing that even dive bars in San Francisco manage to do well. Guess that's a perk when you live an hour from wine country. 

Anyway, I'm picky about giving away four and five stars, so I decided to give this one a three. That said, I did think about giving it a four. Maybe I'll try it again. If I change my mind about the rating, I'll let you know.
author: Jennifer G.

description: I can't believe people have criticized this place for small portions; every time I go there, the portions seem huge. I've been many times and I've always had great food and great service. I like sitting at the counter and watching the chef cook; he's very good.
author: Kathleen B.

description: we had the sisig tofu, some glass noddle dish and the ahi with garlic noodles. the flavors were developed well but we couldn't enjoy them the way they were meant to be enjoyed because everything that was salty was overly salted and everything that was sweet was overly sweet. the garlic noodles were supposed to be slightly sweet but it was more than slight for sure.
author: Regina C.

description: Should I write this review?  Oh, how I love this place.  Don't want to ruin such delicious perfection.  It's hard enough getting in there on a weekend night as it is.  But must give kudos to original flavors, wonderful atmosphere, great service, and the joy of sitting at the counter where watching the artist at the burners is like tuning in to Iron Chef live.  Enjoy -- just don't take my seat.
author: Blue B.

description: If you can make it up the hill, and excellent late in the date bite to eat! Although for me I went with my brother. Serving food with complicated flavors from deceivingly simple dishes. Each bite invited something new. In addition, the small high end quick eat feel added a very nice intimacy for conversation.
author: Christian M.

description: The "Havana" was excellent (Cuban style dish with skirt steak and plantains).  Cozy place.  Most of the seating is at the counter, but that gives you a front row seat to watch the chef in action.
author: Chris T.

description: Came here for lunch with a friend.  Always wondered what this place would be like when I would pass by, but never stepped inside until now.  As it's been stated many times on here, this place is tiny - you have to get here before the lunch rush hour to get some seats.  My friend and others had told me that this place is expensive for lunch and in general, and it certainly is - it's about $10-16 average for person, depending on what you get.  I tried the Solo (Indonesian style soup w/noodles, chicken and veggies) and thought it was okay - it wasn't bad, but it failed to leave a lasting impression on me.  For the $10 it costs here, I think the Singapore noodles over at Lime Tree is much better, in my opinion.  That dish on the other hand still to this day, a few years later, still makes me want to return there.  I tried the Manila and thought that was better than the Solo, but that is essentially just a gourmet type of Pancit - it shouldn't be more than $10.  The Havana sounded good and I would have ordered that, but spending $15 on lunch?  Are you kidding me, I don't get paid well to be eating like that.
author: Kahanalei M.

description: A-mazing food. Fresh, seasonal...delicious. Koh Samui is my favorite, but I've tried most everything and LOVED it. Large portions so it's perfect for lunch the next day! Reasonably priced. Once of my favorite restaurants in teh city. It's small so you should call ahead to make sure there is room. I suggest sitting at the bar so you can watch the chef work his magic.
author: Katie R.

description: This is an incredibly charming little place.  It maxes out at like 12 patrons and if you sit at the counter you can watch the chef prepare your food in a kitchen the size of a broom closet.  The food is creative, delicious and very fresh tasting.  The ambiance is quiet and intimate.  Overall a great place for two friends to catch up, two lovers to quietly enjoy an evening or two strangers to get to know each other before heading home for "just one cup of coffee."  You can add a third person, but they're probably going to have to have their appetizer on the curb and thus unlikely to join in on the "cup of coffee."
author: Jason S.

description: I like small restaurants esp this one.  I've been here twice. It's maybe a 10 seater restaurant. I love sitting by the cook's corner to watch him prepare the dishes for us.  My favorite was the steak and cubano rice paired with red wine. The desserts were okay; you can get ciaobella ice cream anywhere.
author: Jboogie L.

description: I typically don't like fusion but Pomelo has some really good fusion dishes.  Plus, at this neighborhoody restaurant we sat at the bar watching the owner make all the dishes which was pretty fun and everything looked and tasted really good and fresh.  I'd definitely go back to Pomelo.
author: Julie K.

description: What I love about this Pomelo versus the Pomelo on Church is how tiny it is. Request a spot at the counter so that you can watch your meal being prepared and interact with the staff. The menu changes often and I haven't ever been disappointed. FYI... because of the lack of space, be sure to get a reservation.
author: Juls M.

description: Small place (I thought it'd be slightly roomier inside), sat at the counter overlooking the people cooking. Not too many people inside on a weekday. Ordered a noodle dish off their simple menu. Thought it was pretty good. My friends enjoyed their meals as well. Service was good. I still don't know what a pomelo is.
author: Janel Y.

description:
get ready to be best friends with the table next to you. Pomelo is a great place to dine solo with one other person. more than that and you'll be sitting in the kitchen (you practically are anyways :) ) 

I haven't been to the Noe Valley one I stay true to the Inner Sunset. I had the Havana. Great adaptation but a little salty.
author: Juhi D.

description: I like going here because it is the cutest little restaurant! The kitchen is in full view so you can see everything happen, the food is delicious and interesting and the prices are decent.
author: kristin e.

description: hyped?  the dish I had was too freakin salty.  The place is literally a hole in the wall and you have to be a size 0 to feel properly comfortable in this really tiny place.  I had the jamaican rice dish...it was too salty!
author: Grace M.

description: Ordered take-out from here last night, and the reviews are generally correct: small space, open kitchen (i.e., lots of food aroma everywhere due to bad ventilation, but generally clean, well-decorated space), and expensive. I ordered the Havana--I was craving some steak and plantains--and expected more food for the ~$15 I paid. Even so, it was quite good and can't wait to come back here again!
author: Richie K.

description:
When I lived nearby, I was a big takeout fan of Pomelo on Judah's Koh Samui (described in detail by an earlier reviewer), which thankfully never seems to disappear from their seasonal menu.  I understand it's a staple on Church Street, too.  

Tried to eat at the restaurant a few times but we were usually crowded out -- either because there weren't seats available or because it was just too noisy/cramped.  I really can't believe that anyone would complain about portion sizes here  -- I always had some leftovers (and believe me, that's saying something!).
author: Dennis H.

description:
Definitely a tasty albeit tiny place.  Amazing flavor combinations.  Even for a simple dish like their polenta was so delicious, I was wiping the plate clean with my bread.  oh, and i think i remember the bread being whole wheat or something healthy of that nature.
oh, i got the pomelo salad and definitely recommend it.  the hazelnuts are a nice touch
author: J B.

description: It's got a huge menu full of items at easy to manage prices. The plus side is that I all want to eat al of them. Nice big bowls of soba, coconut sorbet for dessert, sake, and more. Gotta come back and try it again.
author: Jeremy W.

description: The food and service was incredible.  Huge portions, great prices and a very reasonable wine list.  I'm still dreamining about the chicken/cocounut/curry dish...  The one draw back is that there really is no good table.  I have no suggestions for how to change it around but either you sit right by the kitchen or right by the door and I was on the door side getting drafts, bumped and jostled every 30 seconds.  I guess the best bet would be to sit at the counter.  For a date night, swing by- get it go and find a romantic spot in the park.
author: Lauren L.

description: Very interesting fusion.  Never had anything I didn't like, love the setting.  Definitely worth checking out; I prefer to go for lunch, just be ready to spend a little.  I suggest ordering an appetizer and two entrees between two people, it might be too much food, but you want to try several things.  My fav: Ayacucho.
author: Chase N.

description: Awesome. Cute, tiny little place with a range of international, mostly noodle-based dishes. I had quinoa cakes with fresh fish - very very good, fresh, and healthy. It's a little cramped, but you get to watch the cook do his thing. Great execution on the concept. I'll be back!
author: Bowen D.

description: It's been already reviewed extensively for the food-- it's good, and not in a bad Asian fusion kind of way, and the portions are satisfying. The number of seats at the counter is about the same as the number of seats at tables, so solo diners are not at all part of the minority here, but their settings can be placed a little close together.  But the advantage here at the counter is the view of the spare but clean, open kitchen on display and your food looks all the more appetizing when you see, hear and smell the process.
author: Chris B.

description: This place is so cozy and cute! Had the weekend special, panko crusted trout with chanterelle/pear risotto and it was amazing. Really reasonable and overall great experience!
author: Caitlin C.

description: I love pomelo, the food is great, and I always leave full and happy.  They have a really interesting eclectic menu and are helpful with veggie options.  I always get the koh samui with tofu instead of chicken.  I crave it.
author: Sky B.

description: I really liked this tiny space. It was quaint and homey- open kichen, seats by the window. Service was attentive and great. Wine was extremely reasonable. But the food was just okay. I tried the Biloxi- cheddar-jalepeno polenta cakes in a spicy slow cooked pork stew with tomatoes and okra. The pork wasn't all that tender... although the broth was pretty good. Also sampled Manila- stir fried rice noodles tossed with prawns, chicken, chinese sausage, vegetables, with scallion and lemon. That was okay as well.  Also had a side of tofu- it was alright, not that flavorful. I would give them another try as they change their menu seasonally.
author: Monica P.

description: I finally got around to try out "that place with big ole fruit outside" and the food was pretty good.  I loved the global+asian fusion perspective on the dishes - at least they're trying to go beyond the completely overdone Vietnamese fusion thing.  You can call this place "cramped" or "cozy", but I thought the small space added to the charm of Pomelo.  Service was great and I was suprised that they didn't try to hurry us to turn over the tables.  Great place for a party of 2, but try to get there sooner rather than later to avoid a long wait.
author: Tim L.

description: This is a super cute and small place close to the N Judah.  On a Sunday night, however, we got a table right away even though it was otherwise a full house.  Our appetizer was mouthwatering (polenta and mushroom ragu), and our main dishes were not bad -- cold noodles with cucumber and tofu (a bit overpriced at $10 in my opinion).  Too bad the dessert menu consists solely of ciao bello gelato.  The server forgot my drink order, but otherwise was attentive.  I'd go back again if they added more (more than one) vegetarian entrees...
author: Stacy R.

description: Places like this make me proud to be a San Franciscan... This place serves delicious California Cuisine out of a tiny but fashionable location in the inner sunset.  I love the fact that you can sit at the bar and watch them cook your food, and the menu is eclectic and unique-- with dishes inspired from all corners of the world.  The prices are very reasonable as well, wtih entrees ranging from $9 - $14...... I have paid $15 - $23 for similar quality dishes at other locations. The food here is a great value and is delicious.  This place is like one of the "secrets" you dont want to get out.
author: James M.

description: Cute little place, cozy and intimate, just don't sit by the door. It definitely needs a curtain to block the wind or something. The food was pretty good,  I was surprised to find a pretty interesting variety of Asian and international foods that didn't taste so much as fusion as I thought, but instead the flavors were very true to their origins. Filipino, Thai, Chinese, Cuban, and what have yous. I've been here twice and have enjoyed it throughout. Their sorbets and gelatos were incredible, especially greentea with white chocolate and rasberry cabernet. It can very well be a regular dinner option of mine.
author: Joey W.

description: This place has got to be the smallest -- best place I've tried for lunch.  My bedroom is probably bigger but the good stuff that comes out their kitchen covers for it.  I ordered the Lanzhou which was like noodle with seared tuna over it.  I hear that their menu changes seasonally and im down to try it every season.  Seems to be very busy during lunch hours, probably because of all the students and workers of UCSF.  If it's in this kind of high demand where it always seems to be full, then you have to try it.  Overall I'd definitely come back to this place again and hopefully it will not be full and crammed.
author: Warren G.

description: If you're looking for a neighborhood gem with great food, reasonable prices, and very good service - this is the place!  My friend and I shared the Puerto Princesa and the Chiang Mai - both very good. Menu has a lot of noodle dishes with a very eclectic flare, although mostly Asian influenced. You can sit at the counter and watch as the chef works. It's a small place so if you have to wait a bit, it's worth it!
author: Dorothy W.

description: Loving this place. Small, clean and cute with amazing food and great service. I found it pretty difficult to decide on a dish because they all sounded so great. We had the Varallo, the ayacucho and the manilla. The wine was really good too. I'll definitely be going back to Pomelo soon!
author: Dana L.

description: This Pomelo branch has a lot of reviews and doesn't really need mine, but we have enjoyed going here so much it seems like the right thing to do. If you know what you're getting into (tiny, minimal decor, non-"authentic" Asian) you can't do much better. My sister lives down in China Basin and she always asks if she can come to my neighborhood when we have dinner, and by "my neighborhood" she means Pomelo. What's the appeal? Not the least of it is that Pomelo always has something for every nearly every freaky diet San Francisco can throw at it, executed pretty well. I'm a vegetarian: no problem. For several months my sister was following the Paleo diet: no problem. My mom eats almost nothing but meat and starches: no problem. My husband's coworker is vegan: no problem. Every once in a while you'll hit a dud (once I tried a tomato soup that tasted exactly like pizza sauce), but come back next month and they'll have a new menu. I like the aggressive attention to local and seasonal ingredients, and I love how pleasant they make it to pack in several servings of vegetables in a meal. Portion sizes are reasonable, prices are reasonable, the wine list is good, service is attentive but unobtrusive (although it slips a little when they get very busy, but that's true anywhere). The small scale of the place makes it very intimate even though decor-wise, it's basically a shed. Pomelo doesn't complete with white tablecloth restaurants, but it pretty much owns its niche. It reminds me of neighborhood restaurants in Paris, where the ambition isn't to become a destination but to make it easy for people who live and work nearby to eat well. So we keep coming back.
author: D E A.

description:
One of my ABSOLUTE favorite places in the city. I love the food, but I also love the fact that I can bring just about anyone here and have them adore their meals as well. Not too many places like that.

We've been going here and to the Noe Valley location for years and love both of them. Definitely true about the "cozy" feel of this location- it's tiny!
author: Elizabeth P.

description:
cozy, tasty and definitely inexpensive. 
staff is friendly, accommodating and helpful.
simple space with great taste.
author: Fred C.

description:
We went a little earlier than the crowd and got a table for 3 of us including our child.  NO booster seat, but she managed.
We ordered Pomelo (salad), Manila (noodle dish) and Havana (steak and bean / rice, avocado).  All quite tasty.
Nice little place.
author: Miinno N.

description: The ambiance is what makes this place.  It's a little tucked in restaurant, an afterthought really.  The space is really crammed and it can only seat 20 people at most; but that's what makes it work.  A great place for a date.  Food was a little pricey, but the portions are larger than most trendy-ish places.  Asian fusion is difficult to pull off well, and they don't do the best job, but the food is okay, probably better with good company.
author: Sanjiv B.

description: I'll never know if the food is any good given the rudeness of the staff.  Given the small size of the restaurant you would think they would be a little more accomodating.  Arrived there on a Friday night after 8:00 p.m. and the place was full - fine.  It was freezing outside so we asked if we could go around the block to get warm somewhere else and have them call us when the table was ready. The answer was that they could call us but if they could not guarantee us that we could be seated unless we actually stood there until the table was ready.  Have never had such attitude even in LA or NY and will certainly not put up with it for some neighborhood place in SF.  No interest at all in whether it is any good or not as there are plenty of great places in this town with staff that actually care about their customers.
author: Lee Y.

description: don't be scared off by the size of this demure restaurant.  it may be the smallest food establishment i've ever seen, but somehow they are able to offer a diverse menu and feed 16 people all at once.  best miso soup i've ever had.  now i know what it is actually supposed to taste like when care is given.  watermelon radish, carrot, and beet salad-fresh, crisp, and delicately dressed.  cold soba noodles with pan fried tofu left me wanting another.  i shared all of this with a friend and we were both perfectly satisfied.  she also ordered the crab, asparagus soup that was interesting and delicious.   the kitchen closes precisely at 2pm for lunch, so if you're going to graze as we did, tell them in advance.
author: Tammy N.

description: I used to love this place, hence the generous two stars. But I ate there tonight and EVERYTHING but the fish tacos was super salty. I don't think I'll be going back again.
author: felicia s.

description: i love pomelo! i like that fact that its global cuisine. the ingredients in my food tasted extremely fresh, i want to go back already! i just wish it were a bit bigger...
author: Dae M.

description: I have been eating here for at least 10 years and love it.  Very small intimate space, with nice staff.  Sitting at the counter sometimes is fun distraction also. The Havana is a great dish.
author: Mark c.

description: The food is fresh, tasty and filling.  The place itself is small, which can either be endearing or a bit impossible when it's full or close to full and you can hear everyone else's conversations.  Staff is friendly and
author: Amanda H.

description: love this little restaurant. food is fresh and in season without being pretentious. large portions. i like sitting at the bar to watch the chef cook.
author: suzanne w.

description: so much charm & good taste packed into such a tiny place
author: John P.

description: good creative food but i was pretty annoyed when i went to pick up our huge $200 take-out order and the guy working there was really rude and brusque with me and made it pretty clear that i took up too much room in his small restaurant when i checked our order before leaving. i'd give this place a second chance and hope i got a nicer wait person since the food is worth it.
author: lisa w.

description: A bit on the pricey side but they give generous proportions.  The food is interesting but they're a hit or miss for me.  Some dishes were excellent but this one rice dish I tried was not to my liking.  I guess you should stick to the noodles here since that's what they're known for.  The restaurant is small like everyone mentioned so don't expect to bring large parties.  You may want to check out the other location for more room.
author: Eric L.

description: was already a fan from the Church St. outpost, so was definitely happy to pick up a fresh, yummy panzanella-style salad as a study break lunch.  just wish they took credit cards for smaller dollar amounts!
author: Nat K.

description: with dishes inspired from cabo to callao and gilroy to havana this place lives up to its by-line, "intimate, simple and undeniably global".  i've been to the one on judah twice now and both times i've walked away saying 'wow'.  i think this is one of those places you get to infrequently but look forward to it with anticipation because its always one of the best meals you have had recently.  its a small space with only a few tables with gracious service and a cozy intimate feel. dont go here expecting a fancy dinner with table cloth service.  its simple, supple and a meal worth eating.
author: Kevin J.

description: Great little restaurant in the Inner Sunset.  Went there only because it was close to my home.  Great prices for a nice portion of food and a good selection of beer and drinks for cheap.  I thought that the food was a little less than amazing, but the atmosphere and service made for an enjoyable dining experience.  Will likely be going back soon.  Maybe for lunch this time.
author: Alex B.

description: As I approached the ivory door of Pomelo, my heart fluttered and a tear fell from my eye. I took a deep breath - gasp - was i... in for the meal of my life... or, quite possibly a trip to the Baghdad/Islamabad/Twin Towers... you name it... of  SF dinerettes. The darling waiter appeared like a meadowlark from behind a grassy knoll, displaying his personal delight for the menu as if it were a side order of love. I ordered the blissful orzo pasta salad and instantly  came in my pants. The gelato made me feel as if I had grown wings and soared above the bay, only to land on a soft bed of pillowy lace upon the top of the giant pomelo that hangs above the majestic entrance to this  exquisite establishment. eat here, or you're probably a fascist.
author: Kt M.

description: Great dishes. A repeat favorite is the Koh Samui, the cuban steak dish, and the fish tacos. I like the cozy size of the place. The service is great, the perfect neighborhood restaurant for any old weeknight or a special date night.
author: Jen W.

description: cute little noodle joint cloaked in feels-like-home style. brightly lit interior, decent food, and nice staff. i definitely liked my dish (seared ahi tuna over egg noodles) but there is always room for superiority.
author: julia r.

description: it's average in tastiness but way too much $$ for what you get. i don't know why but it's usually crowded (but i think it only seats like 10 people max). i had this dish with lemon grass, chicken and rice. and some over-priced lumpia which they cut in half to make it look like i got more food than i did. i guess you could eat it. i guess. :(
author: Tin-Tin E.

description: I've eaten here twice over many months for lunch and have had identical experiences.  The food is very, very good and a little pricey for the size of the portions, however the server has been exceptionally rude.  I'm a neighbor and would probably bring my family here weekly if it weren't for the service.
author: Sarah S.

description: i really love the concept of this place, simple, healthy, and ethnic-inspired dishes.  for some reason, i wasn't impressed with the scallops or the lanzhou noodles.  i liked the fact that i was able to watch the chef prepare my food.  maybe i'll go back during a different season.
author: Big e.

description: Delicious small little cafe/bistro with good prices, decent portions (go to Buca di Beppo or Sizzler if you want to be a pig) using very creative ingredients.  Everything was very fresh and like the others said, it's cool to watch a maestro in his kitchen.
author: Dave Z.

description: order Koh Samui and Havana
author: fivewordsorless ..

description: The place is small but the food is so good.  There's always a line but it's well worth the wait.  Their seared tuna over garlic noodles is to die for.  It's a plus that the owners are very friendly and nice.
author: Kate L.

description: I love this place. It is definitely worth going to for super yummy and healthy food- lot of fish, veggies and whole grains. The portions are big and the prices are totally reasonable for the quality of the food, especially as compared to other SF restaurants.
author: Alexis O.

description: I've had lunch and dinner here... and both times it was pretty darn good!  My only qualm is that it's a really small space... but really it isn't a big deal - only when it's full.  If you're a meat eater definitely try the Havana... my sig -o had it for dinner and I wanted it for myself!  Oh and the gelato is pretty good as well...  Also, if you sit at the bar you can see the chef at work, which is cool - at least I think so.
author: Abigail C.

description: Came here about two weeks ago with a friend and was surprisingly really dissappointed. I'm not sure whether or not we just both happened to order the wrong dishes or we just went on a bad night, but I'm willing to give the restaurant the benefit of the doubt since it sounds like people have enjoyed the food before. My friend ordered the ramen noodles, which came out soggy, swimming in a bowl of tasteless undersalted soup with what was supposed to be sliced pork on top but was really mostly sliced fat. My dish was a japanese yaki soba type stir fry  which proved to be a disasterous cornucopia of mismatched flavors topped with bonito, this fish food like substance that didn't make any sense whatsoever.  Overall, I was quite disappointed with the food; I could have had noodles ten times better from a one eyed quadraplegic street vendor in Chinatown. The decor was nice though, and the waiter seemed friendly too, so I felt badly about complaining... wish I could have had a better experience.
author: Noodle S.
